post_text: I have my first medicare patient (yay!) in my private practice. I am an OT credentialed with Medicare B only, and this patient has Humana Full Access PPO. Is this considered out of network? And what is the best billing practice moving forward? TIA!!

comments.text: It sounds like this is a Medicare Replacement plan - not Medicare.

Yes. This plan most likely has OON benefits being PPO. You will confirm benefits for OON and then you will bill. Reimbursement will be based on Medicare Fee Schedule. At this time of the year, need to check OON deductible etc. as well as Copay. You can ask for payer ID when you call and submit electronically through your EMR.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have my first medicare patient (yay!) in my private practice. I am an OT credentialed with Medicare B only, and this patient has Humana Full Access PPO. Is this considered out of network? And what is the best billing practice moving forward? TIA!!

COMMENT 1: It sounds like this is a Medicare Replacement plan - not Medicare.

COMMENT 2: Yes. This plan most likely has OON benefits being PPO. You will confirm benefits for OON and then you will bill. Reimbursement will be based on Medicare Fee Schedule. At this time of the year, need to check OON deductible etc. as well as Copay. You can ask for payer ID when you call and submit electronically through your EMR.

Does anyone in mass have reimbursement amounts for codes 97535, 97530, 97112, 97140 (OT codes, basically) and evals for bcbs? Feel free to DM me. 

I am in CT, moving to MA next year - I have a hybrid pelvic rehab clinic in CT and considering going fully cash based in MA but also considering staying in network with BCBS only. Thanks!

comments.text: Take a look at Strata PT‚Äôs website for their real time reimbursement list. This will give you a good idea by payer and locations Generally, clinics are not supposed to share their contracted rates which is why most people won‚Äôt give you a straight answer on this question. For us, BCBS is a great payer in Mass and has been pretty easy to work with. The contracting process takes about 90 days and up to another 90 to add a new employee to your existing contract, so be ready for that, time/planning-wise.

post_text: Anyone here know what is up with TriEast? Per my credentialing person, they are still only accepting a few types of providers. He said I can become an "out of network provider" - but I would rather just do cash + superbill because, what is the point of being an "OON provider"?! Will my current Tricare patients not get reimbursed with their superbills?! Thanks!

comments.text: It‚Äôs easy to be out of network provider then your patients turn in their own receipts and the prime people know they need a Referal regardless but that‚Äôs for them not fir you if you are in a direct access state.  Then as long as a Dr orders PT they usually can turn it in if going to an OON provider and get about 62-65% reimbursement.  Win for you both. (Just have the patient check with Tricare to see what is needed for their plan.  I just have to send in my updated PT license renewal to keep it going.  Tricare is the only one you actually have to sign up to be out of network provider everyone else, you just are.  Good luck!

Certain types of tricare will reimburse for OON services, but normally require for providers to be classified as out of network. There is a good chance that tricare will not reimburse based on a superbill. (My husband is a navy vet and when we had tricare we were not guaranteed reimbursement if we went out of network and they did not authorize it.)

Hello, question for those who bill Blue Cross Blue Shield OON. How do you facilitate the process of checks /payments being returned to you by your patients?
Thank you and Happy New Year!

comments.text: Unfortunately most BCBS plans ignore the assignment of benefits and always sent checks to the pt regardless. We always keep a credit card on file and instruct the pt to bring the check in within 10 days or we will charge the card on file. This is in our financial policy.
Benefits are assigned to us, not patient. Much easier.

post_text:
Hello all! Does anyone have experience working with someone who has BCBS primary, and Medicare secondary? I am mobile and primarily OON/cash pay, but am participating in Medicare Part B. This is a process I'm finding online, and looking for clarification and confirmation of understanding.

From what I'm seeing, I would try to submit the claim to BCBS (or have the patient submit the claim?) for OON benefits. BCBS would likely pay nothing, and then send back an EOB stating as much. This EOB could then be submitted to Medicare, for usual reimbursement (0% until deductible, 80% after). The patient would then be responsible for the remainder (20%). 

Does this sound accurate? Or are there other components I need to be aware of?

comments.text:
Med part b will pay 80% and then bcbs will do the 20%. 

I'm non-par and all of the claims I've submitted this far have been automatically forwarded to the secondary.

My experience is that bcbs will only issue the payment to the patient for OON claims.  For that reason,  we keep a card on file so that way once the claim processes and if bcbs has paid the patient we can still get paid. All of our patients have sent the money directly to us,  but I know that some therapists have had to eat the cost of the 20% because the patient refused to send the money that bcbs sent them.

I used to do billing, yes that sounds about right. 

Sometimes the payment and EOB goes to patient so make sure you have in written form and signed by patient that it is their responsibility to provide that to you, or they would be liable.

full_thread_text:

For that reason,  we keep a card on file so that way once the claim processes and if bcbs has paid the patient we can still get paid. post_text: Hello everyone I am in the process of becoming uncaged and owning my own clinic. But I am concerned with finding an insurance that I can look into getting for my wife, son, and I that would cover health, dental, and vision and not overly priced. Any suggestions where I can start looking?

comments.text: Look into the health sharing plans like Christian Healthcare Ministries-and then sign up with a direct care physician ($50-65 per month) you will be shocked at got cheap things are through your direct care physician -antibiotics $6, blood pressure meds-$ 8 blood work $29 -so much cheaper than insurance!!

We went through a local insurance broker for our 2026 insurance. We were previously using insurance through my husband's work but needed a change for 2026 because our premiums were going to be sky high when we only go to the doctor for wellness visits and maybe 1 urgent care visit a year. We got a much better quote compared to what marketplace was offering.

post_text: I see patients privately at their home and haven‚Äôt run into this yet. I have a former patient wanting to see me after her TKR. From my understanding I cannot accept cash from her, she is under Medicare and the services I‚Äôll provide are medically necessary and covered. Is this correct?

comments.text: You can bill Part A for home health as long as she meets homebound criteria and then switch to Part B when she is no longer homebound

That is correct, cash cannot be accepted for medically necessary and covered services which it would be. If they're discharged from PT and have goals beyond what is medically necessary then you could though. There is a bill up for PTs to be able to opt out of Medicare and then you would be able to but currently as it stands we are not able to opt out

post_text: For PTs billing out of network how much have you seen in reimbursement for 4 units of physical therapy?

comments.text: All you have to do is submit a claim and see. Your patient won't be meeting their OON deductible anytime soon so you will have plenty of data on what the plan pays. All of them pay differently OON even within the same carrier. Some plans pay dollar for dollar and some pay a % above Medicare. If you are billing OON you need to be collecting your cash pay rate and by the time you might get reimbursed you will know what the plan pays.

Completely depends on the plan/carrier. Sometimes $80, sometimes $500 like stated above. 

We balance bill and always collect up to our cash rate if insurance low balls us. We disclose this ahead of time and it‚Äôs very legal to do so. Their EOBs even say it to the patient that the provider is OON and may charge higher than what the EOB says.

post_text:
Recently got a referral with pt Medicare and Medicaid. 
I am par with Medicare but never worked with Medicaid. How does it work with Medicaid being secondary insurance? Ôøº

Do I need to apply for approval or something? Will the claims forward to them after Medicare processes them?

Any guidance is highly appreciated üôè

Happy Holidays üòä

comments.text: Yes. The claims will be automatically forwarded if you have set up correctly in your emr. But if you are not in network with medicaid you may not get paid. Also you can not collect that 20% from pt.

As a general rule, Medicare will take care of the secondary...like if it's UHC secondary, you don't have to be in network with UHC to get the 20% that Medicare doesn't cover. I am only credentialed with Medicare and I still get paid by my patients' secondary. I don't take Medicare/Medicaid bc in NJ, Medicaid won't cover the extra 20%

full_thread_text:
POST: Recently got a referral with pt Medicare and Medicaid. 
I am par with Medicare but never worked with Medicaid. How does it work with Medicaid being secondary insurance? Ôøº

Do I need to apply for approval or something? Will the claims forward to them after Medicare processes them?

Any guidance is highly appreciated üôè

Happy Holidays üòä

COMMENT 1: Yes. The claims will be automatically forwarded if you have set up correctly in your emr. But if you are not in network with medicaid you may not get paid. Also you can not collect that 20% from pt.

COMMENT 2: As a general rule, Medicare will take care of the secondary...like if it's UHC secondary, you don't have to be in network with UHC to get the 20% that Medicare doesn't cover. I am only credentialed with Medicare and I still get paid by my patients' secondary. I don't take Medicare/Medicaid bc in NJ, Medicaid won't cover the extra 20%

post_text: I have a patient has both tufts HMO (I am out of network)and VA insurance. Is one insurance reimburse better with PT? Also, with VA insurance, do I have to be in their network in order to provide care for their patient? Can I issue superbill to patient and VA insurance will reimburse later? Thank you very much for your insight in advance.

comments.text: VA has to authorize treatment. Generally, you have to be a VA provider. In rare situations, if a VA provider type is not within a certain distance, the VA will allow an outside provider and will coordinate directly with that provider for payment. Patient will not be reimbursed via a superbill. The patient can pay for treatment, but shouldn't expect to be reimbursed.
Yeah you need to be in network with CCN and see who is the one overseeing for me it's UHC.

post_text: I‚Äôm thinking about starting a vestibular mobile practice. I‚Äôd like to do cash only, but know many of the patients who need treatment would be likely be Medicare patients. I‚Äôve heard that I can‚Äôt charge a Medicare patient my cash rate as I‚Äôd have to submit through Medicare. I could apply to become a Medicare provider, but when canalith repositioning is an untimed code, I fear it wouldn‚Äôt adequately pay for my time spent with the patient. Any advice? Thanks so much!!

comments.text:
I typically use a lot of neuro re-ed for vestibular patients. 

One thing I wanted to throw out there is that yes you're going to get a lot of Medicare patients. Medicare pays decently. The problem is so many patients nowadays have the Medicare replacement plans and then you're going to have to deal with those. 
Rather than deal with all of the administrative BS, I wind up referring all of my insurance patients to Luna now and let them handle it. I get paid a bit less but it's so worth it because I can literally treat and not worry about anything else. Just throwing up that as a possible idea for you as well.
In my area I get 74 a visit if I refer to the platform.

You‚Äôll end up charging eval plus CRM which is a good paying combo. When you do it as a follow up, you‚Äôll use CRM only when the test is positive and then you‚Äôll use NRE/ Self-care/tA/ TE for the rest of the session anyways

post_text: If someone is using the VA for the home health, can we see them for Medicare part B?

comments.text:
Are they admitted to VA Home Based Primary Care Program?  The team included PT.  Seems to be some confusion about receiving HBPC PT at the same time skilled home heath PT or Part B outpatient PT is used. The HBPC PT performs annual assessment at minimum and supports with additional visits for equipment assessment and trial, follow up training, HEP instruction, follow up assessment after hospitalization, maintenance intervention.  
So if the client is receiving HBPC, they may have Part B OR Part A PT services. 
VA is providing HHOT and HHST - for example in our catchment area, HHOT follows Part B documentation/billing and HHST follows Part A/skilled HH billing. 
All VA's are not the same due to location, availability of services etc.

It would be important to clarify if the veteran is referring to Home Based Primary Care (a VA service for homebound veterans that includes a NP, RN, SW, Dietician, Pharmacist, Psychologist, and rehab therapist: PT/OT). That is just primary care but in the home and veterans can still use Medicare Part B while enrolled in HBPC assuming they have Medicare Part B. Otherwise, home health is home health whether they are a veteran or not, and you would not be paid through Part B

full_thread_text:
POST: If someone is using the VA for the home health, can we see them for Medicare part B?

COMMENT 1: Are they admitted to VA Home Based Primary Care Program?  The team included PT.  Seems to be some confusion about receiving HBPC PT at the same time skilled home heath PT or Part B outpatient PT is used. The HBPC PT performs annual assessment at minimum and supports with additional visits for equipment assessment and trial, follow up training, HEP instruction, follow up assessment after hospitalization, maintenance intervention.  
So if the client is receiving HBPC, they may have Part B OR Part A PT services. 
VA is providing HHOT and HHST - for example in our catchment area, HHOT follows Part B documentation/billing and HHST follows Part A/skilled HH billing. 
All VA's are not the same due to location, availability of services etc.

COMMENT 2: It would be important to clarify if the veteran is referring to Home Based Primary Care (a VA service for homebound veterans that includes a NP, RN, SW, Dietician, Pharmacist, Psychologist, and rehab therapist: PT/OT). That is just primary care but in the home and veterans can still use Medicare Part B while enrolled in HBPC assuming they have Medicare Part B. Otherwise, home health is home health whether they are a veteran or not, and you would not be paid through Part B

I have a current referral that lists the patient as having Medicare as primary insurance, BCBS PPO as secondary. When I went to verify, it says Medicare part A and B active coverage. But it also says her BCBS is a Medicare advantage‚Ä¶. 
So does she just have Medicare advantage?

comments.text:
Yes, this patient just has Medicare advantage. The MAC portal will always say Medicare part a and Medicare part B eligible or active, but that doesn‚Äôt mean they actually have those plans. 

Since it‚Äôs a PPO, you can assume there would be out of network coverage, so you would want to charge the patient the Medicare part be allowed amount and if the patient wants you to submit claims you can do it as a convenience, but you would be limited to what the plan allows. ÔøºÔøº

post_text:
Hi! 

I wanted to request clarification regarding our recent Medicare claim denials.

1. We submitted all claims through Office Ally after completing EDI enrollment for Medicare Part B. However, we recently received a Medicare Remittance Advice indicating that none of the claims could be processed and were denied with the following codes:
 ‚Ä¢ CO-16
 ‚Ä¢ MA112
 ‚Ä¢ MA130

After reviewing the claims in Office Ally, I noticed that the rendering provider NPI was mistakenly populated with our group NPI instead of the individual therapist‚Äôs NPI. Before we resubmit the claims, I just wanted to confirm whether this was the cause of the denial.

2. For patients treated by a PTA, the PTA‚Äôs name appears as the rendering provider, but the supervising PT‚Äôs NPI is the one that shows on the claim.

My questions are:
- Should the rendering provider name be the supervising PT and not the PTA, even when modifier CQ is used?

- If we change the rendering provider name to the PT, will Medicare deny the claim because modifier CQ was used (since the PT did not personally provide the treatment)?

- If the rendering provider must be the PT, what is the correct way to update the rendering provider name and NPI when our EMR (JaneApp) automatically lists the PTA as the rendering provider, even when the note is co-signed by the PT?

3. Since JaneApp + Office Ally autofill the rendering provider based on the clinician who wrote the note, we do not have the ability to manually replace the rendering provider name before EDI submission.

What would be the correct solution for this?

Submit corrected claims manually through NGSConnex so we can manually update the rendering provider name and NPI?

or

Is there a way to continue submitting through Office Ally while overriding the rendering provider field so it always reflects the PT‚Äôs name/NPI for Medicare billing?

Also, would there be any conflict having both EDI enrollment with Office Ally AND manual claim submissions via NGSConnex?

Any clarification or guidance you can provide would be greatly appreciated before we resubmit the claims.

Thank you!

post_text: I‚Äôm new to Arizona, and I know PTs here just recently got approved to order imaging. I want to order a MRI for a client (Medicare) who I‚Äôve been treating for hip pain. Anyone know how to do this? I called Medicare and they said it just needs to be ‚Äúmedically necessary‚Äù and they will cover it.

comments.text:
Your practice act may say that you can order imaging, but please read Medicare guidelines and don't go based off what a representative is telling you because they are frequently wrong. For instance, PTs can fit for pessaries; however,  Medicare doesn't reimburse if done by a PT. I'm not sure of this answer,  but would hate for the person to get stuck with this bill and be under the impression that Medicare will cover it.

And your original post says family member. Please remember that you can't bill Medicare if the person is family and Medicare also explains this in their guidelines. Also,  review your state practice act to find out if they allow this as well. 

(PS- even though you updated your post,  the original post is still available to be seen. Just in case you are wondering)

Here in Colorado, I‚Äôm a provider registered with Colorado Springs Imaging and can directly place orders through the online portal. Colorado Springs Imaging schedules the patient and handles the insurance billing. Sometimes the imaging center requests my notes faxed stating medically necessary.

post_text: Does anyone balance bill for Medicare Advantage patients if you are out of network?  Or do you take the MA payment as paid in full?

comments.text: You are limited to Medicare rates if they have OON benefits

Like Heidi said, you can only balance bill if the plan does not have out of network coverage and you appropriately notified the patient of the cost of care. Ôøº

And in the situations, everybody should be charging their full bill rate for offering a prompt pay discount, both of which would typically be higher than the Medicare allowed amount.

full_thread_text:
POST: Does anyone balance bill for Medicare Advantage patients if you are out of network?  Or do you take the MA payment as paid in full?

COMMENT 1: You are limited to Medicare rates if they have OON benefits

COMMENT 2: Like Heidi said, you can only balance bill if the plan does not have out of network coverage and you appropriately notified the patient of the cost of care. Ôøº

And in the situations, everybody should be charging their full bill rate for offering a prompt pay discount, both of which would typically be higher than the Medicare allowed amount.

post_text: I am a solo practitioner practice currently utilizing a cash-pay model. The goal is to grow to multiple therapists and have multiple revenue streams with a 24/7 gym space and other holistic wellness offerings in the future. I do not want to go away from a largely based cash model because the liberty to actually practice our craft with fewer limitations has been amazing, but have recently felt a pull to contracting with Medicare and Medicaid to serve patients who may not be able to afford our services otherwise. I‚Äôm having a hard time leaving out whole populations of people who still need help. My question is, how tricky does it get when people have secondary coverage in addition to their Medicare or have Medicare replacement plans, as I would not be contracting with secondary or Medicare replacement insurance plans?

comments.text:
Secondary coverage (medigap plansO) are automatic and we don't individually credential with those to be paid. 

With being OON with MedAdvantage plans keep in mind that if the plan has OON benefits, and you submit a claim, you are limited to charging Medicare allowables. To truly keep things cash pay you cannot ever submit those claims, just continue with the route of cash pay + superbills. 

Also keep in mind that if you ever credential in the future, that standard commercial (such as RegenceBCBS) and MedAdv commercial (such as MedAdv RegenceBCBS) are typically credentialed together as they're administered by the same company.

Just communicate up front that you are not taking Medicare Advantage plans. They are ridiculous and I got screwed over several times, finally learned my lesson and started having the hard conversations. But, nearly 50% of those over 65 apparently have opted for those plans, so they would have to shift back to traditional Medicare then to access your services.

full_thread_text:
POST: I am a solo practitioner practice currently utilizing a cash-pay model. The goal is to grow to multiple therapists and have multiple revenue streams with a 24/7 gym space and other holistic wellness offerings in the future. I do not want to go away from a largely based cash model because the liberty to actually practice our craft with fewer limitations has been amazing, but have recently felt a pull to contracting with Medicare and Medicaid to serve patients who may not be able to afford our services otherwise. I‚Äôm having a hard time leaving out whole populations of people who still need help. My question is, how tricky does it get when people have secondary coverage in addition to their Medicare or have Medicare replacement plans, as I would not be contracting with secondary or Medicare replacement insurance plans?

COMMENT 1: Secondary coverage (medigap plansO) are automatic and we don't individually credential with those to be paid. 

With being OON with MedAdvantage plans keep in mind that if the plan has OON benefits, and you submit a claim, you are limited to charging Medicare allowables. To truly keep things cash pay you cannot ever submit those claims, just continue with the route of cash pay + superbills. 

Also keep in mind that if you ever credential in the future, that standard commercial (such as RegenceBCBS) and MedAdv commercial (such as MedAdv RegenceBCBS) are typically credentialed together as they're administered by the same company.

COMMENT 2: Just communicate up front that you are not taking Medicare Advantage plans. They are ridiculous and I got screwed over several times, finally learned my lesson and started having the hard conversations. But, nearly 50% of those over 65 apparently have opted for those plans, so they would have to shift back to traditional Medicare then to access your services.

post_text:
Hello! I have a patient that switched to Medicare Primary last year. However for a variety of reasons she has kept her regular primary BCBS PPO plan. She ALSO has a separate BCBS supplemental plan just for your FYI. 

She is very complex and I have seen her off and on for the past two years. At the start of this year I saw her under Medicare. She was making slow steady progress but I was starting to get worried the progress would be not be significant enough to pass a Medicare audit. So I switched her over to her BCBS plan which I had billed the year before. 

I recently received a larger reversal of payment from BCBS. When I called they said I need to complete an EOMB (explanation of medicare benefits) and the patient needs to update her COB (coordination of benefits). The BCBS representative was very unhelpful in explaining what any of this means, how to submit, or what to include on the submission. 

Sooooo.... all of that being said, should I work on jumping through these hoops (and if so, any advice you have on how would be appreciated) OR should I submit these claims to Medicare, knowing with hindsight that she did continue to progress throughout the POC. 

Thank you for your thoughts and advice. Cross posting to try to get as much help as possible. 

Picture of a dog on a scooter in Paris for the algorithm.

comments.text:
Might get an answer in Learn Medicare Billing for PT, OT, SLP or Physical Therapy Billing 

I would start by looking up her Medicare benefits in your MAC portal to see how they have insurance listed.

Call your MAC and ask them what this means. I have found my MAC staff so much more helpful. Just an fyi patients don‚Äôt need to have progress to receive therapy she may qualify for a maintenance therapy program which is a covered Medicare service-not sure why you stopped billing Medicare?

post_text: Hey everyone! I am currently in-network with BCBS in Texas. I now have a 1099 employee. Does he/she need to go through the entire credentialing process to see BCBS patients? Or can I co-sign notes and/or be added as a supervising provider. Does anyone have any insight into this? I tried to research this already.

comments.text: Therapist must credential with BCBSTX. You can then add them to assign benefits to your business. There is no consigning of notes.
I still work for a rehab company, and have a prn PT that does evaluations. She sends her evals to be co-signed by our regional director and she is not credentialed. We are in Alabama

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey everyone! I am currently in-network with BCBS in Texas. I now have a 1099 employee. Does he/she need to go through the entire credentialing process to see BCBS patients? Or can I co-sign notes and/or be added as a supervising provider. Does anyone have any insight into this? I tried to research this already.

COMMENT 1: Therapist must credential with BCBSTX. You can then add them to assign benefits to your business. There is no consigning of notes.

COMMENT 2: I still work for a rehab company, and have a prn PT that does evaluations. She sends her evals to be co-signed by our regional director and she is not credentialed. We are in Alabama

post_text: This is an official Medicare government test you must take to sell Medicare advantage plans   Read that and tell me if it makes any sense üëÄ keep in mind. This is a 2026 test because open enrollment starts this week.

comments.text: Wow! That is interesting. Haven‚Äôt heard a thing about HH services being limited at 100 days/year. But if I‚Äôm being honest, this wouldn‚Äôt surprise me in the slightest. It‚Äôs limited in SNF. OP coverage is limited by many insurances. Why not HH?

Its the basis of how medicare works and advantage plans follow the guildelines they just "manage" it a lot more. Medicare A/"advantage" A allows for up to 100 days of consecutive services (typically paid at days 1-20 100%, then often 80% after. If all consecutive services are used the patient has 60 days were they must remain out of the hospital to reset med A benefits. Although i did have one patient that exhausted his lifetime medicare A benefits which is wild. Med B benefits never really go out. Where these "advantage plans" screw you though is they really like to dictate how much therapy theyre willing to give under both a & b and it has to often be pre-authorized and sometimes they even dictate what codes we use vs medicare who lets us do our thing and give the best services we can. New flash: theres absolutely no advantage to an advantage plan.

If all consecutive services are used the patient has 60 days were they must remain out of the hospital to reset med A benefits. Where these "advantage plans" screw you though is they really like to dictate how much therapy theyre willing to give under both a & b and it has to often be pre-authorized and sometimes they even dictate what codes we use vs medicare who lets us do our thing and give the best services we can. post_text:
I started my solo practice on the side in April, just cash-based, and finally made the leap to leave my full time gig.  I opted to start taking BCBS, as a number of my patients wanted to follow me and didn‚Äôt feel they could afford the self-pay rates. I felt good about keeping it simple with just one insurer, and decided to use MedLife to do my credentialing (they were great!) and billing.  The billing portion has proven difficult here at the beginning, to say the least. 
Main question: they are saying I need to sign up for claimMd as well. Isn‚Äôt that redundant?  
Also, where did you all learn about the whole process??  I knew I was spoiled not needing to do more than CPT and billing codes throughout my career, but I am resourceful and it‚Äôs seeming ridiculous I can‚Äôt get a clear explanation anywhere about the process. TIA!!

comments.text: You need a clearinghouse to send your claims to, who then sends them onto the insurers essentially. We use claimMD with Jane and do billing in house (also INN with BCBS). It‚Äôs not hard to do yourself once you get the hang of it. Jane has GREAT modules and is super helpful if you need to call and talk to someone.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt feel they could afford the self pay rates‚Äù‚Ä¶ is a limiting belief and an assumption. 

Every consumer is buying more and more goods these days from Amazon, Walmart, Costco, BJs etc etc. Most people are spenders and buy whatever they deem valuable.

Newsom cited that the bill's provisions would be more appropriately handled by the [California Office of Health Care Affordability (OHCA)](https://www.google.com/search?q=California+Office+of+Health+Care+Affordability+%28OHCA%29&oq=Newsom+Vetoes+CPTA+Prior+Auth+Bill&gs_lcrp=EgZjaHJvbWUyBggAEEUYOTIJCAEQIRgKGKABMgkIAhAhGAoYoAEyCQgDECEYChigATIJCAQQIRgKGKABMgcIBRAhGI8CMgcIBhAhGI8C0gEIOTM1ajBqMTWoAgiwAgHxBXoXYxf437oJ&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&mstk=AUtExfCXbmUfErPIsV7HkRNxXkEhgDAKYhWK2TY1cYEeMzGJeCOIPrMjpJVjXMEcBw5ayButbzNXgIgTf63lqWgxp2HNGzsI9F34TMBWpk46lnDV_Y3dWX3v0hDVD4kwgDtnTfyYWUinJH8nxCrqoKp8VtV7g2SDufTAZUSRqcGquvuxVYg&csui=3&ved=2ahUKEwicsLOuhpOQAxVkQjABHSbwHQ4QgK4QegQIARAF), which already oversees health care transaction consolidation and affordability.

Newsom cited that the bill's provisions would be more appropriately handled by the [California Office of Health Care Affordability (OHCA)](https://www.google.com/search?q=California+Office+of+Health+Care+Affordability+%28OHCA%29&oq=Newsom+Vetoes+CPTA+Prior+Auth+Bill&gs_lcrp=EgZjaHJvbWUyBggAEEUYOTIJCAEQIRgKGKABMgkIAhAhGAoYoAEyCQgDECEYChigATIJCAQQIRgKGKABMgcIBRAhGI8CMgcIBhAhGI8C0gEIOTM1ajBqMTWoAgiwAgHxBXoXYxf437oJ&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&mstk=AUtExfCXbmUfErPIsV7HkRNxXkEhgDAKYhWK2TY1cYEeMzGJeCOIPrMjpJVjXMEcBw5ayButbzNXgIgTf63lqWgxp2HNGzsI9F34TMBWpk46lnDV_Y3dWX3v0hDVD4kwgDtnTfyYWUinJH8nxCrqoKp8VtV7g2SDufTAZUSRqcGquvuxVYg&csui=3&ved=2ahUKEwicsLOuhpOQAxVkQjABHSbwHQ4QgK4QegQIARAF), which already oversees health care transaction consolidation and affordability.

post_text:
Hello everyone,
I‚Äôm a new practice owner and have a quick question. A patient recently contacted me after being involved in a car accident. Pt has a claim number from her auto insurance, which is already using for chiropractic care, and now she would like to start physical therapy with me. Pt  plans to submit the claims to her auto insurance.

For those of you with experience in these situations, how do you typically handle such cases? Any guidance or best practices would be greatly appreciated.

comments.text: Whoever submits first, gets paid first. If you end up seeing them on a lien, then you won't get paid until it is settled. That can take time....I've seen it take a few months to years for payment to be distributed. You'll want to have a contract with the attorney in place. fyi...some attorneys will come back at a later date and try to negotiate payment to a lower amount.

Call the auto insurance, speak to the person handling your patients case. Find out if the PIP policy (personal injury policy) is exhausted or if there‚Äôs still money in it. Typically it is $10,000 and they pay out claims as they come in. So what Heidi Grove Harmon said is correct. Submit your billing immediately. 
They will not tell you how much is left in the policy, so have your patient call and find out. Once that money is gone, if you choose to continue treating them, it will be on a lien with the lawyer so you will have to contact themÔøº

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello everyone,
I‚Äôm a new practice owner and have a quick question. A patient recently contacted me after being involved in a car accident. Pt has a claim number from her auto insurance, which is already using for chiropractic care, and now she would like to start physical therapy with me. Pt  plans to submit the claims to her auto insurance.

For those of you with experience in these situations, how do you typically handle such cases? Any guidance or best practices would be greatly appreciated.

COMMENT 1: Whoever submits first, gets paid first. If you end up seeing them on a lien, then you won't get paid until it is settled. That can take time....I've seen it take a few months to years for payment to be distributed. You'll want to have a contract with the attorney in place. fyi...some attorneys will come back at a later date and try to negotiate payment to a lower amount.

COMMENT 2: Call the auto insurance, speak to the person handling your patients case. Find out if the PIP policy (personal injury policy) is exhausted or if there‚Äôs still money in it. Typically it is $10,000 and they pay out claims as they come in. So what Heidi Grove Harmon said is correct. Submit your billing immediately. 
They will not tell you how much is left in the policy, so have your patient call and find out. Once that money is gone, if you choose to continue treating them, it will be on a lien with the lawyer so you will have to contact themÔøº

Hello, 
My cash based client insisting me to treat his wife who was rear ended by a car. 
Can someone assist me how to bill insurance . What all to consider ? Any pointers would be helpful. BTW , I am in Georgia 
Thanks

comments.text:
Have them pay cash and sort it out with their attorney and/or insurance is the easiest way for you.

If it goes through an attorney or insurance, then you'll have to wait until the claim is closed to get paid. That can take time. I've seen 3 months and I've seen years.

So much to unpack there. A few options. Then you need to decide which one is best for you.  

I‚Äôm at the gym. Dm me and remind me if I don‚Äôt come back in a few hours.

post_text:
Anyone here want to chime in on their experience with PIP insurance in their clinics? 

I have a chiropractor friend who swears it's some of the most reliable and lucrative clients she gets. But I had heard from another owner years ago that it was a bad idea.

I'd love some real-life feedback from people who either love it or who have been burned by it. Thanks!

comments.text:
If you are billing auto insurance PIP policy, it is a first come first serve sort of billing situation! Get your invoices in fast before the PIP is exhausted. Once it is exhausted, you will likely be waiting for payment through an attorney settlement and as Heidi said, this can take years sometimes. Ultimately they are lucrative, but you have to be able to have the cash flow to wait for a few years. We always have a handful of cases like these, but I certainly wouldn‚Äôt build my whole caseload around it. 

Always reach out and talk to the adjuster at the insurance company and the lawyer as well. Make sure they understand that you are treating and expecting payment based on settlement of the case ÔøºÔøº

It can be very good or very bad. Typically you will wait for a settlement for years. But, I always demand full pmnt (no adjustments) when we have to wait. In clinics we'd take them but only a few at a time.

comments.text: You can't provide re assurance that they will be reimbursed from their commercial carrier.    Can't charge Medicare patients cash (legally) for skilled services (less dedctibles) regardless of your relationship with them.

post_text:
Questions for folks who have a solo cash practice on the side and work in-network elsewhere. 

I recently had a patient submit for out-of-network reimbursement for my services using the superbill I provided (she paid cash for the visit), but she was told by her insurance that I am in-network and that they tried to reimburse me instead of her (though I have not seen any reimbursement to that effect). In my superbill I state clearly that balance has been paid in full by the patient, to NOT reimburse me, and that I am out of network with all insurances. I do, however, work at another facility that is in-network, that is also associated with my NPI. 

Is this a matter of the insurance company being dumb and not reading the superbill, or have I run into a problem where insurance won't reimburse this patient? Do I need to include something different in the superbill to make things easier for my patients?

Thanks in advance for any advice

comments.text: Do you have a Type 2 NPI for your cash practice? Billing through that might help with the confusion from the insurance company.

post_text:
We just got this from our company.  Has anyone been denied payment for an eval if within the 180 day time frame?

**Aetna** - we have discovered Aetna will only pay for an evaluation code every 180 days. While they'll still pay all other codes, if you evaluate someone, discharge and then want to pick them up for therapy again within that 180 days we will not be reimbursed for the evaluation code.

comments.text: Yep. When verifying benefits ask if there are limitations to eval code. A few more insurances are like that as well.

post_text:
Hi all, I am totally cash-based, but previously worked at clinics that billed insurance. I got a call from BCBS because they still had me as a PPO provider. They thought I needed to reimburse the patient and bill through BCBS. When I explained what I do, she told me I needed to ‚Äúde-par‚Äù with BCBS and gave me a number to call. 

Is this true? Anyone else done this? I‚Äôve not heard of it before. I opened a year and a half ago

comments.text:
Yeah... I had this happen to me. They had actually sent the payment for my patient to the other clinic. My patient told them she was pissed because this is a hipaa violation because now that clinic has her medical info. They were clearly concerned because she got her reimbursement check 3 days later (vs typical 45 days). Anyways, they sent me some form to fill out, and it's never happened since. 

Someone mentioned being linked to EIN, but despite having clearly different EINs, they said in the system it's still linked via NPI. Interestingly it happened out of the blue with 2 patients in a row but never an issue for the years prior.
Yes. Sometimes with bcbs if you are contracted through an old job you need to call and have that cancelled.

post_text:
If you‚Äôre in-network with Medicare, do you also have to be in-network with the secondary insurance (like UHC, Aetna, or Medicaid) in order to get reimbursed for the 20% coinsurance?

Also‚Äîhow does it work when the secondary is Medicaid?
Do they pay the 20% coinsurance if you‚Äôre not enrolled with them?

For those of you who are out-of-network with commercial plans:
Have you had any success negotiating with Data iSight (Cigna/Aetna‚Äôs repricing vendor)?
I‚Äôm increasingly getting underpaid‚Äîoften well below FAIR Health‚Äîand every time I try to dispute or appeal, it ends up in a loop between the payer and Data iSight, and eventually gets denied.

Would appreciate any tips, success stories, or appeal strategies. üôè

comments.text: No you just need to be in network with Medicare

Some states laws dont allow you to collect the 20% from Medicaid insurances. Check your state law.

Other insurances will be automatically sent the20% if Medicare has it on file. I get checks about 2-3 weeks after Medicare pays.

I have a patient with Aetna in our physical therapy clinic. He has insurance but a high deductible. So we charged him our self pay rate of $180. And when we billed his insurance they deducted $160 from his deductible. Patient called us and said that we owe him $160. 

How do we tell him that we did not get paid $160, that‚Äôs just the amount that his insurance plan took off his deductible. And we charge every single patient $180 if they have not reached their deductible.

Do I have to reimburse him the difference of $20?

comments.text:
Interesting no one knows the answer or able to provide easy clear source üôÑ 

All for a hard, laborious, mediocre pay job that's greatly needed. 

I call waste, fraud and abuse on the bureaucracy of the professsion. Doctorate required but yet no one can tell you how to bill for services üôÑ

Lots of incorrect info here. 

Sounds like his plan only had 160 of an allowed amount. Doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre limited to the allowed amount. 

Remember there‚Äôs technically no sure thing as in network and out of network. 

There‚Äôs contracted and non-contracted. There‚Äôs a difference.

post_text: I have a new OON practice. Right now about 3k in claim reimbursement / month. Billing service is quoting $450/month or 7% (for the first 6 months). States they are a boutique billing company and can also help with some light insurance verifications. Is this a good rate?

comments.text: I'd recommend, as an owner of a billing company, to look for a contract with a 30 day walk away policy. For example, my clients sign a contract, but can give me 30 days notice at any time. And 7% isn't high for your volume. It goes down the higher your volume gets. I specialize in small/growing businesses. This is because I love guiding the new provider. I do recommend doing it on your own for a bit, but if your time is better spent marketing, etc, get a biller. üòâ
If you have time, then I woyld recommend learning how to do it yourself.  If you get busier and need to delgate, then you will understand what you are hiring and overseeing.

post_text: I created a superbill for a patient recently. I went to her home to perform dance PT eval. I put the POS as 11 but insurance thought I was in network because of it. Should I have put 12 ‚ÄúHome‚Äù instead? I thought no because I wasn‚Äôt providing traditional home PT. I just provided concierge/mobile PT in her home. Thanks in advance!

comments.text:
That doesn‚Äôt make any sense. POS has nothing to do with being contracted or not. 

But to answer your question on POS it Really depends on payer and what they want. 

For the most part MedB is 12 for mobile and most commercial plans don‚Äôt recognize that and use 11 instead for OP services. They recognize 12 as home health instead.
If your NPI is/was linked to a previous in-network clinic that maybe what‚Äôs causing the issue. Insurance shenanigans. POS has nothing to do with it

post_text:
Hi y‚Äôall,
Wondering what codes people use if they‚Äôre billing for wheelchair evaluations? Do people use the 97755 code? I‚Äôve always billed it under 97530 thinking it‚Äôs kind of like patient education/equipment recommendation, but did some research and found this code.  Can both PTs and OTs bill this code or is it discipline specific?  

I‚Äôve gotten some referrals for wc evaluations but then found out later they were getting outpatient therapy somewhere else, and just needed me for the wc evaluation bc I‚Äôm mobile and can come to them.  I know that insurance doesn‚Äôt like to see the same codes or diagnostic codes being used for different companies and claims, so I‚Äôm just trying to see if using a more specific cot code may prevent me from getting denials. 

If anyone has any info or experience I‚Äôd love to hear it!  Thanks!

comments.text: No discipline owns any codes. If it‚Äôs in your scope of practice you can bill it. 97755 would be for more advanced power wheelchair switches, environmental or voice controls through the chair electronics, etc. 97542 is what I have always seen used in seating clinics for evaluation and follow up visits.

post_text: Good morning and happy Friday the 13th groupüò±üò≥. Someone might have posted this question before but I have a former patient that reached out to me that I was seeing through another company I contracted for via her insurance (Medicare). She recently reached out to me and stated that she has been having issues with another problem, that doesn‚Äôt require surgery but her physician want her to go to PT. She reached out to my business and wanted me to help her with a training program that could help her but she wants to pay cash. Medicare confuses me, is this a üëçüèø or üëéüèø, thanks

comments.text:
The simple guideline is you can't take cash from some one with Medicare for medically necessary services, other than the 20% co-insurance patient responsibility (assuming they don't have a secondary) or their deductible if it's unpaid. 

If you've done an evaluation and determined that services are not medically necessary/don't require the skills of a PT, then you can create and charge for a wellness program. 

PT's cannot opt out of Medicare like medical providers can.

Document the heck out of it and assess your own risk tolerance. 

According to a number of individuals, there are very specific methods to try to work around this for medically necessary services. If you're asking this question here, and have not set yourself up with good legal advice for those ways, you don't want to consider them.

full_thread_text:
POST: Good morning and happy Friday the 13th groupüò±üò≥. Someone might have posted this question before but I have a former patient that reached out to me that I was seeing through another company I contracted for via her insurance (Medicare). She recently reached out to me and stated that she has been having issues with another problem, that doesn‚Äôt require surgery but her physician want her to go to PT. She reached out to my business and wanted me to help her with a training program that could help her but she wants to pay cash. Medicare confuses me, is this a üëçüèø or üëéüèø, thanks

COMMENT 1: The simple guideline is you can't take cash from some one with Medicare for medically necessary services, other than the 20% co-insurance patient responsibility (assuming they don't have a secondary) or their deductible if it's unpaid. 

If you've done an evaluation and determined that services are not medically necessary/don't require the skills of a PT, then you can create and charge for a wellness program. 

PT's cannot opt out of Medicare like medical providers can.

Document the heck out of it and assess your own risk tolerance. 

According to a number of individuals, there are very specific methods to try to work around this for medically necessary services. If you're asking this question here, and have not set yourself up with good legal advice for those ways, you don't want to consider them.

post_text:
Would love some knowledge and expertise on this as I‚Äôve been scratching my head thinking about this the last few weeks!

I am new to the cash based physical therapy game as well as just simply billing insurances as I worked full time as a home health PT-all the billing, etc was handled by the company I worked for.

I am currently starting a cash based practice and I know we provide superbills for patients. I have written that we do not bill insurance directly but will provide superbills if needed to submit to insurance companies for possible reimbursements and to contact said insurance companies prior to starting with me for information on what‚Äôs covered. 

Should I offer cash based services and get in net work with some major insurance companies or just provide superbills? I‚Äôm confused because I feel if I accept some insurances it may make it a lighter financial burden. 

Can someone expalin the pros and cons of superbills vs getting in network with certain insurances  or even how to start that process. 

A little lost ü§ê

comments.text:
It depends on what you want to do..

Insurance based practices don't have a shortage of patients and people will go to see an insurance based provider regardless of their skills simply because they are in network...and I get it because premiums are expensive so people want to use their insurance. As a provider accepting insurance you do have to play by insurances rules (authorizations, documentation requests, reimbursement limits, co-pay and/or co-insurance collection, etc)

For cash based you can give a superbill and move on. It may take longer to build your clientele simply because some people want to use their insurance. You have the flexibility of setting your rate and determining the need for treatment without insurance influence.  You also don't have the same administrative requirements for billing submission, authorizations, etc. 

Insurance reimbursement is generally less than cash based; however, depending on your market and target audience it may make sense for your business model. 

I personally am non-par with Medicare and limit the number of Medicare patients ai have on my caseload at one time. Otherwise, I am completely cash based. I used to run a busy outpatient clinic that accepted most major insurances and some of those insurances were an absolute pain to work with. Others, weren't bad. Still, you have to run the numbers and see what works for your business model.

Also, I think it is important to understand that not allow services or physical therapy needs are truly covered by insurance and that in these situations, cash based is acceptable.

post_text: I'm getting tripped up on the rules for billing OON/cash for federal insurance plans. I understand that I can't bill Medicare / Medicaid as out of network / cash. I'm in Washington State, and I have a past patient that wants to see me with Molina insurance which I'm out of network for. In Washington, Molina services Medicaid plans, and Molina also has commercial plans on the Washington State Insurance Marketplace. I called Molina to check this patient's benefits and Molina confirmed that the plan was a commercial marketplace plan. There is no out of network benefit for the plan, and the customer service representatives were unsure if this particular Molina commercial plan counted as a federal plan and would therefore be illegal for me to bill cash. They did advise me that I needed to request prior authorization as a non-participating provider. Can anyone advise me on how to confirm whether Molina marketplace plans would follow the federal payer rules prohibiting OON/cash in my state, or who to call to sort this out since the Molina call center reps don't know?

comments.text: Ive noticed alot of customer service representatives for commercial insruances are not familiar with private pay clinics and so when they give advice they play it safe and just say ‚Äúa prior authorization is needed‚Äù its even more difficult when a patient reaches out to them because a huge number of patients still doesn‚Äôt know the difference between in and out network.
You can bill cash pay for Molina if it's commercial

Has anyone had success getting Cigna to pay out-of-network claims based on UCR (Usual and Customary Rates) instead of the deeply discounted rates from Data iSight?

I recently submitted claims as an out-of-network physical therapist, and the reimbursement was shockingly low ‚Äî as if I were in-network. After digging, I found that Cigna uses Data iSight to reprice OON claims, often ignoring Fair Health/UCR benchmarks.

post_text: I have a cash based pelvic floor PT clinic and I also take Medicare. A patient called me and said she had Medicare, so I scheduled her and then had her email me her Medicare card. This is what she sent me. Is this a Medicare advantage plan? Would she have to be a cash pay patient since this isn‚Äôt Medicare? Thank you. New to this.

comments.text: Yes, that is an advantage plan and you would have to be in-network with Aetna. It may have out of network benefits, but I doubt it.

Yes, this is a Medicare Advantage plan, as others above have stated. Because it is a PPO, she has out of network benefits and you can bill her insurance without your practice being in-network or having a contract with Aetna. These PPOs often have a large deductible or out of pocket max that the patient has to meet prior to insurance ‚Äúkicking in‚Äù for services. You are allowed to have these patients private pay since it‚Äôs not a traditional Medicare plan (sometimes they‚Äôre more willing to go this route if you can provide them with a superbill so they can submit it to insurance themselves). Hope that helps!

COMMENT 1: Yes, that is an advantage plan and you would have to be in-network with Aetna. It may have out of network benefits, but I doubt it.

COMMENT 2: Yes, this is a Medicare Advantage plan, as others above have stated. Because it is a PPO, she has out of network benefits and you can bill her insurance without your practice being in-network or having a contract with Aetna. These PPOs often have a large deductible or out of pocket max that the patient has to meet prior to insurance ‚Äúkicking in‚Äù for services. You are allowed to have these patients private pay since it‚Äôs not a traditional Medicare plan (sometimes they‚Äôre more willing to go this route if you can provide them with a superbill so they can submit it to insurance themselves). post_text:
Working on opening a PT/chiro business in a small town (6,000 people). I am starting as a cash based clinic and I‚Äôm finding different things when it comes to providing services for people on Medicare. I have found Medicare ABN forms and have also made my own for them to sign that they agree to not bill and submit to Medicare. Is the only way to see Medicare patients to accept Medicare or determine that they are a maintenance patient?
Any and all input is appreciated!

comments.text: I recommend contacting Gwen Simons. She‚Äôs a PT and attorney who specializes in helping practitioners charge Medicare beneficiaries cash for service as well as providing you with the proper documentation for them to sign. It‚Äôs true that PTs can‚Äôt ‚Äúopt-out‚Äù but you can unenroll. From my understanding, unenrolled providers don‚Äôt need to use ABNs and, as far as legal precedent is concerned, don‚Äôt need to abide by the fee schedule that Medicare requires enrolled, non-participating providers to use. Don‚Äôt take my word as law though, Gwen can help you out. If you just google her name with the word lawyer, it should come up at the top! Really good price for everything you get in my opinion.
Don‚Äôt make and user your own ABN forms. These are promulgated forms distributed thru Medicare MACs.

How would this work? 
I have an opportunity to take over ownership and operational management of a small (60ish visits/week) PT private practice from a combined Chiropractic/PT business. I want to keep two of the insurance contracts (Tricare/VA) associated to the original NPI but will ultimately run the entire business with my business NPI, etc.

comments.text: It will be based off tax id#. You will have new? Or will that remain?

So I just recently bought my existing clinic from my previous bosses. I had to fill out a form to take over possession of the existing tax ID to maintain my credentialing. So I think an easy thing to do would be to set up a DBA and continue to use the old tax ID just for those insurances. Depending on where you are at least. For me, it was impossible to get back on with Tricare and BCBS otherwise. I‚Äôm in the Florida panhandle and neither are taking new providers. As far as the VA goes, if you‚Äôre already credentialed with Optum, then we were told all you have to do is let them know you want to be credentialed with the VA and they‚Äôll put you on.

post_text:
I have a question about the what's-so on commercial insurance billing, specifically AETNA. 

I had a new patient whose benefits I checked via Availity. When I checked, it said that the patient had not met their deductible. However, once they did, they would have a co-insurance % to pay. 

When I saw the patient for the I.E., I charged him the full price at the end of the appointment. 

Today, I received a check from AETNA with a explanation of benefits. When I called AETNA to inquire why I received a check when he had not met his deductible, they told me that he had in fact met his deductible and the processing was correct. 

I know with Medicare, you cannot charge the patient more than what they say that the patient is responsible for, but is that the same for commercial insurance? 
The total amount of the check plus what the co-insurance that the patient is responsible for is less than the total of the initial evaluation. At the minimum, I plan to refund the amount of the check, but I wasn't sure if I could still charge them the difference that AETNA did not include in patient responsibility. Does anyone know?

Also, has anyone else had this sort of experience in which Availity says that their deductible has been met, but then the company says otherwise?  

Thank you for your time

comments.text: Availity is inaccurate‚Ä¶..all the time. We check availity and still call for verbal confirmation. It‚Äôs time consuming but it‚Äôs really the only way we can somewhat protect ourselves when we receive wrong information. If things are still processing availity will not be updated. And per commercial insurance, you are not allowed to charge more than the allowable or your contracted fee.

post_text: Patients who has commercial insurance and attends outpatient PT wants home visits from me (mobile PT) as well. I am only contracted with Medicare. Patient aware that my visits would be out of pocket. Is it worthwhile to even provide a superbill for patient to submit, knowing that it‚Äôll be denied? I could alternatively justify as wellness based on what I‚Äôm working on with him on the superbill but not sure it would matter?

comments.text:
Honestly, if the patient knows it will be out-of-pocket and likely denied, I‚Äôd still give them the superbill, just with clear expectations. Some patients get lucky with partial reimbursement or at least use it for FSA or HSA purposes.

If you‚Äôre worried about the medical necessity side, you could code it as wellness or maintenance, especially if that‚Äôs really what you‚Äôre working on. Just avoid giving the impression it‚Äôs skilled PT covered by their plan, or you might be setting them and yourself up for frustration.

Bottom line: it probably won‚Äôt get reimbursed, but if they want the paper trail and you‚Äôre transparent, it doesn‚Äôt hurt.

If it's on top of what they're already getting, then you're already going beyond what has been determined to be medically necessary (by the other evaluating PT).

Doesn't hurt to offer this person the option of a Superbill. ü§∑

They might get something for it.

post_text:
Hello we are hoping to go out of network for UHC. 
Can someone share the process. 
Also will going out of network affect our medica status ( which is managed by UHC)

comments.text:
First, be upfront with your patients about what the new costs will be. It‚Äôs super helpful to guide them on how to submit out-of-network claims for reimbursement.

It‚Äôs also a good time to rethink your rates, make sure they reflect your expertise but stay in line with what the market can handle. And make sure your documentation is on point. Insurers may ask for more detail for reimbursement, so thorough notes are key.

As you transition, your patient base might shift a bit, so think about how you‚Äôre communicating your value to justify the pricing. And about Medicaid ‚Äî it usually won‚Äôt be impacted, but it‚Äôs always good to double-check just to be safe.

Hope that helps!

post_text:
Would anyone be able to please guide me on how to submit a Medicare Advantage Aetna claim?   I am Medicare provider only.  

Aetna had me download a form called medicare provider complaint and appeal request.  I don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôm supposed to be putting the dates of service the codes I used and the amount billed.  The woman on the phone insisted that that was the right form and just told me to write it on a piece of paper and send it along with that form.  

Does this sound correct?

Thank you

comments.text:
Is the patient willing to pay you cash? If Aetna Advantage has OON, you can bill patient directly at Medicare allowance rate for the treatment then give the pt a superbill (cms 1500 form is the easiest) to submit to their insurance. Just don't check off the box to accept assignments

If you want to take on the plans and bill directly,  Availity is good to bill insurances. It took me a while to get set up on Availity though.

I personally don't accept assignment and do not bill the commercial advantage plans. I give the superbill to the patient and they submit. 

Each insurance company can have a slightly different process. You can do through a clearing house or use the CMS1500 form often times. Sometimes they'll make you ask for authorization as well if you bill directly.

Probably a better question for the Physical Therapy Billing group.

post_text:
At what time of the phone call do you ask patient what insurance they have or if they have insurance?

I have 2 insurances I used to take and can‚Äôt get them to get me out of network no matter how much I try (call, email, mail, fax‚Ä¶) they just won‚Äôt  acknowledge receipt to start counting time. I am very careful not to accept patients from these insurances, and to refer them to other providers. One of these insurances has very few providers in network, and I will often get calls from their representative asking if I am taking new patients and trying to schedule their patients. Also they don‚Äôt identify themselves: hey this is Ana with XYZ insurance. Usually when I ask: who I am talking to, they just say: Ana. 

Anyway, someone calls and say: hey I want to schedule a session, when is your next opening?
When is the appropriate time to ask: do you have insurance?

comments.text:
It‚Äôs one of the first things I‚Äôd ask.

‚ÄúSure have you ever been here before?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, okay no problem which insurance carrier do you? 

Answer the question fast don‚Äôt waster your or their time. 

Also send a certified letter stating you want to be dropped from the network. Key thing here is certified mail. If that doesn‚Äôt work report them to the state regulator.
Similar to others above I ask right off, but I usually start with are you using insurance or cash, and then follow up with the which insurance question.

Anyway, someone calls and say: hey I want to schedule a session, when is your next opening?

COMMENT 1: It‚Äôs one of the first things I‚Äôd ask.

Answer the question fast don‚Äôt waster your or their time. 

Also send a certified letter stating you want to be dropped from the network. Key thing here is certified mail. If that doesn‚Äôt work report them to the state regulator.

post_text:
Okay help me brainstorm‚Ä¶. What keeps a PT clinic from billing for skilled PT, and also charging for a gym membership and fitness training to address fitness goals that aren‚Äôt skilled?  It seems like as long as the patient is 100% informed about what is PT and what‚Äôs covered by their insurance, and what services are NOT PT and what the costs are, that we should be allowed to do this?  I‚Äôm just thinking about all the non-covered, ‚Äúnice‚Äù perks that we provide under the banner of providing ‚Äúhigh quality care‚Äù, which could more appropriately be charged for cash on an ala-cart menu of options.  

I imagine the cleanest legal way to do this would be separate business/LLC‚Äôs, separate spaces, separate billing systems, and of course some crystal-clear communication to the patient.  Anyone doing things like this?  

My reason for asking is actually that I am a professor teaching global fitness exercise to students, and they probably shouldn‚Äôt prescribe push ups and overhead press for plantar fasciitis patients, but I want to encourage them to maximize their value and skills even beyond the rehab goal. 

Of course this model also makes a strong case for cash-based services that simply provide for ALL goals regardless of insurance coverage‚Ä¶. But I‚Äôve never done it!  Thoughts?

comments.text: I own a semi private training facility and PT clinic all under one roof, one LLC, one set of books. There is no issue. It‚Äôs a whole different service and insurance is not being billed for it.  They sign a membership contract for those services. This is also almost no different than someone being cut off by insurance and becoming a self pay patient,  minus the fact that you aren‚Äôt doing skilled evaluations or follow ups that would require documentation.

post_text: Hey y'all I saw a post earlier about a group of clinicians who got in trouble for fraud. I had a question regarding this. I've been working for a mobile home health agency for a couple months and we see all kinds of insurances. We have PT, PTA, OT, OTA on staff. For the PT and PTA my boss cosigns all of our notes and I believe he is the only one credentialed with insurance. He hasn't spoken to me getting credentialed. I work as a contract worker so it never crossed my mind that I may need to get credentialed later down the road. Is it illegal for him to cosign my notes for this long? He also wants us to see our pt's for 68 minutes so he can bill for 5 units. ( I'm in TX by the way )

comments.text:
It sounds like you're doing mobile outpatient not home health? 
It sounds like they want you to do 68 minutes to use the rule of eights to get to that five units.  If the patient truly needs the care, That's okay although I feel like done repeatedly it might raise a red flag. I contact with a company locally who is also a mobile outpatient provider and they encourage us to work with the patients for up to six units who have traditional Medicare.  I find that it's not warranted in most cases and most patients can't tolerate that length of treatment anyway. 

But every so often I get someone who's really involved and I can totally justify six units. 

If you're a PT I'm assuming you're doing supervisory visits for the PTA?

I own a clinic with 4 other PTs and an OT, and had to get them all reassigned/credentialed under the business. So they bill with their NPI but it is under the business. 
I don‚Äôt cosign their notes.

post_text:
Did you think the Hertel and Brown case was a fluke or a "one off"? Guess again!

Owner of Oahu Physical Therapy Clinic Sentenced to 9 Months in Federal Prison for Health Care Fraud.

Timothy Wells admitted that from July 2013 through early 2020, he submitted false claims for payment for physical therapy services to TRICARE and Medicare. Wells used individuals not trained in physical therapy, including massage therapists, athletic trainers, personal trainers, and an individual who had no professional licenses or certifications whatsoever, to provide physical therapy services to patients. Wells admitted that he knew these individuals were not authorized providers and that he could not legitimately bill TRICARE and Medicare for physical therapy services rendered by them, even under supervision. Nevertheless, Wells billed the programs as though the services had been provided by licensed practitioners.

comments.text: I just don‚Äôt understand all the hard work and effort it takes to become a therapist and people choose greed over integrity it‚Äôs just crazy üíÄ

If you commit blatant fraud, you deserve to get caught. Hopefully, that does not fall under their professional liability claims, or we all end up paying for the bad guys. To be fair, from what I read about Hertel and Brown, there was some pretty shady things going down on a personal level with the owners as well. When you use unlicensed people to perform physical therapy--we all know this is fraud. If you are looking to make $$$ in the profession, do us a favor and leave rather than mar the profession.

Wells used individuals not trained in physical therapy, including massage therapists, athletic trainers, personal trainers, and an individual who had no professional licenses or certifications whatsoever, to provide physical therapy services to patients. Wells admitted that he knew these individuals were not authorized providers and that he could not legitimately bill TRICARE and Medicare for physical therapy services rendered by them, even under supervision. Nevertheless, Wells billed the programs as though the services had been provided by licensed practitioners.

post_text:
So for all those that think PTs, PTAs, OTs, OTAs, and billers do not go to jail and that it must be okay because we got paid and everyone does it, you might want to google search Hertel and Brown case. 20 therapists, assistants, and billers indicted plus the company. 17 of the PTs, PTAs, and billers, including the 2 owners, have now pled guilty to a felony count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and health care fraud.

The 2 owners will receive a 6-year prison sentence in federal prison followed by 3 years of supervised release. Essentially, their careers are over. Other 15 have sentences scheduled in May, June, and July.

The other 3 have jury selection start tomorrow. 

This is why documentation, CPT coding, billing, etc., should be mandatory CEU requirements for all therapists and assistants.

comments.text: So, they did things that we all know are wrong? Right?

Scary!! Reading one of the articles is says they billed for services not provided and billed as if provided by a PT when a tech provided. I hope no one here is doing these things!! Great reminder to document what you do and charge for what you do

The 2 owners will receive a 6-year prison sentence in federal prison followed by 3 years of supervised release. Essentially, their careers are over. Other 15 have sentences scheduled in May, June, and July.

The other 3 have jury selection start tomorrow. 

This is why documentation, CPT coding, billing, etc., should be mandatory CEU requirements for all therapists and assistants.

post_text:
I work for a home/community neuro program that is not covered by Medicare. Today I learned that my patient is receiving home health PT. We are definitely treating her with skilled therapies, not ‚Äúwellness,‚Äù albeit focused on community reintegration (in her home and in various communtiy locations) but Medicare does not pay for our model. She is privately paying for our program. 
I‚Äôm wondering everyone‚Äôs thoughts on the situation. Minimally I think she may be ineligible for home health and should be using Medicare for outpatient therapies, but is there any issue on my end with treating her if Medicare doesn‚Äôt pay for my company‚Äôs model? Should I do/say anything or keep my head down and keep treating her?

comments.text: Just a guess that it‚Äôs Rehab Without Walls ü´£ cool idea but there are questionable ethics at play!

If it is skilled therapy that is medicallynecessary, then I would ask why medicare is not being billed. Even if Medicare doesn't cover your company's model, then the patient should be referred to a provider who is able to bill Medicare. Now if services are not medically necessary per Medicare's guidelines that's a different story. If homehealth is present that service is billed under part A and part B cannot be used at the same time. If additional services are desired by the patient outside of what home health is providing that can be a cash service even if it is skilled.

I'm not sure if this answers your question or not, but hopefully it helps some.

I‚Äôm wondering everyone‚Äôs thoughts on the situation. Minimally I think she may be ineligible for home health and should be using Medicare for outpatient therapies, but is there any issue on my end with treating her if Medicare doesn‚Äôt pay for my company‚Äôs model? Should I do/say anything or keep my head down and keep treating her?

COMMENT 1: Just a guess that it‚Äôs Rehab Without Walls ü´£ cool idea but there are questionable ethics at play!

COMMENT 2: If it is skilled therapy that is medicallynecessary, then I would ask why medicare is not being billed. Even if Medicare doesn't cover your company's model, then the patient should be referred to a provider who is able to bill Medicare. Now if services are not medically necessary per Medicare's guidelines that's a different story. If homehealth is present that service is billed under part A and part B cannot be used at the same time. If additional services are desired by the patient outside of what home health is providing that can be a cash service even if it is skilled.

I'm not sure if this answers your question or not, but hopefully it helps some.

post_text:
Warning: this is just a rant. Not necessary looking for advice. 

We have built a very strong, mobile practice, have two full-time therapists with full caseload and two per diem therapists with partial caseloads. I also have a Clinic where we see individuals one on one. We average between 70-90 visits per week. 

But at the end of the day, the bank account is always drained. We feel we are experts, dealing with insurance as we have been doing it for several years. But there‚Äôs always denials, hours on the phone with insurance companies, massively delayed reimbursements due to those denials. 

On top of that, we have deductible season that comes around, patients fail to notify of new insurances, not all secondary cover the Medicare B deductible (then we have our handful of patients that say ‚Äú oh wait I have a third insurance‚Äù) leaving us to figure out how the heck to bill that coinsurance to them. 

We have people with two insurances, whose benefits are not coordinated, with the secondary making it impossible for us to correctly bill them. 

ÔøºÔøº combine that with therapists wanting top dollar even though reimbursements continue to decline per unit‚Ä¶

With all of this being said, I truly thought building this big independent one-on-one practice was going to be a life changer financially, and all that has happened. Is that more money transfers through my hands, but is not building in any account. 

Has anyone just packed it up realizing they would save more by having a regular job with a savings plan? The steadiness of the same exact paycheck every two weeks? 

I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm there yet, and I don‚Äôt think I could actually go back to working for someone. But this thing really wears on us I feel.  

Rant over!

comments.text:
Thanks everyone! I want to be clear. It seemed like we did very well when it was just me! Then I scaled and all heck broke loose. Just so many expenses.

Glad to know im not the only one who has experienced this!

I hear you.  This is why I went cash. It‚Äôs the only way.  Even with cash, I still struggle looking at the bank account every month but I‚Äôm still building.  

We HAVE to cut out insurance because they are ruining our profession. If enough of us leave‚Ä¶ maybe one day they will end up paying for our services again ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

post_text: Hello, anyone here have experienced with Auto accident cases? How do we go about it? Patient called me last week and I told them I‚Äôm only cash. They asked me if I could wait for settlement, l said I don‚Äôt do that. What are you guys doing for auto accident cases?

comments.text: Thank you üòä all!!

You make money by attorney liens in one of two ways:

1) you treat the patient. You bill each cpt code according to your fee schedule. The treatment is over. You send your billl. You wait until case settles and get paid. Off that payment you usually agree to a reduction with the firm. Ranges anywhere from 30-40%

2) you treat the patient. A middle man lien company can come in and you sell your lien to that company. Instead of waiting they pay you let‚Äôs say 30-35% of your bill straight up and they handle the lien.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: Thank you üòä all!!

COMMENT 2: You make money by attorney liens in one of two ways:

1) you treat the patient. You bill each cpt code according to your fee schedule. The treatment is over. You send your billl. You wait until case settles and get paid. Off that payment you usually agree to a reduction with the firm. Ranges anywhere from 30-40%

2) you treat the patient. A middle man lien company can come in and you sell your lien to that company. Instead of waiting they pay you let‚Äôs say 30-35% of your bill straight up and they handle the lien.

Pre-Authorization BCBS HMO
Hi all, I had a case and it was my first time working with BCBS HMO (I‚Äôm in network with HMO). My claims denied due to lack of pre authorization. From what I know, it is ok to made up  pre authorization although the evaluation and treatments were already finished. However, I am getting conflict informations from BCBS and PCP‚Äôs office. BCBS required pre authorization filled out by PCP; whereas PCP said they never done that, it‚Äôs the PT clinic should request pre authorization from insurance company. So I‚Äôm stuck in the middle. I only have 90 days to ask for pre authorization retrospectively, yet I couldn‚Äôt move forward and I‚Äôm loosing the days now. Any suggestions? What‚Äôs the correct approach? Any insight will be much appreciated. Thank you.

comments.text: PCP should call BCBS that they are referring their patient to you. PCP will need your NPI. You can evaluate or treat patient once you have the referral or authorization code. May not be paid for your evaluation and treatment before the start of authorization.

We work with BCBS in WI and when pre-auth is required we need to request it as the treating therapist/facility. The information usually includes clinical information like an outcome measure, which the PCP wouldn‚Äôt be able to provide. I‚Äôve never heard of retro authorization, but if you are planning to continue to see the client you might be able to request authorization now for future visits.
