BCBS required pre authorization filled out by PCP; whereas PCP said they never done that, it‚Äôs the PT clinic should request pre authorization from insurance company. So I‚Äôm stuck in the middle. I only have 90 days to ask for pre authorization retrospectively, yet I couldn‚Äôt move forward and I‚Äôm loosing the days now. Any suggestions? What‚Äôs the correct approach? COMMENT 1: PCP should call BCBS that they are referring their patient to you. PCP will need your NPI. You can evaluate or treat patient once you have the referral or authorization code. May not be paid for your evaluation and treatment before the start of authorization.

COMMENT 2: We work with BCBS in WI and when pre-auth is required we need to request it as the treating therapist/facility. post_text:
I have a patient with Medicare who wants to be seen 5x a week. They are happy to pay for the additional sessions as wellness. I just have a few questions about this.
1. Can we do 2x per week through medicare and 3x per week as wellness?
2. What paperwork do we need to see them with wellness?
3. What is your recommendation for payment methods? I‚Äôm assuming credit card would be best, how do you set it up?
4. How does documentation work with all this?

Thank you in advance.

comments.text:
I treat a guy privately for cash with mobile PT who goes to outpatient PT 2x/week. 
My services would not be covered by Medicare so I see no issues with it.

I would say just document well on what you‚Äôre doing differently to separate these sessions and you‚Äôll have a sound argument if ever needed (highly unlikely)

You can't just call extra sessions "wellness" because they're not covered by insurance. If you're doing PT (and read your practice act about PT vs wellness) then document it like PT. Because it's not medically necessary per medicare, you have then sign an ABN and collect cash. Now if you're doing "wellness stuff" in compliance with your practice act those other 3 days, then yeah. Document wellness visits and collect cash. Still probably need an ABN.

COMMENT 1: I treat a guy privately for cash with mobile PT who goes to outpatient PT 2x/week. 
My services would not be covered by Medicare so I see no issues with it.

I would say just document well on what you‚Äôre doing differently to separate these sessions and you‚Äôll have a sound argument if ever needed (highly unlikely)

COMMENT 2: You can't just call extra sessions "wellness" because they're not covered by insurance. If you're doing PT (and read your practice act about PT vs wellness) then document it like PT. Because it's not medically necessary per medicare, you have then sign an ABN and collect cash. Now if you're doing "wellness stuff" in compliance with your practice act those other 3 days, then yeah. Today's ChatGPT hack:

I take a patient's initial subjective history as it comes. My sentences are choppy, out of order, and often have typos. The story is there, but I wouldn't want to be the one who has to read it. üòÇ

Today, as part of finishing my documentation, I asked ChatGPT to take my jumbled mess and restructure it in a narrative format to make more sense.

post_text: Does anyone have experience treating  someone with VA insurance (not Tricare). I have a patient requesting my services but we don‚Äôt have a contract with them. I‚Äôm not sure if we can see them and what the process would be.

comments.text: If you don't get VA authorization to treat the patient, even if in network, you will not get paid. If there are VA providers nearby, then they will more than likely send the patient there. If not, the VA may be willing to pay without you being in a contract with them, butthis is rare and you'll still need authorization.
VA can be pretty specific to location. We‚Äôve had them deny before but then we‚Äôve also had them approve due to being a closer location.

post_text: I started a small private Pilates rehab practice out of my home. Im private pay but when asked, will provide a superbill to a patient/client if they want to submit it to their insurance company. I started to see a number of older patients (over 65) for Pilates but also incorporated some balance work, falls prevention and PWRmoves (Im certified in that for Parkinson‚Äôs). Im still cash-based but after reading some of the posts online, Im wondering if I can still be a cashed-based business if they are on Medicare. As a PT, If Im providing prevention/wellness services can I bypass Medicare altogether? Im not even a Medicare provider, but thinking I ought to be (not sure of what that entails but thats a separate question ). I would appreciate some guidance on this. Im certain the topic has been covered however there are definitely gray areas so wanted to get some clarification and direction. I‚Äôve just been charging an hourly rate or do bundled packages.

comments.text: I really appreciate the insight. I feel like I can make a clearer distinction for wellness when Im seeing my healthy general geriatric pop. I feel like I run into a problem when I see patients who actually have a diagnosis, for example, my Parkinson‚Äôs clientele. Can I stilll provide PWR/dual task, therapeutic exercises (some Pilates based/some not) all out of pocket? I have a handful of people now who want to come specifically for all of these things. Can I still deem it wellness? They all understand Im private pay and are happy to see me regardless. Going forward however, like you suggested, I should be clearer on my intake form and billing. Im currently giving a bill for services the way I would a PT patient. I give them a bill on my letterhead, diagnosis code and treatment codes. I think Ive just done it that way out of habit, not realizing that my 65+ clientele really should have just a wellness bill without codes etc. because I dont want them trying to submit it to Medicare.

For anyone wondering about how to handle Medicare... I highly suggest taking Anthony Maritato Zero to Paid course. Worth the money. I have a much better idea of what is considered a Medicare covered service and can say that I have successfully incorporated Medicare into my mostly cash based practice.

As a PT, If Im providing prevention/wellness services can I bypass Medicare altogether? Im not even a Medicare provider, but thinking I ought to be (not sure of what that entails but thats a separate question ). I would appreciate some guidance on this. Im certain the topic has been covered however there are definitely gray areas so wanted to get some clarification and direction. I‚Äôve just been charging an hourly rate or do bundled packages.

COMMENT 1: I really appreciate the insight. I feel like I can make a clearer distinction for wellness when Im seeing my healthy general geriatric pop. I feel like I run into a problem when I see patients who actually have a diagnosis, for example, my Parkinson‚Äôs clientele. Can I stilll provide PWR/dual task, therapeutic exercises (some Pilates based/some not) all out of pocket? I have a handful of people now who want to come specifically for all of these things. Can I still deem it wellness? They all understand Im private pay and are happy to see me regardless. Going forward however, like you suggested, I should be clearer on my intake form and billing. I think Ive just done it that way out of habit, not realizing that my 65+ clientele really should have just a wellness bill without codes etc. because I dont want them trying to submit it to Medicare.

Assuming the superbill listed insurance rates? Not the PP rate of $75? I've seen many profit on their own Healthcare and no, that shouldn't happen. It all depends on what you list your CPT prices at.

full_thread_text:
POST: Let's say I charge a patient $75 an hour and provide a super bill for them to submit to their insurance. The insurance goes off of 4 units per visit and determines the units were $100 worth of therapy. The patient has co-insurance of 20% and the insurance pays back the patient 80% of the bill, being $80 a visit. Is that how it would work? It doesn't seem right

COMMENT 1: The insurance can say since you accepted $75 then the 80% is off of $75. Discussed in length at PPS.

COMMENT 2: Assuming the superbill listed insurance rates? Not the PP rate of $75? I've seen many profit on their own Healthcare and no, that shouldn't happen. It all depends on what you list your CPT prices at.

post_text:
I find it saddening how vigorously some  will defend the limitations of our ability to serve people. I‚Äôm talking about the issues with serving people who may be Medicare recipients with coaching or wellness, teasing out the nuances of skilled or unskilled care. I don‚Äôt understand why some are so vigilant at chastising therapists who attempt to serve people based on their incredible training and skill set. Therapists who are trying to serve people that are begging for help. Therapists that are trying to stay passionate about a career they love and a system that has broken so many of us, and leaves many patients floundering for support that is reliable and professional. I know that many of the comments are designed to protect people and their license. However,Ôøº I don‚Äôt understand why we are not outraged that this, limitation even exists.  I don‚Äôt understand why professionals like us defend it instead of saying this is utterly ludicrous, and we must change it. Ôøº I have personally struggled to find care for a family member that needed specific rehab services and none were available for weeks and weeks. This was in a reasonably large metro area and I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not alone.  How is it even reasonable that we should not pay cash for someone that could support us in a timely fashion? Ôøº We can do better. We can make a change. We can serve more people that need us. 
Ôøº I‚Äôm not arguing the rules that are written. I‚Äôm arguing how absolutely ridiculous they are and that we should be more outraged that they exist than trying to defend them. Ôøº Rant over. Please recognize this came from struggling to find help for a loved one.  Seeing it from the patient side is heartbreaking. Ôøº

comments.text: The whole Medicare thing is ridiculous. You should be able to see whoever you want with your own money.

I‚Äôm pretty sure the limitation exists to protect Medicare beneficiaries from being bewildered and scammed.  

Having said that, I don‚Äôt agree with the limitations, but I think what you sense as some people vehemently defending the rule isn‚Äôt that at all.  It‚Äôs exasperation at the number of professionals in our field who have such an incredibly poor grasp of the current law before they jump into business.  

People jump on here every day asking questions about how they can treat Medicare patients for cash and then people respond every day citing the mandatory claims submissions regulation and skilled vs unskilled and it is exhausting to see the sheer number of people who don‚Äôt understand it - whether you agree or not. 

And I think that is mostly proof that most of us are caregivers relying on fb groups to teach us instead of doing the work of properly setting up our businesses. 

So I don‚Äôt think you are sensing that anyone is defending the rule.  We are however defending the need to know the rules if you are going to be in business.

post_text: Hi everyone! I have started my mobile practice ‚Äì cash pay and Medicare- but I am absolutely hating dealing with Medicare. Reimbursements are all over the place and I‚Äôm tired of being stressed trying to figure out why and getting signatures for POC‚Äôs has been a nightmare. Has anyone ever gone in with Medicare and then opted out in less than a year? This is a side hustle for me and with two other traditional positions right now I would rather just focus on the cash based side. Thanks for your help!

comments.text: If you are a PT, you cannot opt of Medicare. You can choose not to take it, but that means you cannot charge cash for skilled therapy services (that Medicare would cover) to Medicare beneficiaries. Reimbursement is not great across the board with any insurance, including Medicare. The rates are dropping again in January. I honestly find Medicare probably the easiest insurance to deal with compared to other insurance headaches I deal with.

Ôøº It might not be Medicare that‚Äôs the issue. It could be the combination of the EMR and billing company. What state are you located? What billing company are you using? How many clients are you seeing?

post_text:
Hi there,
Wondering if anyone has experience offering lymphedema therapies, such as wrapping, and whether you take insurance? I am wondering if it's worth taking a certification course in lymphedema treatment. Not many people offer it in my area, and I am wondering if that is because reimbursement rates are low and the therapy can be relatively labor-intensive? Anecdotally I have seen a considerable need in my community so I would like to provide this service, but since it would require a few thousand dollars of investment, would like to hear about others' experiences. Thanks!

comments.text: We do, hybrid practice

Hello there! I have a practice for lymphedema across the board. I also have a hybrid business model where I take a combination of medicare and cash pay patients. We also have ongoing maintenance care memberships which shape our wellness programs. I'm unsure what your community needs as far as an insurance based business model or cash based but we always need passionate and caring lymphedema therapists in every region. I think if you take insurance you really have to dive into what you are billing and how you're building it when it comes to lymphedema. Supplies are also an issue and you have to decide how you're going to get your patients supplies in a cost-effective way. And sometimes lymphedema is not very glamorous especially when it comes to wound care and lower extremities. However, you are 100% correct! The need is great and with the certification you'll have the skill to really provide relief and hope for a diagnosis that in most arenas appears to be hopeless.  Where are you located?

post_text: I know this topic has been covered before BUT I had someone approach me about seeing their mother for PT. Her mother is on medicare. She and her mother would prefer to see me over an in-network provider but I told her I am not comfortable seeing medicare patients because of legality questions. Now I'm questioning the grey area of can we, as cash-based PTs, see medicare patients for PT? I have avoided medicare patients entirely thus far but would like more information. Can anyone give me a more solid answer on the rules for treatment of medicare patients as an out-of-network provider? Does anyone have a good healthcare lawyer in Massachusetts that they can refer me to so that I can answer more of these types of questions myself?

comments.text: I don‚Äôt see why this is even an issue. You aren‚Äôt defrauding anyone, the patient is making their own choice to see you and  use their own money. What is best for the patient trumps anything else in my opinion.

This rule applies if it is a covered service by Medicare. Medicare only covers ‚Äúmedically necessary services‚Äù. If you can justify that you‚Äôre seeing her for something that is not exactly medically necessary you should be fine. 

I would also argue that no one really cares. Medicare isn‚Äôt going to come for you and say ‚Äúyou should have taken our money, not the patients.‚Äù But that‚Äôs just a risk you would have to be comfortable taking if you do think it‚Äôs a covered skilled service and can‚Äôt argue otherwise.

post_text:
I am hearing of multiple mobile PTs in my area that are having clients sign a waiver that basically states the clients are not going to bill Medicare for their services/are giving up their Medicare rights to get around the mandated Medicare rule for PT. They are having patients sign this and then charging cash. Thoughts on this? 
I thought this was sketchy but then found multiple people are doing it, so I was curious what the group thought.

comments.text:
Answer from chat GPT: No, a physical therapist cannot have a patient on Medicare sign a waiver to bypass Medicare and charge cash for covered services. Medicare has strict rules about billing, and providers must bill Medicare for services that are covered unless they have opted out of Medicare.

If a service is covered by Medicare, providers must submit a claim to Medicare, and patients cannot be asked to pay out-of-pocket for that service. There are some exceptions for non-covered services, but for covered services, bypassing Medicare is not allowed.

In rare cases, a physical therapist who has officially opted out of Medicare may have private agreements with patients, but this requires specific formalities.

I know multiple outpatient clinics (privately owned) in my area that make patients sign ABNs thus giving up their Medicare rights and also avoiding the clinic from being audited. They have some patients on caseload for 3+ years.

They probably will never be investigated by Medicare. Do I agree it‚Äôs wrong 100%. But people do what you are saying 100%.

full_thread_text:
POST: I am hearing of multiple mobile PTs in my area that are having clients sign a waiver that basically states the clients are not going to bill Medicare for their services/are giving up their Medicare rights to get around the mandated Medicare rule for PT. They are having patients sign this and then charging cash. Thoughts on this? 
I thought this was sketchy but then found multiple people are doing it, so I was curious what the group thought.

COMMENT 1: Answer from chat GPT: No, a physical therapist cannot have a patient on Medicare sign a waiver to bypass Medicare and charge cash for covered services. Medicare has strict rules about billing, and providers must bill Medicare for services that are covered unless they have opted out of Medicare.

If a service is covered by Medicare, providers must submit a claim to Medicare, and patients cannot be asked to pay out-of-pocket for that service. There are some exceptions for non-covered services, but for covered services, bypassing Medicare is not allowed.

In rare cases, a physical therapist who has officially opted out of Medicare may have private agreements with patients, but this requires specific formalities.

COMMENT 2: I know multiple outpatient clinics (privately owned) in my area that make patients sign ABNs thus giving up their Medicare rights and also avoiding the clinic from being audited. They have some patients on caseload for 3+ years.

They probably will never be investigated by Medicare. Do I agree it‚Äôs wrong 100%. But people do what you are saying 100%.

post_text:
For those of you approaching/are in retirement, what are your experiences with Medicare as a patient?  (I‚Äôm a pediatric therapist so not as familiar as some with Medicare). I work for myself and am wondering if Medicare is sufficient or will I need to keep my private (self-employed) insurance. 

Is it good coverage that meets your needs?
If not, what other insurance options have you found helpful?
(Please reserve political debates for your own post :-)

comments.text: Biggest problem I see as a HHPT is that people cannot afford caregivers or DME needed as they age. It‚Äôs very hard to get DME with Medicare and I believe only end of life insurance will cover caregivers. Maybe looking for a supplemental that has caregiver benefits. It‚Äôs such a strain on people

You need to buy supplemental insurance and drug coverage. Very good insurance. I am on traditional Medicare. Medicare replacements are less money but managed care. However I know many people happy with that coverage also. Recommend reading the Medicare and You booklet. You can get it through your social security office.

post_text:
Happy Friday :)
If anyone can help, I have a couple questions regarding a patient with Humana PPO as an out of network provider:
1. Cohere says no auth is required for the initial evaluation, am I only able to bill the 97161 eval code for this visit?
2. I checked availity and the patient still has a significant amount owed towards their OON deductible, will I not be paid by Humana until this deductible is met?
3. How do I determine if the patient has a copay?

comments.text: I check eligibility on availity. Most likely out of network deductible needs to be met before anything will be paid out, if there is a limit of visits you'll probably never get paid and all the visits will run out. You can offer for your patient to pay upfront and bill for them or they can submit it to insurance on their own

post_text: Is anyone using Webpt for billing? We‚Äôve been using them for EMR for over 12 years but use an outside billing company. Looking for reviews on how the service works and if you are happy with the billing aspect. TIA

comments.text: I switched to StrataPT - Physical Therapy EMR & Revenue Cycle Management. Billing is part of the EMR. They‚Äôve been excellent

We used them and they were very bad. They do not go after any kind of complicated billing issue issue and will end up writing it off. If you go on the webPT support group on Facebook you will see that they did this to a lot of clinics. Every month they are claims that do not make it over to the insurances so you have to watch them like a hawk because they will just write them off. At one point we had an outside agency audit their work, and that agency called them ‚Äúcriminal ‚Äú. Once you are done using their services they hand you a mess. I spent countless hours trying to get paid on some of it but somethings had to be written off because they let it go on timely or they messed it up so badly. I could go on and on about it, but it‚Äôs something that I think was our biggest mistake as a practice.

Hi everyone who works with worker's comp case, welcome your feedback: with worker's comp, which billing rule should I follow? AMA guideline so I can bill 8 min/unit (eg: 24 min for 3 unit) or should I use Medicare rule like 40 min for 3 units?

post_text: Has anyone switched from taking insurance to a cash based clinic? I‚Äôm really interested in doing cash based and switching back to home visits. Wondering if it‚Äôs doable or a terrible idea.

comments.text:
I'm used to run an insurance based clinic. I left and started my own mobile outpatient that is cash based. 

I'm not sure what area you're in, but in the Atlanta area I've had several people reach out asking specifically for a pediatric PT that would travel to their home.

It‚Äôs all about being able to have the appropriate conversations with patients. Often times I see clinicians struggle with being able to have the money conversations and overcome insurance objections. If you can do that well even if you cut your caseload in half if you‚Äôre charging enough it shouldn‚Äôt affect your income.

post_text: Billing question.  The only insurance I accept is medicare, and have had no issues with being paid by secondaries.  I just spoke to BCBSFL after getting 20 claim denials for secondary patient from the same patient.  They said they don't pay out of network benefits with this plan.  I was under the belief that if Medicare pays, then the secondary has to pay.  Does anyone have information on this?  I am not really set up to have time to call everyone's secondaries before they come in to see if they are in our out of network.  Thanks for any help.

comments.text:
Supplement is different than secondary

Some secondaries (PPO) will pay the remaining 20%. Other secondaries (HMO) will not. 

True secondaries are generally few and far between but you need to know what you‚Äôre looking for on the card. Those are the ones where you call or look up benefits so you get ahead of things like this.

If the secondary doesn't pay, patient gets a bill and a super bill and they can follow up.  Not my insurance, not my problem. Says right on my website I am out of network for everything but Medicare and I make no guarantees when asked.  They are welcome to call before scheduling but I'm out of network to avoid all that BS so not calling anyone or filling out anything.

post_text: Do not EVER sign a contract with OptimisPT for you EMR. They offer the most offensive customer service experience you will ever experience.  They will advertise "you wont receive a bill for the first two months!", but in reality that means the first bill you pay at month 3 is actually for month 1... so it's a scam set up to make you keep paying long after you told them you would be switching services to another EMR. To leave them has cost me $1200 and they are asking for another $600 for two more months of "usage" even though there hasn't been any.

post_text: Sorry if this is a stupid question, but I'd like some clarification as I'm still learning all of the ins and outs of billing insurance companies. My significant other was talking to his mental health counselor about my new physical therapy practice, and the counselor gave him some advice on insurance. We're based out of Iowa, and in Iowa, most people either have Wellmark BCBS of Iowa or Anthem BCBS, which is actually based out of New York (I believe). He said that he just runs my SO's insurance as Wellmark BCBS of Iowa, and Wellmark will bump it over to Anthem, and it still gets covered as in network. Can anyone verify this or tell me if this is correct? I have a long time patient of mine who has BCBS of NC but if I can just bill it to BCBS of Iowa and they'll send it to BCBS of NC and it will get covered, that sounds pretty enticing. Thanks!

comments.text:
Look on the back of the card and if it says ‚Äúbill with local Bcbs‚Äù then you should be good. 
I am in KC and we get a lot of different BCBS but we file with our local, unless it says otherwise. Be sure with anthem you are calling for auth

My understanding is that if you‚Äôre in network with your local BCBS you are in network with any BCBS. It just gets tricky verifying benefits and getting auth as different states use different 3rd parties for authorizations. We‚Äôre in WI and have billed BCBS from other states and been reimbursed.

post_text: Hey everyone! I have a lymphedema practice and am 100% cash-based.  I have a patient wanting to start with me but she is Medicare/Humana and I am not in with Medicare. I told her that she will need to go to a clinic that bills Medicare, but she is desperate because she has to pay $150 for medical transport. There are really not any mobile CLTs in my area but me. I just want to make sure there is no way around Medicare. I feel bad not helping her, but I don't want to mess with Medicare. Thanks!

comments.text: Contract with a home health company who is INN and treat her. She'll either have to pay $150 for transport to a clinic where they take insurance or pay you out of pocket so maybe it's a wash?

I think you technically could have her sign an ABN saying she refuses to have her information sent to Medicare and you would have to comply.  I think if you don't do this often it would work, but not 100%, maybe something you can look into further.

post_text:
Looking to start my own mobile hybrid insurance/cash-based practice. I have so much to learn so I love reading all the discussions. Been a PT for 12 years now and currently doing PRN and part-time work at different insurance-based clinics. My biggest questions right now are: 
If I already have my individual NPI number, do I need another NPI (NPI 2)? 
Do I need to do another CAQH?

comments.text:
Hey Kevin! Hope you‚Äôve been well. You‚Äôd need an NPI 2 for your business entity. For example, with Medicare you would do an initial enrollment with your type 2 NPI and you‚Äôd reassign benefits to the company for your type 1 NPI (assuming you have been credentialed with Medicare under your type 1 while working for other companies). 

As for the CAQH, you‚Äôd likely need a similar process. Create a CAQH for your practice and then affiliate your personal CAQH with your practice profile

COMMENT 1: Hey Kevin! Hope you‚Äôve been well. You‚Äôd need an NPI 2 for your business entity. For example, with Medicare you would do an initial enrollment with your type 2 NPI and you‚Äôd reassign benefits to the company for your type 1 NPI (assuming you have been credentialed with Medicare under your type 1 while working for other companies). 

As for the CAQH, you‚Äôd likely need a similar process. Create a CAQH for your practice and then affiliate your personal CAQH with your practice profile

post_text:
Hey everybody.  This is gonna be a long one.

I‚Äôm trying to stay positive here but I‚Äôm just really frustrated.  I run a Medicare/hybrid mobile clinic and I am just having the hardest freaking time with all of the Medicare replacement plans outside of UHC and Humana.  Every Aetna, Anthem and Molina referral I get I just dread trying to figure anything out for them.

I finally got on availity, but it‚Äôs hit or miss if I can even use it to look up the patients.  Half the time I get error messages for the information I put in, saying numbers are correct when I know they are.  The other half of the time I submit for preauths and they can‚Äôt cancelled for no reason that I can find.  And don‚Äôt even get me started on trying to call into the companies.  The information I got for all three of these agencies was that I have to get ‚Äúin network‚Äù in order to bill them, but the directions they all gave me to get in network were wrong.  

Anthem said I have to said a fax in to this designated fax number, the fax came back saying that it was undeliverable. 

Molina said I have to fill out the Medicaid form, but I don‚Äôt have a Medicaid number, nor most of the things that form was asking me for. 

And Aetna said I have to apply and then had a mile long list of things I had to do in order to apply.

And the kicker is I don‚Äôt even know if I truly have to be in network in order to bill these insurances, but when availity has been unrealizable in helping me look this stuff up. 

I know some of you will tell me that I need to stop taking insurance, and I would love to build up my cash paying clientele, but while I‚Äôm breaking into that market, this is what I‚Äôm getting referrals for. 

I guess I‚Äôm just looking for some guidance.  Does anyone have a tip for navigating this stuff better?  A person to call for guidance, a place to go for info?  Any info would be appreciated

comments.text:
BCBS Anthem is horrible 
You have to send W9 for each and every claims for OON 
They are not enrolling any therapist for in network for state of GA!
Give them super bill and you get your cash!
There's podcasts called uncaged clinician.. they're free but you can also hire them for consulting for mobile services. Good luck

post_text:
Hello!
Does anyone have any insight on how to bill insurance when services were rendered by a PTA? 

I use PT Everywhere EMR and when the PTA sends it over for signature and I sign it does not have the PTAs name (has my name instead) on the CMS1500 form. To me this makes it appear that I performed the treatment rather than the PTA.

If anyone has been billing for PTAs service and can help I would so greatly appreciate it!

comments.text: It does get billed under the supervising therapist. You add modifier CQ when services were performed by a PTA. Their name does not go on the claim.

post_text: For those of you that are OON/cash and take Medicare part B. Are you still charging your normal rate, having them sign an ABN and then submitting the claim on their behalf, but still collecting your full rate at time of service? I'm just wondering if it is worth starting to take Medicare, but their reimbursement is typically garbage, so I'm just wondering what people out there are doing. Thank you!

comments.text: Legally you can't do that. You agree to accept what Medicare pays a full payment for Medicare covered services.

If your schedule is full, and you can get it full with cash pay patients, of course that‚Äôs going to be more financially feasible. For me, Medicare patients pay well enough to make it worth being in network with them. You cannot have them sign an ABN as a blanket Coverage at the beginning of every treatment. You only have them sign an ABN when they are doing a treatment that you don‚Äôt expect to be covered like after the KX modifier. (I believe)
I like having a mixture of Medicare and cash pay.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those of you that are OON/cash and take Medicare part B. Are you still charging your normal rate, having them sign an ABN and then submitting the claim on their behalf, but still collecting your full rate at time of service? I'm just wondering if it is worth starting to take Medicare, but their reimbursement is typically garbage, so I'm just wondering what people out there are doing. Thank you!

COMMENT 1: Legally you can't do that. You agree to accept what Medicare pays a full payment for Medicare covered services.

COMMENT 2: If your schedule is full, and you can get it full with cash pay patients, of course that‚Äôs going to be more financially feasible. For me, Medicare patients pay well enough to make it worth being in network with them. You cannot have them sign an ABN as a blanket Coverage at the beginning of every treatment. You only have them sign an ABN when they are doing a treatment that you don‚Äôt expect to be covered like after the KX modifier. (I believe)
I like having a mixture of Medicare and cash pay.

All guidance/opinions welcome and would be greatly appreciated! 

I‚Äôm a mobile physical therapist that owns my own mobile clinic and I‚Äôm the only employee‚Ä¶therefore, I am doing all the billing through my EMR system, scheduling patients, administrative work and of course, treating patients.
I started my clinic one month ago and already have a full schedule working 8-5 Monday through Thursday.

I am only in network with Medicare right now and do cash based for all other patients but provide them with a superbill upon their request.

I am trying to decide whether to become in network with Blue Cross Blue Shield or stay OON. 
How difficult are they to work with? (I‚Äôm in Kansas) 
Do you typically see better reimbursement from them than Medicare?
Almost all of my cash patients (about 3-4 patients) pays the full amount upfront‚Ä¶ would I be chasing Payment down from patients or do you typically see that patients do a good job of paying their remaining balance whether insurance pays very much or not? 
Would I have to pay attention to an amount that I would need to write off if BCBS does not pay the fullamount or do my patients pay the difference between the billed amount and what Blue Cross Blue Shield pays?

Thank you for any insight and your opinions on whether I should become in-network or stay OON with BCBS. I am very new to this and don‚Äôt want to get in over my head as I don‚Äôt want to feel like I can‚Äôt keep up with the billing side as well as treating patients. 

P.S. thank you to everyone for all your posts which helped encourage me to step out on my own‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm absolutely loving it and it is the best thing for our growing family now and in the future üòÉÔøº

post_text:
For cash based PT: what, if any, codes are you adding to your invoice/superbill? 

Are you guys using CPT codes or just a flat rate regardless of what you do?

comments.text:
Mine have both ICD 10 and CPT codes with GP modifiers, otherwise insurance will deny them without a second glance (at least the standard ones BCBS, UHC, Cigna, Aetna etc) 

I split my cash charge by 4 for an hour appt and apply 1/4 charge per CPT code. They all get billed out the same per unit, but that‚Äôs the easiest way for me to do it so that there‚Äôs the most chance of insurance doing something with it for my patients.

Cpt codes on superbill to provide to client for potential reimbursement with insurance.

Also including ICD-10 on superbills.

My invoices only indicate that patient was made and serve as a receipt. Some patients require both for insurance reimbursement

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: Mine have both ICD 10 and CPT codes with GP modifiers, otherwise insurance will deny them without a second glance (at least the standard ones BCBS, UHC, Cigna, Aetna etc) 

I split my cash charge by 4 for an hour appt and apply 1/4 charge per CPT code. They all get billed out the same per unit, but that‚Äôs the easiest way for me to do it so that there‚Äôs the most chance of insurance doing something with it for my patients.

COMMENT 2: Cpt codes on superbill to provide to client for potential reimbursement with insurance.

Also including ICD-10 on superbills.

My invoices only indicate that patient was made and serve as a receipt. Some patients require both for insurance reimbursement

Client agreed to copay and I treated for 4 sessions. I just got the EOB in the mail and the member responsibility for Eval was $25 (not $70) and then member responsibility for 2/3 treatment visits was $0 (haven‚Äôt received the last tx eob)

Since the client no longer needs therapy I‚Äôm obviously going to reimburse. I have one more EOB im waiting to get back - I‚Äôm wondering if I should wait in case that shows $25? 

Also Is the EOB final or is it possible UHC will come back requesting the initial $70 they had said or $25 for the tx visits they charged $0??

comments.text: This is why you let the patient deal with submission for out of network benefits, in my opinion. You end up calling out of the good of your heart, spending your time, and then given the wrong information. Then, you get next to nothing back. It‚Äôs unfair to you as the provider.

post_text:
I have prospective pt who is ex military, and she says she got approved for therapy. I don't take insurance, but she says this isn't insurance it's just a code that's submitted to the VA for reimbursement, and then "they pay for it".

Does anyone have experience getting paid through the VA? Do you have to be on an approved list of providers?

comments.text: In Arizona, the VA sends us an authorization, typically for 15 visits. We cannot treat VA patients and have it covered by the VA without it. We are part of the VA community care network. Depending on the state you are in,  it may vary though.

I do out of network Tricare, call Humana Tricare in your area. It‚Äôs super easy as you just send in your license and ask for ‚Äúout of network‚Äù Tricare number.  Put that number on your reciept and you can at least have them get reimbursed for out of network tricare (in network is a pain) and frankly they are getting about 65%+ reimbursement so hassle is less for both of you and  tge patient and considering what I do that is not reimbursed with laser etc I‚Äôm actually a better deal than in network (except post op since it takes so long)
Good luck.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have prospective pt who is ex military, and she says she got approved for therapy. I don't take insurance, but she says this isn't insurance it's just a code that's submitted to the VA for reimbursement, and then "they pay for it".

Does anyone have experience getting paid through the VA? Do you have to be on an approved list of providers?

COMMENT 1: In Arizona, the VA sends us an authorization, typically for 15 visits. We cannot treat VA patients and have it covered by the VA without it. We are part of the VA community care network. Depending on the state you are in,  it may vary though.

COMMENT 2: I do out of network Tricare, call Humana Tricare in your area. It‚Äôs super easy as you just send in your license and ask for ‚Äúout of network‚Äù Tricare number.  Put that number on your reciept and you can at least have them get reimbursed for out of network tricare (in network is a pain) and frankly they are getting about 65%+ reimbursement so hassle is less for both of you and  tge patient and considering what I do that is not reimbursed with laser etc I‚Äôm actually a better deal than in network (except post op since it takes so long)
Good luck.

comments.text: I have a fully mobile neuro practice in Austin TX. We've expanded to 3 part-time PTs plus myself full-time, and 1 part-time OT . We do about 75/25 split Medicare and cash . Some of the Medicare patients stay on and pay cash for wellness. The more we've grown the more cash patients we've actually done. Taking Medicare and Medicare Advantage has definitely been worth it. post_text:
Thoughts as I'm answering questions to get a liability insurance quote?
1. "Do you accept patients only with a written plan of treatment from an attending physician? If not, please explain."

I'm thinking I'll explain that the physician doesn't write the plan of treatment... I have only worked in schools for the last several years and don't remember the process. I'm in Utah which AOTA lists as not requiring a referral for OT, though our state practice act doesn't explicitly make a statement about this. If I'm understanding correctly, Medicaid requires a physician prescription for OT in Utah, but I plan to start cash-based. Before scheduling an appointment, I require a dr to sign that there are no contraindications or precautions for incorporating horses as part of occupational therapy. Is there reason to send the doctor the eval, plan, or anything else?

2. Are you approved to receive Medicare or Medicaid payments?

I haven‚Äôt sought this yet under my own business. I have planned on starting out as only receiving cash/health savings accounts/FSAs and may decide to become in-network with medical insurance later.

comments.text: HPSO never asked those questions....

post_text: Had a client submit a superbill for out of network coverage through Cigna. Was told Dx code M54.5 LBP ‚Äúis out of date or invalid‚Äù - any thoughts as to why? Thanks

comments.text:
The diagnosis code M54.5 for low back pain (LBP) is considered out of date or invalid because it was replaced by a more specific code in the ICD-10-CM (International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision, Clinical Modification) updates. As of October 1, 2021, the code M54.5 has been replaced with the following more specific codes:

- M54.50: Low back pain, unspecified
- M54.51: Vertebrogenic low back pain
- M54.59: Other low back pain

Cigna and other insurance companies require the use of the most current ICD-10-CM codes for claims processing. You will need to update the superbill with the appropriate new code for low back pain to ensure it is accepted. 

To determine the correct code:
- If the low back pain is unspecified, use **M54.50**.
- If the low back pain is vertebrogenic, use **M54.51**.
- For other specified types of low back pain, use **M54.59**.

In my previous employment (insurance based system) we were notified low back pain M54.50 usually wasn‚Äôt covered by insurances. Usually had to be more specific like radiculopathy (M54.16) or vertebrogenic (M54.51). But not sure how super billing reimbursement looks for it! Good luck with it!

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: The diagnosis code M54.5 for low back pain (LBP) is considered out of date or invalid because it was replaced by a more specific code in the ICD-10-CM (International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision, Clinical Modification) updates. As of October 1, 2021, the code M54.5 has been replaced with the following more specific codes:

- M54.50: Low back pain, unspecified
- M54.51: Vertebrogenic low back pain
- M54.59: Other low back pain

Cigna and other insurance companies require the use of the most current ICD-10-CM codes for claims processing. You will need to update the superbill with the appropriate new code for low back pain to ensure it is accepted. 

To determine the correct code:
- If the low back pain is unspecified, use **M54.50**.
- If the low back pain is vertebrogenic, use **M54.51**.
- For other specified types of low back pain, use **M54.59**.

COMMENT 2: In my previous employment (insurance based system) we were notified low back pain M54.50 usually wasn‚Äôt covered by insurances. Usually had to be more specific like radiculopathy (M54.16) or vertebrogenic (M54.51). But not sure how super billing reimbursement looks for it! Good luck with it!

post_text:
How much reimbursement reduction do you guys see from Medicare ?

Medicare cut Therx  from $28 per unit to $21. This Probably seeing result of MPPR (multiple procedural payment reduction). It would explain the considerable drop in those values if you are within the same region.

Basically reimbursement is result of an equation. The equation is liability (small in PT), providers work (labor), and practice expenses (cost of clinic, equipment, etc).

MPPR is the reduction of the practice expense for coded units following initial unit, the argument being if using the same clinic why pay for it again.

https://www.apta.org/your-practice/payment/medicare-payment/coding-billing/mppr#:~:text=The%20multiple%20procedure%2Opayment%20reduction,outpatient%20hospitals%2C%20and%20rehabilitation%20agencies.

comments.text: Where the APTA at?
Confused by the MPPR? So if you bill therex twice you won‚Äôt get the full amount because you are billing it twice?

post_text:
Need advice on what to say to lawyer. Talking to them next week. 

So originally the kawyer had reduced our amount to $2500 and $1500 for husband and wife. Which we emailed back saying we accepted those amounts.

Then the husband came to our office and asked for reduction in our fee.

I spoke with the husband and told him there‚Äôs nothing we could do and it would be fraud if we reduced our amount for him to get more money back.

Well a few days later the lawyers office send us a check for $500 for the husband and $900 for the wife‚Ä¶..

I emailed the lawyer and asked what happened to our original amount.

Here‚Äôs what they said: After speaking with my clients looking at the medical billing, you billed Medicare for all of Mr (husband) visits and some of Ms. (Wife‚Äôs) visits.  Under Medicare rules, providers are not allowed to balance bill patients.  The payment of $500 represents Mr. (Husbands) copays.  There should have been a separate check for Ms. (Wife‚Äôs) in the amount of $900 for the visits that were not willed to Medicare.‚Äù

I have no idea what to even say. I‚Äôm so pissed. We charged the wife our self pay rate because she was not on Medicare. So I don‚Äôt understand how the lawyers office can reimburse us Medicare rate‚Ä¶. 

And for the husband, they only covered his copay and NONE of the dry needling‚Ä¶.

Don't worry about blue cross just bill medicare and wait a month after medicare pays u for blue cross to pay

full_thread_text:
POST: I have my first patient and they have Medicare and BCBS secondary. How does payout work in this case? I will be verifying both insurances and not sure how any of this works. Thank you!

COMMENT 1: Don't need to verify supplemental.  Make sure patient has signed up with MC for direct rollover to his/her BC.  Thus way when claim paid by MC, it rolls directly to BC and is paid timely.

COMMENT 2: Don't worry about blue cross just bill medicare and wait a month after medicare pays u for blue cross to pay

post_text:
Hey all! I am about to start really trying to get my business off the ground. It‚Äôs a mobile cash/med B business and I established it a year ago and started with a mentoring group. Due to unforeseen family circumstances I took about 4 months away and was not seeing clients. Now that I‚Äôm back I‚Äôm re-evaluating things. While the mentoring group was immensely helpful in the beginning I feel like at this point I want to work with what I‚Äôve learned and just start seeing clients for a bit. I‚Äôm shopping around for EMR and phone options and trying to decide if I stay on a monthly mentorship program or if I try to trim expenses for the time being and just get a client base built up. 

Is anyone who is a solo practitioner who takes cash and Medicare willing to share their average costs for phone and EMR? Right now I‚Äôm with hellonote/high level but the costs are bundled with the mentoring so it‚Äôs difficult to tease them apart. I‚Äôve spoke with a ring central rep and looked at Jane for EMR. Just trying to iron out all the details and feel comfortable where money is going. Thanks!

comments.text:
What is your Medicare B to cash ratio?
- asking because if you are not seeing very many Medicare clients, maybe you just go cash for a while & document using Google Drive. 
- if you are set on an EMR and looking for a good balance between inexpensive and functional, look at PT everywhere. May not have the bells and whistles, but it‚Äôs a solid product and nearly built specifically for a cash or cash and Medicare practice.
- I do believe that a CRM (I‚Äôve come to believe go HighLevel specifically) is an invaluable tool for independent business owners. It may be worth your while to speak with the guys at Uncaged. While I won‚Äôt comment on price specifically I can testify to the fact that they believe you should own your own data. They also back up those words with action.
- I have been running my phone through HighLevel for the last six months with minimal problems (any issues were entirely my creating).
- Even if you paid me, I could not go back to hello note. Lots of unrealized promises and unnecessary complexity. ÔøºÔøº

I just started using stride a few months ago and pay for a cheap cellphone. I have a brick and mortar but see a mix of cash and insurances. There‚Äôs no monitoring but it‚Äôs much cheaper than what you‚Äôre paying!

post_text:
Are there any legality issues with me seeing a patient for cash-services and another PT seeing a patient for insurance services at the same time for the same issue? I am almost positive there is not, but wanted to clarify.
Example: PT called me stating they were worried that there were two POCs and there can only be one and don't want to put their license on the line if there are too many POCs.
Context: I see the neuro population and some of them want more therapy than just twice a week, so they bring me in to sub that therapy.

comments.text:
If you're both billing insurance then someone won't get paid. The patient is likely not going to get reimbursed for cash based services if they submit a superbill. 

No, there's no issue. Just misinformation from the other PT. Patients can choose to pay for additional services outside of what their insurance pays and classifies as medically necessary.

If they're providing the medically necessary PT services, you are likely providing services that wouldn't be covered by insurance. I know I've done this (provided supplementary services-private pay) with those on Home Health. I suspect the same would be true for OP but I don't have a reference for that.

COMMENT 1: If you're both billing insurance then someone won't get paid. The patient is likely not going to get reimbursed for cash based services if they submit a superbill.

post_text: Anyone know if there are rules or regulations against being able to offer cash physical therapy services for those who have Medicare or Medicaid in the state of Florida?

comments.text: If the service is not medically necessary you can offer an ABN for the patient to sign. If the service is medically necessary and MC would cover it then you need to bill MC. You can opt to be a Non-Participating Medicare practitioner but I would do more research on that.
You can only offer cash to a Medicare recipient if it is wellness or a non-covered service. Physical therapists cannot opt out of Medicare

full_thread_text:
POST: Anyone know if there are rules or regulations against being able to offer cash physical therapy services for those who have Medicare or Medicaid in the state of Florida?

COMMENT 1: If the service is not medically necessary you can offer an ABN for the patient to sign. If the service is medically necessary and MC would cover it then you need to bill MC. You can opt to be a Non-Participating Medicare practitioner but I would do more research on that.

COMMENT 2: You can only offer cash to a Medicare recipient if it is wellness or a non-covered service. Physical therapists cannot opt out of Medicare

post_text: Hello. Now that I am credentialed with Medicare, will I need to be credentialed with each separate Medicare advantage plan such as Aetna Medicare in order to fully be paid?Thank you.

comments.text:
Hi. Crucial clarification here: Is the Aetna plan a supplemental? (I think it'll say so on their insurance card.)

You only ever need to be in network with the primary payer -- the primary payer will automatically send the remainder of the (approved) bill to the supplemental. You'll get a check in the mail from the supplemental later; timing varies. 

If the Aetna plan is their primary plan, then it's a Medicare replacement. Don't bother going in network with those, generally speaking, unless you have really good reasons. If their plan has OON benefits for PT, they reimburse at the same rates as Medicare would have. 

Please feel free to set up a call with me if you need more guidance -- since we've chatted about some of these things already.

understabd Medicare (dis)Advantage plans are NOT MEDICARE.  They are commercial insurance.  So if you are going to hassle with them then yes you will have to credential with each one.  Unless they have OON BENEFITS and you want to hassle witg that!  Good luck.  Sorry for my negative bias regarding said Disadvantage plans.  ü§£

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: Hi. Crucial clarification here: Is the Aetna plan a supplemental? (I think it'll say so on their insurance card.)

You only ever need to be in network with the primary payer -- the primary payer will automatically send the remainder of the (approved) bill to the supplemental. You'll get a check in the mail from the supplemental later; timing varies. 

If the Aetna plan is their primary plan, then it's a Medicare replacement. Don't bother going in network with those, generally speaking, unless you have really good reasons. If their plan has OON benefits for PT, they reimburse at the same rates as Medicare would have. 

Please feel free to set up a call with me if you need more guidance -- since we've chatted about some of these things already.

COMMENT 2: understabd Medicare (dis)Advantage plans are NOT MEDICARE.  They are commercial insurance.  So if you are going to hassle with them then yes you will have to credential with each one.  Unless they have OON BENEFITS and you want to hassle witg that!  Good luck.  Sorry for my negative bias regarding said Disadvantage plans.  ü§£

post_text:
Hello everyone,

Any suggestions on EMR system for mobile PT? I am not sure if this help but will be doing a hybrid of insurance and cash pay.

comments.text: We are hybrid, been using HelloNote since 2018

I just finished doing  a bunch of research on this specificity between hello note and Jane. Ultimately I am choosing Hello note due to pricing, Medicare friendly and good services. Everyone raves about Jane‚Äôs customer service but the draw back is that their pricing for the middle plan which everyone should do if you are billing insurance has a separate clearing house fee and fee per claim. So with Jane it‚Äôs $99 plus $25 for the clearing house and then .30 cents per claim. Hello note is $95 which includes the billing of Medicare and their clearing house and no % is given up with billing insurance. Hello note also per reviews has Medicare reminders on PN and other Medicare friendly tools. So it depends on what you are gearing towards. Also hello note has fax option included in the $95 a month so you can fax out the Medicare notes to doctors.

Everyone raves about Jane‚Äôs customer service but the draw back is that their pricing for the middle plan which everyone should do if you are billing insurance has a separate clearing house fee and fee per claim. So with Jane it‚Äôs $99 plus $25 for the clearing house and then .30 cents per claim. Hello note is $95 which includes the billing of Medicare and their clearing house and no % is given up with billing insurance. Hello note also per reviews has Medicare reminders on PN and other Medicare friendly tools. So it depends on what you are gearing towards. Also hello note has fax option included in the $95 a month so you can fax out the Medicare notes to doctors.

post_text: I have a cash based mobile vestibular practice. My patient reached out to his insurance company asking about out of network benefits. He will be requesting a superbill and gave me the list of requirements needed on it. I have most of them on my bill but hadn‚Äôt heard of a ‚ÄúPlace of Service Code.‚Äù Can someone share what that is? I will be treating him at home tomorrow but may also meet him at his workplace if need be in the future. Thanks in advance!

comments.text: Place of Service codes are exactly as they sound, codes to signify where you are performing the treatment.  POS 12 is for home whereas your typical clinic POS is 11. I'm not sure if it would be different for their office,  but you may want to have them verify with their insurance that POS 12 will allow reimbursement.

post_text: I'm currently working in 2 roles: A clinic-based W2 job and my new, completely separate, mobile PT business. I had my first UHC client (mobile PT) and went through the pre-approval process to get visits authorized through Optum Physical Health. Well, it turns out that Optum's authorization for visits was based on one major incorrect assumption. Unfortunately, neither Optum nor myself confirmed the proper TIN was being authorized. Optum Physical Health based the authorization on the the W2 related TIN. In hind sight, it's my fault for not clarifying the proper TIN with Optum, but I'm new at this and don't know what I don't know. Well, it turns out that Optum Physical Health doesn't contract with mobile PTs. At this point, I fear that I'm just going to have to write off the claims (Medicare Advantage so no possibility for claw back). Does anybody have any advice on how to approach this situation? I certainly won't be accepting any UHC patients going forward. Thanks for any advice!

comments.text:
I have had several UHC Medicare patients that I needed to get approval for before treating. But they still paid me.  They didn‚Äôt say anything about not paying mobile PT but I didn‚Äôt use that terminology, I just said this was for outpatient therapy, because it is, and they would also say ‚Äúyou‚Äôre out of network‚Äù and I would confirm, but they still paid me because I got pre auth prior to the visits. 
Perhaps the person you spoke to just didn‚Äôt know what they were talking about? (Happens a lot) because I‚Äôve had several UHC patients and once I received the pre auth I always got paid.  
Granted getting the pre auth is sometimes a nightmare because I‚Äôd end up transferred several times but I always took down the reference numbers, and I always bill the first visit immediately and make sure I‚Äôm going to get paid before I schedule another one so I don‚Äôt run into an issue where I don‚Äôt get paid for any services

So your practice has no affiliation with Optum/UHC but you were through the pre-auth process?

Were you planning to bill OON?

I‚Äôm confused here.

post_text:
Hello! I'm opening my own cash-based practice and plan to also be a participating provider for Medicare only. I have two questions:
1. I have an NPI Type 2 for my business. Do I put my NPI #1 or #2 on a superbill for patients? I updated the information on NPPES for my NPI #1, and I updated my I&A account.
1. I have previously worked for employers that were in-network with various insurances. My most recent employer was OON. I have a CAQH profile that has expired, as CAQH told me that I did not need to reattest for my most recent employer since that employer didn't use CAQH. Do I need to update my profile now since I don't want insurances to view me as in-network? Or is that not necessary since my NPI #1 and #2 are no longer affiliated with previous employers?

comments.text: I would keep CAQH updated. Medicare will typically want it updated. It doesn't put you in network with anyone but a way for insurance to pull your info.
For Medicare you'll need to submit the claims directly

post_text:
Hi Gang,   

We no longer bill insurance for clients (we stopped almost 20 years ago). 

However, a client wants a statement with the codes itemized to submit for possible reimbursement.  

If billing for a 75-minute session, incorporating 4 modalities, do we need modifier -59? (97112 x 2, 97530, 97140 x 2)    

Or, what's the best way to show the breakdown so they have the best chance of receiving the highest OON reimbursement?  

Thanks, 
Irene Diamond

comments.text: I have never included any sort of modifier, simply the CPT codes and amount charged for each code. For reimbursement, the superbill may need certain info on it like time and place of service, NPI, EIN (tax number), license number. Hope this helps!
Is there a reference page for the codes with 59 modifiers?

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi Gang,   

We no longer bill insurance for clients (we stopped almost 20 years ago). 

However, a client wants a statement with the codes itemized to submit for possible reimbursement.  

If billing for a 75-minute session, incorporating 4 modalities, do we need modifier -59? (97112 x 2, 97530, 97140 x 2)    

Or, what's the best way to show the breakdown so they have the best chance of receiving the highest OON reimbursement?  

Thanks, 
Irene Diamond

COMMENT 1: I have never included any sort of modifier, simply the CPT codes and amount charged for each code. For reimbursement, the superbill may need certain info on it like time and place of service, NPI, EIN (tax number), license number. Hope this helps!

COMMENT 2: Is there a reference page for the codes with 59 modifiers?

post_text: Has anyone filed with their state insurance Director for violation of timely payment of claims against United healthcare?

comments.text:
Subject: Urgent Assistance Needed: Delayed Payments from UnitedHealth Group Subsidiary

Dear Director Ann Gillespie,

I am writing to bring to your attention a critical issue that is impacting numerous healthcare businesses in our state, including my own. As a small healthcare business owner, I have been severely affected by the recent cyberattack targeting Change Healthcare, a subsidiary of UnitedHealth Group.

The cyberattack, which occurred in February, resulted in the shutdown of the data clearinghouse that serves a significant portion of U.S. medical providers, patients, and pharmacies. As a consequence, payments from UnitedHealthcare, a key payer for many healthcare providers, including my business, have been delayed for over two months.

This delay in payments has created significant financial strain for my business, as well as countless others across the state. Despite repeated attempts to address the issue with UnitedHealthcare, we have not received any satisfactory resolution or timeline for when payments will be processed.

Furthermore, the impact of these delayed payments extends beyond just financial hardship. It has disrupted our ability to provide timely and quality care to our patients, as well as caused significant operational challenges.

I am reaching out to you, Director Gillespie, in the hope that you can provide assistance in addressing this urgent matter. Specifically, I am seeking your support in advocating for healthcare businesses like mine to receive the payments owed to us by UnitedHealthcare, along with any associated interest and fines for the delayed payments.

Given the widespread impact of this cyberattack on the healthcare industry, I believe it is imperative that state authorities take action to ensure that affected businesses receive the support and assistance they need to recover from this crisis.

I would appreciate the opportunity to discuss this matter further and explore potential solutions to mitigate the financial and operational challenges facing healthcare businesses in our state.

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter, and I look forward to your prompt response.

Sincerely,
K Joy Lind, PT 
President 
Enjoy Mobile Rehab

I'm in the process of applying to Medicare, and the application is saying that the bank where I have my business account (a local credit union) does not have a Medicare ID.  Specifically, the application says this:
"EFT dataset Space Coast Credit Union is not associated to any Medicare IDs. Please associate a Medicare ID to this EFT dataset in the Electronic Funds Transfer topic."
Do I need to open another account at a different bank just to accept payment from Medicare?

comments.text: This happened to me as well with Suncoast Credit Union.  I called the First Coast Service Options and they said it was ok just to have the voided check.  I would call them to verify

This is a warning only. Just go ahead and submit. You are good. This is standard as your business does not have a current Medicare ID. I do credentialing all the time for people and this is the standard procedure.

post_text: If someone is being seen under worker comp (Slip and fall resulting in a TBI/concussion), and the current therapist wants to refer to us for concussion rehab. Can we see them under Medicare vs work comp?

comments.text:
Tricky. Some wc cases will deny them and have the patient pay themselves if they use their own insurance too soon and see someone outside of their recommendations, some docs won't even see them if it's an open claim. If the claim is open, the therapist might have to talk to the claim manager to see if the new treatment can be added. Insurance might also deny you if it's an open wc case, and they were hurt at work. Not sure about Medicare specific, but nowadays some insurances are looking for a way out to deny claims. 

Saw a case where a pt was using their insurance to try to get back to full duty at work and the insurance denied all their visits and said it should have been auto being billed from an accident months prior, the pt was contacting their lawyer. Frustrating. Hope you get more answers you are looking for more specific to your case.

Call the WC adjustor and explain the situation, proceed accordingly.

They are typically very helpful.

And WC pays better than Medicare

full_thread_text:
POST: If someone is being seen under worker comp (Slip and fall resulting in a TBI/concussion), and the current therapist wants to refer to us for concussion rehab. Can we see them under Medicare vs work comp?

COMMENT 1: Tricky. Some wc cases will deny them and have the patient pay themselves if they use their own insurance too soon and see someone outside of their recommendations, some docs won't even see them if it's an open claim. If the claim is open, the therapist might have to talk to the claim manager to see if the new treatment can be added. Insurance might also deny you if it's an open wc case, and they were hurt at work. Not sure about Medicare specific, but nowadays some insurances are looking for a way out to deny claims. 

Saw a case where a pt was using their insurance to try to get back to full duty at work and the insurance denied all their visits and said it should have been auto being billed from an accident months prior, the pt was contacting their lawyer. Frustrating. Hope you get more answers you are looking for more specific to your case.

COMMENT 2: Call the WC adjustor and explain the situation, proceed accordingly.

They are typically very helpful.

And WC pays better than Medicare

post_text: I bill primarily Med B . I have someone wanting me to see their family member on a cash basis.  He is on hospice and does not have Medicare.  This will be my first cash client . Do I need to have signed orders? I am in a direct access state. What kind of paperwork should I have them sign?

comments.text: Must have the GFE

You don't need orders. I would have them sign a consent to treat, a form stating they received your HIPPA privacy notice, a communication preferences form (how you may contact them & ROI if relevant), and a payment agreement form explicitly stating your rates & when payment is expected.

full_thread_text:
POST: I bill primarily Med B . I have someone wanting me to see their family member on a cash basis.  He is on hospice and does not have Medicare.  This will be my first cash client . Do I need to have signed orders? I am in a direct access state. What kind of paperwork should I have them sign?

COMMENT 1: Must have the GFE

COMMENT 2: You don't need orders. I would have them sign a consent to treat, a form stating they received your HIPPA privacy notice, a communication preferences form (how you may contact them & ROI if relevant), and a payment agreement form explicitly stating your rates & when payment is expected.

comments.text: Next Thursday, the 25th, I‚Äôll be hosting another Community Q&A with JaneApp. Come learn about their product!

I used hellonote for about 3 years when I started. It‚Äôs a great platform but I felt like I needed more help with billing and revenue/KPI reporting as my company grew. I recently switched to StrataPT - Physical Therapy EMR & Revenue Cycle Management. They don‚Äôt charge you for the EMR or per user but they take a percentage of the billing. They do all the billing, follow up on denials and everything. I have a lot of contractors which made companies like prompt way too expensive for me‚Ä¶. With strata, I can add as many contractors as I want, and there is still no actual cost for the EMR, only the percentage for the billing.

post_text:
If you want to know what is wrong with healthcare in this country, look no further than this. Insurance companies and 3rd party administrators like ASH and Multiplan getting incentivized to deny claims or cut payments to obtain a percentage of the "savings" from the employer self funding the plan. Meanwhile the healthcare provider loses out on reimbursement or the patient is stuck holding the bag having to make up the difference. All while the insurance company and 3rd party laugh all the way to the bank. Complete sham of a process.

https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/07/us/health-insurance-medical-bills-takeaways.html

comments.text: We recently dropped Cigna/ASH at the clinic I work at because we had a contracted rate of $65/visit and out of nowhere they decided to only start paying us $32/visit. After arguing with them for over 6 mos my boss just said, ‚Äúfine. We‚Äôre no longer taking your pts.‚Äù Then they decided to come up to $50 but since that‚Äôs still shy of what we‚Äôre supposed to get, my boss laughed and still said no. A lot of disappointed pts, but they all seem to understand for the most part

I saw a lawyer today on social media who was informing clients and the public of tactics that certain insurance companies have of just flat out refusing to pay as long as possible, to the benefit of the insurance companies‚Äô bottom line. 

I‚Äôm about to make a post about this, and start sharing this sort of thing. I think providers should. What do you think?

post_text: Hey guys! I could use some help. I live in Maryland, and as a PTA, I just opened my own practice. While  waiting for credentialing to go through, my PT and I have been working as independent contractors through my friends business so we could get the ball rolling. I was denied by Medicare after applying myself, so I decided to pay someone to do the credentialing for me. I was told that i will not be able to credential with the insurances under my own company as it will need to be done through the supervising PT (there isn't anywhere on the Medicare application where we can put the supervising PT info). Can anyone shed more light on this situation and possibly provide references?! Thanks in advance!!

comments.text: I am a PTA that owns a clinic. Feel Betterpt is correct the PT has to reassign their NPI to your clinic which is the type 2 npi then you credential the PT with Medicare and that will credential the clinic

PTA do not get credentialed with Medicare and most other insurances.  You are practicing and billing under supervising PT NPI. As such there is nothing to do for you.  

You will have to get the contracts credentialed through that PT.

COMMENT 1: I am a PTA that owns a clinic. Feel Betterpt is correct the PT has to reassign their NPI to your clinic which is the type 2 npi then you credential the PT with Medicare and that will credential the clinic

COMMENT 2: PTA do not get credentialed with Medicare and most other insurances.  You are practicing and billing under supervising PT NPI. As such there is nothing to do for you.

post_text: I plan on working part time at a clinic that is an INN with Aetna and they currently have me enrolled as an INN provider. If so, how would I do that?

comments.text:
You should be able to work for or in  both
Working with someone- you are the treating provider but not the billing provider so they bill under their group NPI.
In your own practice- you are the billing and treating provider, billing under your practice NPI.

post_text: Will someone explain how oon works. I was not aware that we could bill insurances we are not credentialed with. How does this work and are we usually paid?

comments.text: OON typically has a separate deductible, different copay/coinsurance and so you most likely aren‚Äôt going to end up getting paid by the insurance unless their plan has met the deductible like normal. It works the same as in network and they will usually try to negotiate what they pay you/their client pays. They have to have out of network benefits stated in their plan though. A lot don‚Äôt.

I‚Äôm OON with most ins. I check on availity for their benefits. About 35% of the time it matters. Different deductible ‚Ä¶ copay etc.  some are so low they don‚Äôt care. Other plans there is no difference. PT doesn‚Äôt matter if it‚Äôs in or out. Same/ same. I‚Äôve never been screwed on an OON patient
