post_text:
Hi all! I was speaking to a local chiropractor (I am a physical therapist looking to launch my own business) she was telling me‚Ä¶

‚Äúshe believes as a licensed healthcare provider you will need to register with CMS/Medicare in order to treat any patients.  That you can register as a Non-par provider and should be allowed to accept cash from a Medicare patients. Charges must ‚Äúbe in alignment with customary & reasonable for your region‚Äù.  I guess this has something to do with discrimination practices.  But I guess that‚Äôs the Medicare handcuffs, because Medicare patients are allowed to request reimbursement from Medicare and/or deduct medical expenses from their taxes which they are required to receive legit services from licensed practitioners blah, blah.  So bottom line, whether or not you bill/charge/submit to Medicare or not, you have to register with them as a non-par provider.‚Äù 

From what I can tell for physical therapist, the only way I could see a Medicare patient for cash if it‚Äôs truly a ‚Äúwellness‚Äù session. But do I need to register as this ‚Äúnon-par provider‚Äù? I am in Illinois if that makes a difference!

comments.text:
Hi, Katherine Reinertson Wood thanks for asking this. I've been a Medicare provider (PT) for over 5 years, and this local chiropractor is a bit off base! Sounds like she is trying to explain to you what a Non-par provider is. Basically, you need to enroll with Medicare if you want to treat Medicare patients and submit claims. You can enroll as either participating or non-participating provider (confusing, right??!) Non-par does not mean you have no relationship with Medicare, you cannot accept cash (self-pay) from a Medicare patient as a Non-par provider. I would recommend checking out Tony Anthony Maritatos Facebook Group Medicare Billing for (Mostly) Cash Based PT, OT, SLP Providers Group. I've found it very helpful with navigating the Medicare maze üôÇ 
You are correct, you can see Medicare patients as self-pay/ "cash" for wellness visits, if skilled PT is not necessary. No need to register with Medicare, par or non-par, to do wellness visits. Hope that helps!

There are 3 categories:
- affiliated with Medicare, Participating
- affiliated with Medicare, non-Participating
- no affiliation

If you are not affiliated you cannot treat anything that would be reimbursable under Medicare for PT. Non-medically necessary items (such as wellness), can be cash billed.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi all! I was speaking to a local chiropractor (I am a physical therapist looking to launch my own business) she was telling me‚Ä¶

‚Äúshe believes as a licensed healthcare provider you will need to register with CMS/Medicare in order to treat any patients.  That you can register as a Non-par provider and should be allowed to accept cash from a Medicare patients. Charges must ‚Äúbe in alignment with customary & reasonable for your region‚Äù.  I guess this has something to do with discrimination practices.  But I guess that‚Äôs the Medicare handcuffs, because Medicare patients are allowed to request reimbursement from Medicare and/or deduct medical expenses from their taxes which they are required to receive legit services from licensed practitioners blah, blah.  So bottom line, whether or not you bill/charge/submit to Medicare or not, you have to register with them as a non-par provider.‚Äù 

From what I can tell for physical therapist, the only way I could see a Medicare patient for cash if it‚Äôs truly a ‚Äúwellness‚Äù session. But do I need to register as this ‚Äúnon-par provider‚Äù? I am in Illinois if that makes a difference!

COMMENT 1: Hi, Katherine Reinertson Wood thanks for asking this. I've been a Medicare provider (PT) for over 5 years, and this local chiropractor is a bit off base! Sounds like she is trying to explain to you what a Non-par provider is. Basically, you need to enroll with Medicare if you want to treat Medicare patients and submit claims. You can enroll as either participating or non-participating provider (confusing, right??!) Non-par does not mean you have no relationship with Medicare, you cannot accept cash (self-pay) from a Medicare patient as a Non-par provider. I would recommend checking out Tony Anthony Maritatos Facebook Group Medicare Billing for (Mostly) Cash Based PT, OT, SLP Providers Group. I've found it very helpful with navigating the Medicare maze üôÇ 
You are correct, you can see Medicare patients as self-pay/ "cash" for wellness visits, if skilled PT is not necessary. No need to register with Medicare, par or non-par, to do wellness visits. Hope that helps!

COMMENT 2: There are 3 categories:
- affiliated with Medicare, Participating
- affiliated with Medicare, non-Participating
- no affiliation

If you are not affiliated you cannot treat anything that would be reimbursable under Medicare for PT. Non-medically necessary items (such as wellness), can be cash billed.

post_text: How do you educate patients about the difference between Medicare and Medicare replacement plans?  I take medicare, and patients keep saying they have medicare, and I get them all signed up, and then find out it's replacement, add they don't understand why they would have to pay.  üò¨

comments.text:
They should have read the book they're given each year to explain how their health services are billed. üòë  If in person, ask to see their cards first. If not, have them email a copy. You need that to verify coverage anyway. Tell them up front you don't take Medicare Advantage plans. If they are not paying anything extra each month than their $174.90 that is usually subtracted from their Social Security payments, they probably have an Advantage plan. Although some Advantage plans have extra premiums as well. Sounds like their Insurance agent didn't educate them well. It's the job of the agent to make sure they understand their coverage. I would direct them back to their agent if you don't want to spend the time. 

Traditional Medicare is quite costly. I remember my mom paying up to $454 a month over her base premium (now $174.90). And she wasn't really ill until her last year alive. Only hospitalized for 2 TIAs and having 3 children. You are going to see more and more taking Advantage plans. They have a max out of pocket limit that lowers the financial risk. If you are not an ill person, Advantage plans make sense. Plus you get dental and vision benefits, and other perks. Otherwise you are paying close to $600 a month for Insurance you may or may not use

I ask for their cards before, check benefits. If they have Advantage I explain they chose to give up their Medicare benefits to an insurance company who now ‚Äúmanages‚Äù their health care like any other insurance company. I then refer them to another PT clinic that may take their insurance. The Advantage plans are absolutely awful and predatory and should be illegal the way they prey on our elders.

post_text:
Mobile PT in FL!  
I noticed different chiropractic offices in my area ‚ÄúNow Offering Physical Therapy‚Äù  

Announcing that the PTA will be working alongside the chiropractors.  

I always thought a PTA needed to be supervised by a licensed PT??  Am I missing something?  And, how can they do this if PT supervision is required?
  
Thanks!!

comments.text: Suggest asking your state association to look into this.  Not sure about Florida, but in Michigan "physical therapy" is a protected term:  Chiropractors can perform/bill the same CPTs as PTs, but they can not advertise it as physical therapy services.

Chiros can bill PT CPT codes - ther ex, ther act, neuro, manual without a PT or  PTA present.   One in my area bills PT visit and has an LMT do massage.  We found that out when patient ran out of PT visits on insurance when we were the only place she went for PT, but chiro billing PT session for massage.

post_text:
Hi Everyone!

I have a Medicare question. We have a 69 y.o who wants to submit his claim to his Medicare part C supplement which is through UHC. We are out of network with every insurance including Medicare. He seems to think he will get some good reimbursement from this. 

His appt was mainly for shockwave (which if I‚Äôm correct is a non-covered Medicare service) but some time was spent with exercise prescription. Any idea if this is ok to do? I don‚Äôt want to submit if it can open is up for an audit of any problems. I do have Jared‚Äôs Medicare book but that section says it‚Äôs a gray area so I‚Äôm a bit worried about taking the risk. 

Thanks in advance!

EDIT - ok update I‚Äôve attached the cards provided (took me this long to get them). I hope this helps.

comments.text: Part D is prescription

If he does have original Medicare + supplement you absolutely will not want to submit as:

1. Medicare offers no OON coverage nor will any supplemental plan since they just use medicares determination on whether they pay their 20% or not.
2. If you performed skilled PT, covered services to a Medicare beneficiary and charged cash it is technically not allowed. There is gray area. But if you go and submit a bill now you‚Äôre basically contradicting your determination of it being a non-covered service and opening yourself up to potential scrutiny (unlikely).

On the contrary if it is a Medicare advantage plan (part C) and you are OON and he has OON benefits let er rip. We get pretty good reimbursement this way daily.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi Everyone!

I have a Medicare question. We have a 69 y.o who wants to submit his claim to his Medicare part C supplement which is through UHC. We are out of network with every insurance including Medicare. He seems to think he will get some good reimbursement from this. 

His appt was mainly for shockwave (which if I‚Äôm correct is a non-covered Medicare service) but some time was spent with exercise prescription. Any idea if this is ok to do? I don‚Äôt want to submit if it can open is up for an audit of any problems. I do have Jared‚Äôs Medicare book but that section says it‚Äôs a gray area so I‚Äôm a bit worried about taking the risk. 

Thanks in advance!

EDIT - ok update I‚Äôve attached the cards provided (took me this long to get them). I hope this helps.

COMMENT 1: Part D is prescription

COMMENT 2: If he does have original Medicare + supplement you absolutely will not want to submit as:

1. Medicare offers no OON coverage nor will any supplemental plan since they just use medicares determination on whether they pay their 20% or not.
2. If you performed skilled PT, covered services to a Medicare beneficiary and charged cash it is technically not allowed. There is gray area. But if you go and submit a bill now you‚Äôre basically contradicting your determination of it being a non-covered service and opening yourself up to potential scrutiny (unlikely).

On the contrary if it is a Medicare advantage plan (part C) and you are OON and he has OON benefits let er rip. We get pretty good reimbursement this way daily.

post_text: Hi all! I have a client who wants to receive services through me (I‚Äôm private pay only); however, they have managed Medicare (BCBS as primary, Medicare secondary). I am not credentialed with Medicare in my private practice. Is this off limits? Or can I provide treatment? Thank you!

comments.text: So let's look at terms here. If they have managed Medicare e.g. a Medicare Part C Advantage plan they no longer have original Medicare at all. If a spouse or the beneficiary is still working they could potentially have BCBS primary and Medicare secondary. Medicare Advantage plans can offer OON benefits which do require that you bill them, generally that is if they are a PPO plan. HMO plans generally have no OON benefits and you can charge cash.
I was under the impression you could not charge cash for anyone who was Medicare eligible, even if they don't have Medicare?

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi all! I have a client who wants to receive services through me (I‚Äôm private pay only); however, they have managed Medicare (BCBS as primary, Medicare secondary). I am not credentialed with Medicare in my private practice. Is this off limits? Or can I provide treatment? Thank you!

COMMENT 1: So let's look at terms here. If they have managed Medicare e.g. a Medicare Part C Advantage plan they no longer have original Medicare at all. If a spouse or the beneficiary is still working they could potentially have BCBS primary and Medicare secondary. Medicare Advantage plans can offer OON benefits which do require that you bill them, generally that is if they are a PPO plan. HMO plans generally have no OON benefits and you can charge cash.

COMMENT 2: I was under the impression you could not charge cash for anyone who was Medicare eligible, even if they don't have Medicare?

post_text: Mobile therapist that take insurance‚Ä¶‚Ä¶what does that look like for reimbursement wise from bigger private insurance? Is it possible to see Medicare patients at home if they‚Äôre not home bound? Thank you.

comments.text: ABSOLUTELY you can see MC patients as "outpatient" in their homes.  I'd say 80%+ of the people who are in our coaching programs and are mobile take MC.  Many others do as well.

Private insurance is going to vary state to state. 

Medicare - definitely can see them at home. It‚Äôs still outpatient, just with a home location code instead of clinic location code. 

Rough numbers in Oregon for 1-on-1 hour treatment sessions and utilizing RTM, it took me about 68 visits in the month to hit the 10k/month reimbursement mark. I started taking insurance about 6 months ago myself.

Medicare - definitely can see them at home. It‚Äôs still outpatient, just with a home location code instead of clinic location code.

post_text:
Question on keeping track of money:
Hey, I started my biz in 2023 so as I am closing out last year's finances, I am trying to figure out how to do the bookkeeping. I am Mobile PT, Cash/Medicare only at this time. 

With Medicare payments:
1) If I put the claims for DOS from 2023 in Dec 2023, so receiving payments this month and 2nd insurance also paying me in 2024, how do I track the income? 
- do I say I got paid in the 2023 accounts or put the $ in the 2024 accounts (on my excel sheet)? 
Example: DOS for IE is 11/14/23, claim approved 12/5/23 - Medicare paid 12/5 their portion, but 2nd insurance check came in 1/9/24

2nd example: DOS for follow up visits in Nov/Dec, submitted claims in Dec, payment received in 2024 

I hope I am making sense, lol. I just want to keep track of my income/paid claims for yearly tracking therefore need to make a system that can be easy to carry forward.

comments.text: I‚Äôm not a tax professional and this isn‚Äôt advice but the cash accounting method is much simpler method than the accrual method. Basically the cash method of accounting is just ‚Äúmoney in, money out‚Äù so you don‚Äôt have to worry about matching accounts receivable like in the accrual method.

My understanding (not a tax professional) is that the year that you receive payment is the year it would be counted as income-no matter when the claims were submitted. So if part of the payment was received in 2023 it would be applied towards the 2023 tax year. Likewise if a portion was received 2024 it would go to 2024 tax year. Wouldn‚Äôt hurt to discuss with a CPA .

full_thread_text:
POST: Question on keeping track of money:
Hey, I started my biz in 2023 so as I am closing out last year's finances, I am trying to figure out how to do the bookkeeping. I am Mobile PT, Cash/Medicare only at this time. 

With Medicare payments:
1) If I put the claims for DOS from 2023 in Dec 2023, so receiving payments this month and 2nd insurance also paying me in 2024, how do I track the income? 
- do I say I got paid in the 2023 accounts or put the $ in the 2024 accounts (on my excel sheet)? 
Example: DOS for IE is 11/14/23, claim approved 12/5/23 - Medicare paid 12/5 their portion, but 2nd insurance check came in 1/9/24

2nd example: DOS for follow up visits in Nov/Dec, submitted claims in Dec, payment received in 2024 

I hope I am making sense, lol. I just want to keep track of my income/paid claims for yearly tracking therefore need to make a system that can be easy to carry forward.

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm not a tax professional and this isn‚Äôt advice but the cash accounting method is much simpler method than the accrual method. Basically the cash method of accounting is just ‚Äúmoney in, money out‚Äù so you don‚Äôt have to worry about matching accounts receivable like in the accrual method.

COMMENT 2: My understanding (not a tax professional) is that the year that you receive payment is the year it would be counted as income-no matter when the claims were submitted. So if part of the payment was received in 2023 it would be applied towards the 2023 tax year. Likewise if a portion was received 2024 it would go to 2024 tax year. Wouldn‚Äôt hurt to discuss with a CPA .

post_text:
Hello all.

Im doing homecare PT for Medicare part B patients in NY and I make 62.5$/hour plus all the benefits. 

Ive noticed that the company i work for gets reimbursed about 200-220$/(empire) visit which makes me want to open my own company and work on marketing myself if this is the reimbursement rate. Why shouldn‚Äôt i do this? 

Having to see less patients and having more time for myself would be great. Please let me know What are your input from those who have done the same:

Thanks in advance

comments.text: There is no way they make that for 4 unit treatments for Medicare. They may bill that. Steven Glukh is in NY he can give his thoughts.

Pretty certain you are looking at what was billed. Example, I operate my private practice and I bill $60 per 15 minute unit for Part B mobile outpatient. That comes out to $240 billed for 4 units/1hour. After payment we are looking at $100-$108 actually received. Add in the cost of EMR, liability insurance, marketing, billing, book keeping, etc that $100 becomes a lot less real quick. Add in a 3.4% decrease in CPT codes reimbursement for 2024 and I average a $5 decrease for 2024 reimbursement per hour. Depending on what I bill for. As an owner you are taking 100% risk and when you come home from seeing patients you are wearing all of the hats. You are also risking that something was billed incorrectly and you are not getting paid. Consider that above and if you are willing to proceed go for it! Owning your own biz is the way to go! I love what I do! 

If you are talking Home health part A. That's a bit more complex, as you have to adjust for community/institution, complexity, and patient diagnosis. Two 30 day periods and how it's reimbursed differently for every patient admitted.

post_text:
Hey all. 

Medicare question here. I work for an OP Ortho company in NYC that is in network w Medicare (OON all other instrance though). 

When I check my personal NPI # on CMS website, my name comes up as a MCR provider. The address listed is my employer‚Äôs office and the entity type is ‚Äúindividual‚Äù. 

If I leave the practice I currently work for and open my own practice am I already considered ‚Äúin network‚Äù with Medicare? Are there additional steps (other than changing the listed address) that I would have to take with Medicare to start seeing patients? 

Thanks!

comments.text: You need to have ur own place, apply for your group NPI and EIN, u will have to apply for Medicare certification and then they will process your papers, come for surprise inspection before they give u credentialling
That NPI you now have is your personal. You need to apply for an NPI for your business then reassign your personal NPI to it before you can see patients who have Medicare.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey all. 

Medicare question here. I work for an OP Ortho company in NYC that is in network w Medicare (OON all other instrance though). 

When I check my personal NPI # on CMS website, my name comes up as a MCR provider. The address listed is my employer‚Äôs office and the entity type is ‚Äúindividual‚Äù. 

If I leave the practice I currently work for and open my own practice am I already considered ‚Äúin network‚Äù with Medicare? Are there additional steps (other than changing the listed address) that I would have to take with Medicare to start seeing patients? 

Thanks!

COMMENT 1: You need to have ur own place, apply for your group NPI and EIN, u will have to apply for Medicare certification and then they will process your papers, come for surprise inspection before they give u credentialling

COMMENT 2: That NPI you now have is your personal. You need to apply for an NPI for your business then reassign your personal NPI to it before you can see patients who have Medicare.

post_text:
For those cash pay but participating with Medicare:
Since you're not contracted with any secondary insurance the patient might have, what happens if a patient's trying to push their deductible or anything else they might owe onto a secondary insurance? Do you just give them a super bill, do you just have them pay it and they can submit their receipt to their other insurance, or do they just pay their deductible with you and that's just not something they can use their secondary for?
I apologize if this is a dumb question, I've been in a hospital clinic for the last several years and they don't really make me have to understand very much Medicare stuff, because there's always somebody who will fix it

comments.text: The supplemental won't pay the deductible unless it's Plan F. That plan was discontinued years ago but some were grandfathered in. I'd be collecting up front.
They don‚Äôt submit to their secondary. Medicare will automatically cross it over to their secondary and most will pay you even though you are not in network.

post_text: Can someone explain to me when option 2 and 3 on an ABN would be checked. I understand option 1 but the more and more I read about it, I can‚Äôt wrap my head around it. Just a ‚Äúdumbed down‚Äù explanation would be great lol

comments.text: A few years ago, I had a person check off box one. I collected my payment, and then Medicare reimbursed only a small amount for a few visits. I did use the GA modifier. I refunded the amount that Medicare paid me back, but not the entire amount that they paid me. Was that the correct course of action? ÔøºÔøº

Option 2 would be a non-covered service that the patient pays for and does not want to try to file with insurance. 
Option 3 would be if you offer a non-covered service and the patient declines. 
This doc from CMS has plain descriptions of the options 

https://www.cms.gov/medicare/medicare-general-information/bni/downloads/abn-form-instructions.pdf

post_text:
I‚Äôm a solo therapist, I take Medicare and OON with all others. I‚Äôm swamped and super busy even with just taking Medicare. My question is,
Rather than hiring since I‚Äôm so busy, has anyone created a concierge package to offer clients ? Must be a member kind of thing ? The goal of course is to make more and work less, but I‚Äôm trying to figure out how to do that being solo and not hiring. If anyone has any input it‚Äôs greatly appreciated

comments.text: You may have to call it something else.  If u r in network with medicare, they may frown on charging their clients cash on top of being in network.  It could be construed as a foem of balance billing.

Use the Medicare covered episode to find out what makes them tick. ‚ÄúJohn‚Äôs Golf plan‚Äù with a goal to drive 150 yards. ‚ÄúJim‚Äôs Skeet Shooting Plan‚Äù with a goal to be able to handle a 12 gauge etc
$1000-2000 a month. 

‚ÄúFall prevention‚Äù plans are kind of lame, nobody wants that. Need to address what motivates them

Write out a cool plan, laminate it. Make it look exciting and deliver it in a folder 1-2 weeks before discharge and let them talk about it with their family.

post_text: I am in network with Medicare plus blue. My patient has Medicare plus blue as primary and auto as secondary as this was an auto injury. Can I require her to pay the copay as normal and request reimbursement from her own auto company?

comments.text:
We had the same case.
If it's an Auto Injury and the case is still open and/or active, the Auto Insurance comes in as primary.
Auto is primary unless, as mentioned above, the case is closed.  Auto is never secondary

full_thread_text:
POST: I am in network with Medicare plus blue. My patient has Medicare plus blue as primary and auto as secondary as this was an auto injury. Can I require her to pay the copay as normal and request reimbursement from her own auto company?

COMMENT 1: We had the same case.
If it's an Auto Injury and the case is still open and/or active, the Auto Insurance comes in as primary.

COMMENT 2: Auto is primary unless, as mentioned above, the case is closed.  Auto is never secondary

comments.text:
I think I get what you‚Äôre saying here‚Ä¶ I just want to post my two cents about Medicare

Understandably we‚Äôve paid into the benefit through taxes, and it should be used to buffer the cost of healthcare at the age when all those expenses are hitting. 

But if individuals have the means to not use the benefit, it should be less complicated to allow them the ability to control how they spend their money. 

Advantage plans can con people right out of traditional Medicare, and into the palms of private insurance corps. But providers aren‚Äôt given a clear cut way to educate clients on resources or strategic healthcare spending‚Ä¶

The insurance gambit is a fixed game against providers and patients.

post_text:
Hey all,

After looking through post after post regarding medicare part b, I have a few questions (I am sorry to beat a dead horse, I really tried to do my research before asking, but it's confusing!).. üòÖ

I am currently a mobile, cash-based PT in NY who specializes in neuro PT. I have been regularly seeing about 2-3 clients, 2 days a week, which is what works for me currently with my other job set up. I have had no relationship with medicare (not been seeing Medicare clients), but obviously with my specialty I think it could open up a lot more potential opportunities for me. 

1. For those who have a relationship with Medicare Part B, If I go that route, do you find that it makes more sense to be par or non-par in terms of ease of reimbursement, etc. ? I did find the resources on how to go about enrolling, but wanted to gain a little perspective from anyone who currently has a relationship with Medicare, particularly with reimbursement changes ahead in 2024.
1.  For those who participate in Medicare Part B and also accept cash for mobile services , do you limit your travel radius for your Medicare Part B patients to a smaller distance from home to compensate for lesser reimbursement compared to your cash fee?

Thank you so much in advance.. I know this is a topic that has been brought up many times!

comments.text: Sarah Viola would be a good one to chat with on par vs non par. She started non-par and is switching to par.
Definitely PAR is easier and the least hassle to manage.  I can help with credentialing if you want someone to do it for you. I have been operating a practice for over 7 years now.

post_text:
Is it illegal to treat Medicare patients on an out of pocket bash based basis for physical therapy?

Background: have started a mobile cash based practice and initially had the target of under 65. I‚Äôve had a physician want to send his folks to me- but most of his people are Medicare. I was under the impression that physical therapists cannot opt out of using Medicare for covered services- and if not lisenced by Medicare then you can‚Äôt see them. 

Is this true? If so, is there any specific site or paper I can find this written at?

comments.text: If you are not in network with Medicare you cannot treat a Medicare beneficiary with skilled physical therapy services when the services are medically necessary.
Simple answer is no. If u want to treat Medicare beneficiaries for PT services that are covered by the Medicare program, u must enroll in Medicare.

full_thread_text:
POST: Is it illegal to treat Medicare patients on an out of pocket bash based basis for physical therapy?

Background: have started a mobile cash based practice and initially had the target of under 65. I‚Äôve had a physician want to send his folks to me- but most of his people are Medicare. I was under the impression that physical therapists cannot opt out of using Medicare for covered services- and if not lisenced by Medicare then you can‚Äôt see them. 

Is this true? If so, is there any specific site or paper I can find this written at?

COMMENT 1: If you are not in network with Medicare you cannot treat a Medicare beneficiary with skilled physical therapy services when the services are medically necessary.

COMMENT 2: Simple answer is no. If u want to treat Medicare beneficiaries for PT services that are covered by the Medicare program, u must enroll in Medicare.

post_text: Pros and cons of billing insurance vs cash pay for private OT, lymphedema therapist and Graston specialist. Insurance seems overwhelming to me but maybe it‚Äôs worth it? Thanks in advance!

comments.text: What age? If your doing Medicare age. Recommend Medicare and OON or Cash otherwise. But depends on state, etc.

Billing insurance provides financial security and attracts a broader client base, but it comes with administrative burdens. Cash pay simplifies the process, offering flexibility but may limit clients. Assess your priorities and client demographics to decide what aligns best with your practice.

post_text: I would like to propose contract OT services to a rather large grocery chain in NY. I used to work for this company and I know they value employee safety. I was hoping I could take on some sort of workplace injury prevention role in addition to providing upper extremity based therapy in hopes of preventing employees from having to undergo workers comp claims or further injury/surgery. I just have no idea where to start or how this would even work with dealing with insurance. Any guidance would be appreciated!

comments.text: Lauren Hebert has an amazing program for ergonomics. Emma Shapiro also has a workshop for it. Good luck!

Need to find out if they are self insured or not.  That may determine if they can control where the patient goes vs a work comp network.  Also if you have ‚Äúindustrial medicine‚Äù clinics in your area they may already be using them.  The play is to do what you are proposing from a ‚Äúcorporate wellness‚Äù side.  Look for the Director of Safety usually in either HR or ops department and see if they are open to a meeting.  Pitch that you can address OSHA no -reportables better than the big clinics because you can be mobile and take the time to do workshops at each store

Also if you have ‚Äúindustrial medicine‚Äù clinics in your area they may already be using them.  The play is to do what you are proposing from a ‚Äúcorporate wellness‚Äù side. post_text:
Someone shared a great video on the pros/cons of traditional Medicare vs Advantage plans, and I'm wondering if it was in this group. 
I met with my own health insurance rep and we discussed this. My rep is eager to understand how this really works for patients from a different perspective, and I'd really like to share the video I saw. Can someone point me in the right direction? I'm remembering a therapist sitting on the floor, explaining it with drawings...maybe on a white board. Thanks! Helping educate those that sell these policies seems pretty darn important!

comments.text: If you go with an advantage plan when first applying for Medicare you will not be guaranteed a supplement if you change your mind. You will need underwriting. Also, advantage plans advertise no premiums because Medicare pays them $1000. This is all coming from an insurance broker of 40+ yrs
I don't know of such a video but if you are in different States throughout the year, like having a vacation home, you want traditional Medicare. Many Advantage plans are Regional based.

post_text: Is an online exercise class a qualified HSA expense? Anyone know how to get your services approved by HSA.

comments.text:
Agree with Anthony‚Äôs statement.  The insurer would need to get a letter of medical necessity from their physician with a medical diagnosis.  
For example, Optum has a form that a provider can use to qualify as a LMN to use Optum HSA. 
Have the insurer check into their own HSA carrier to see what is required.

My gym just started working with truemed- you can fill out a survey on your medical history and they will send you a letter of medical necessity if you qualify based on your responses. I wonder if you could do something like that? Not sure if it matters if it is online vs in person?

post_text: Had someone reach out with VA benefits inquiring how that works with OON cash pay services and I honestly have no clue if it works the same as other commercial insurances or if there are more rules around it. Would love if someone could give me a brief run down. And does anyone have an idea of how well (or poorly) they reimburse? *cross posting*

comments.text: VA doesn't offer OON benefits. You have to be a provider in their network and also have authorization prior to treating to be eligible for payment. The patient can pay cash to see you, but won't be reimbursed.

Va goes in network only at least for outpatient through va community care through optum basically united health care so if you have a contract with optum u can get the va community care.  Preauthorization is required so until they have an auth number generated in their system you cant treat them.  It does pay well though 90 plus for 4 units outpatient

post_text: We usually participate with running events in our community and provide PT services without any extra requirements but this time I was told this "We will need you to additionally insure Sarasota County and Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy with your insurance"... any red flags about this? or anyone with experience in adding your county to your insurance? tbh i'm not really sure what this means and what to do so any explanation is much appreciated!

comments.text: One of the chamber events I do (a business expo), they make us list them on our insurance policy for the event. I just call CM&F and ask to have them added and it's no extra charge

This is common. Just call or email your agent and say "I need to add Sarasota county and blah blah blah as additionally insured." Sometimes they want an address. They will send you a COI naming them as additionally insured and you can then give that to the requestor as proof.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: One of the chamber events I do (a business expo), they make us list them on our insurance policy for the event. I just call CM&F and ask to have them added and it's no extra charge

COMMENT 2: This is common. Just call or email your agent and say "I need to add Sarasota county and blah blah blah as additionally insured." Sometimes they want an address. They will send you a COI naming them as additionally insured and you can then give that to the requestor as proof.

post_text:
Letter from Medicare stating we bill more  therex than our counterparts ....  I'm not sure what to think ...  what else are you to bill besides therex as a PT OT.... I could see if it was all Neuro or an Therapeutic activities that is billed higher .... 
...the letter stated for us to look into our billing practices in the next 6 months 

Thoughts on this ....

comments.text:
The best way to avoid audits is to diversify your billing.  Any exercise can be billed under any type of code, it all depends on why you‚Äôre doing an exercise.

Straight leg raise = ther act if you‚Äôre prescribing it to help the pt get their leg in bed 

SLR = neuro if regaining quad and hip flexor cocontraction. 

SLR = ther ex if doing it purely for strengthening. (Generally though, aren‚Äôt you strengthening something so the patient can DO things?) 

I bill ther ex the least because I‚Äôm usually prescribing an exercise to have the patient regain a specific task.  It also bills the least.
A lot of therex is them telling you that you aren't focusing enough on function, which is all that medicare wants to pay for

full_thread_text:

...the letter stated for us to look into our billing practices in the next 6 months 

Thoughts on this ....

COMMENT 1: The best way to avoid audits is to diversify your billing.  Any exercise can be billed under any type of code, it all depends on why you‚Äôre doing an exercise.

Straight leg raise = ther act if you‚Äôre prescribing it to help the pt get their leg in bed 

SLR = neuro if regaining quad and hip flexor cocontraction. 

SLR = ther ex if doing it purely for strengthening. (Generally though, aren‚Äôt you strengthening something so the patient can DO things?) 

I bill ther ex the least because I‚Äôm usually prescribing an exercise to have the patient regain a specific task.  It also bills the least.

COMMENT 2: A lot of therex is them telling you that you aren't focusing enough on function, which is all that medicare wants to pay for

post_text: And to follow that... I always think of Square and Stripe but sounds like people are pretty happy with IvyPay?  Pros / cons?  Anyone want to give me a link - IF you are truly happy with it üòÅ

comments.text: I like Ivypay. Pro is that the card is on file once you put it in initially so you don't have to swipe.  It is suppose to be hipaa secure.  My only Con so far is that the first payment did take extra time to process and I think I had to contact customer care, but they responded prompty and, after that, it has been reasonable turn around time for my standards.  Looking back at recent payments, it is taking 2 days to be deposited into my bank account once i bill the card. My code is shay098
If you already use QuickBooks they have a card reader

post_text: How do I go about billing auto insurance? A patient reached out but I have never done that before.

comments.text: Patrick Toy has the best information for this.

Pretty easy you need the name of the insurance company all state geico etc the claim number and just payient demos.  Call the insurance company get there mailing address and mail in the claims with the notes as well you have to send both.  There lawyer will reach out later for the notes and claims via email later on.  Everyone is out of network with auto so it pays really well usually 170 or so per visit so worth the extra work. Here in florida the pip is up to 2500 but check that to see if its exhausted usually the lawyer will know.  If it is exhausted u can bill there insurance or do ur cash rate and have them sign something called an lop.  Once they case settles you will get paid if the lop is signed the money the patient owes out of pocket.  The auto company pays u if the pip is not exhausted and like i said around 170 or so for 4 units

full_thread_text:

Call the insurance company get there mailing address and mail in the claims with the notes as well you have to send both.  There lawyer will reach out later for the notes and claims via email later on.  Everyone is out of network with auto so it pays really well usually 170 or so per visit so worth the extra work. Here in florida the pip is up to 2500 but check that to see if its exhausted usually the lawyer will know.  If it is exhausted u can bill there insurance or do ur cash rate and have them sign something called an lop.  Once they case settles you will get paid if the lop is signed the money the patient owes out of pocket.  The auto company pays u if the pip is not exhausted and like i said around 170 or so for 4 units

post_text:
I want to be more consistent with my billing. But I typically wait until I have all plan of care signstures.

I don‚Äôt have an issue with getting the signatures but sometimes thenphysicians can take an extra week or two.

Knowing this, would it be okay to submit the billing before receiving the signed plan of cares? But knowing I‚Äôll get the plan of care within the next 1-2 weeks?

comments.text: As long as you are making a valid attempt to contact the physician, you can bill.  Make yourself a contact log and document each time you've contacted the physician to prove that you are making valid attempts.  I attempt 3 times before giving up, but that doesn't ever stop me from getting paid.

post_text:
Hi everyone. I'm a Texas provider here who is Cash only mobile clinic. 

A few questions as I'm still in the learning curve of being cash only and OON. One issue I have ran into is with patients who have BCBS

1. If a patient requests services, signs financial policy, and you provided a GFE.......do you courtsey verify auth if they request superbills prior to their sessions? Or do you leave it completely up to the patient to ask for auth from PCP and follow up on it to see if it's been approved or don't follow up and leave it up to the patient completely? 

2. If you saw a patient who did not require auth but a pre notification was needed to the insurance to inform them they were about to start  prior to therapy.....would you refund them all the $ they paid upfront, partial or none  as this was not completed and PT was aware they were going to ask for superbills? 

Being OON seems to be just as hard as being in network....or I'm bad at keeping business and heart felt sympathy for the patient's seperate. I am legally trying to know my rights and do what is ethically right as well.

comments.text:
There are a lot of different ways to handle OON. For example I submit all bills to the insurance for the patient, take the insurance payment on assignment then balance bill the patient. 

Conversely I know ppl who take the entire upfront payment and leave all reimbursement to the pt. And absolutely don‚Äôt give refunds. 

In my opinion I believe that part of the appeal of OON to patients is a premium service. That includes not only treatment but customer service and administrative assistance. So we try to help our pts as much as we can.

I provide superbills only and collect payments at the time of service. When someone contacts me about starting treatment I tell them if they would like to be reimbursed they should call their insurance company to see what their OON benefits are, how to get reimbursed, if they need preauth, etc. Some do and some don‚Äôt. If they do require preauth I‚Äôll call and/or fax what the insurance company wants but that‚Äôs it. I don‚Äôt give refunds.

post_text:
I need help! I was seeing a patient with Luna (outpatient at home) and patient was in the process of having Luna become an official provider with her Mass Mutual long term care insurance. She was not using Medicare whatsoever. She was self pay with Luna and Mass Mutual after 90 days would begin to reimburse her. Long story short, the patient and her husband became so irritated with the process (Luna and MM) that they have decided to hire me (cash based) to see her. 

If they do clear me as a provider, I am wanting to make sure 1. Mass Mutual understands that I am mobile outpatient and not home health. 2. If she was paying Luna self pay at $125, is it totally off to pay me cash?

After 90 days of care (she started with home health then moved on to outpatient) they will reimburse her services once they get the invoice. I left the clinic to not have to deal with insurance. I‚Äôm venting and asking for opinions on this, whether I should take her or not. She would pay me and I would provide an invoice just like Luna would have done for her. 

Hope this makes sense! Thoughts?

comments.text: Besides the Medicare issue, I had a similar patient who wanted me to work with her when I wasn‚Äôt established. I gave her receipts. But then she wanted to submit all the receipts to her long-term care and get reimbursed. The long-term care insurance wanted full codes, and Proof of billing that Medicare rejected it before paying for it. I would just make sure that she‚Äôs not using your bills to get paid back because then it opens up a can of worms. Ôøº

Tricky situation. Typically the purpose of a LTC plan is to cover costs for the insured if they lose the ability or need significant help with at least 2 of 6 functional tasks: bathing, eating, dressing, toileting, bed transfers, and chair transfers. If her home health discharge OASIS paperwork showed that she was independent with these, Mass Mutual may have a case not to pay them. You would essentially have to show that she is restricted with at least 2 of these.

Since she still has Medicare, there still may be a case from a CMS federal level that she can‚Äôt pay you cash if you/the patient are trying to  make a case that her treatment is medically necessary (because she has functional limitations that need treatment) 

I personally wouldn‚Äôt take them as cash pay and would have them continue to go through Luna and/or use Medicare part B insurance. If she needs services like dry needling or other skills that are helpful and not covered by Medicare, I would invoice them for that and they can submit those services to Mass Mutual. They may still be eligible for some reimbursement and you wouldn‚Äôt be caught in a battle between CMS and their private LTC policy

post_text:
Hey!

I am providing a private, cash pay patient with a superbill to submit to her insurance under OON benefits.

Can anyone provide insight on what PT codes can be billed together? I now know you cant bill two of the same codes without a 59 modifier, so I want to avoid another coding mistake and hopefully get it right on the first round. The patient is R ankle pain ICD10.
If I bill 4 codes, one of each: manual therapy, therapeutic exercise, neuro re-ed and therapeutic activities is that okay? or gait training instead of one of the above works too. TIA!

comments.text: One of the benefits of being cash base is that you don't have to worry about this headache. Bill the CPT codes you performed and provide the superbill. As an OON provider you have no commitment to play by insurance rules and can treat as such. GP modifier CPT codes for therapists can be used.

post_text: Hello! I am new here. I am currently working on starting a private pay outpatient clinic on my own. I live in colorado so wanted to avoid insurance due to the capped reimbursement with commercial insurances, but was curious what people‚Äôs thoughts are on being in-network with Medicare?? Is it worth it at all?

comments.text: I did that prior to switching to health and wellness. Medicare was pretty easy to navigate and I was paid within 3 weeks and never had issues. I had one instance of a denial and I threw in a code to go over cap and was paid for those visits. Wasn‚Äôt my favorite but my location had a great deal of geriatric referrals. I did that a year and decided I despise all the rules, tracking down docs to sign notes, etc so moved to wellness instead. I‚Äôm also in CO. You can look up the par provider reimbursement rates online using the novitas online portal. If doing Medicare, I highly recommend signing up for this Portal, esp for any insurance verifications. I also heard that legally you can‚Äôt bill Medicare private pay for PT services so that was another reason I got in network
What type of clients/practice? If geriatrics.. yes!!

post_text:
How would you proceed to discharge a patient who is causing havock, is pushy/aggressive and keeps pushing your boundaries, BUT is also a health care provider (though other discipline) and not only you share a few patients with but has sent you patients in the past (so kind of a referral source, which is why I‚Äôve been very diplomatic). Plus this guy is super charming and his patients love him. So I am nervous about him bad mouthing me. Ugh
I have 7 additional sessions authorized per his insurance. It pains me the idea to see this person 7 additional times. And the chance he will want to complete more afterwards and get approved for it. For what is worth it he is improving. And he is happy with me as his therapist. It is just that the emotional havock he causes is not worth the discounted rate his insurance pays me. 

Please advise!

comments.text:
Generally if he is like this with you he is like this with everyone. 

Of course he likes working with you because you are willing to let him be this way and it feels good to him. 

If it ends badly it will likely happen in the way you expect. He will through a tantrum and make you feel guilty but it doesn‚Äôt matter. You can only be a punching bag for so long. 

His influence on others also doesn‚Äôt matter. They likely know how he is and won‚Äôt put much importance on his opinion. 

Personally, I would finish the approved visits. Increase the intensity of the workouts to a level high enough that it is uncomfortable for him to continue. Celebrate his success and if he choose for more just find a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù therapist who can take him to the next level of success. üòÇ

I know this personality all too well. You absolutely cannot give in to his demands. It‚Äôs like adding fuel to a fire. He knows he can take advantage of your demeanor. Once you cut off his supply of validation/winning, he will find a new target. It doesn‚Äôt mean you have to discharge him immediately. Do the 7 visits and have a firm end date. He will likely periodically bother you in the future but don‚Äôt give in! Also if he bad mouths you, ignore it. These types of people are smear campaign experts. He will flip flop between badmouthing and praising you.

full_thread_text:
POST: How would you proceed to discharge a patient who is causing havock, is pushy/aggressive and keeps pushing your boundaries, BUT is also a health care provider (though other discipline) and not only you share a few patients with but has sent you patients in the past (so kind of a referral source, which is why I‚Äôve been very diplomatic). Plus this guy is super charming and his patients love him. So I am nervous about him bad mouthing me. Ugh
I have 7 additional sessions authorized per his insurance. It pains me the idea to see this person 7 additional times. And the chance he will want to complete more afterwards and get approved for it. For what is worth it he is improving. And he is happy with me as his therapist. It is just that the emotional havock he causes is not worth the discounted rate his insurance pays me. 

Please advise!

COMMENT 1: Generally if he is like this with you he is like this with everyone. 

Of course he likes working with you because you are willing to let him be this way and it feels good to him. 

If it ends badly it will likely happen in the way you expect. He will through a tantrum and make you feel guilty but it doesn‚Äôt matter. You can only be a punching bag for so long. 

His influence on others also doesn‚Äôt matter. They likely know how he is and won‚Äôt put much importance on his opinion. 

Personally, I would finish the approved visits. Increase the intensity of the workouts to a level high enough that it is uncomfortable for him to continue. Celebrate his success and if he choose for more just find a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù therapist who can take him to the next level of success. üòÇ

COMMENT 2: I know this personality all too well. You absolutely cannot give in to his demands. It‚Äôs like adding fuel to a fire. He knows he can take advantage of your demeanor. Once you cut off his supply of validation/winning, he will find a new target. It doesn‚Äôt mean you have to discharge him immediately. Do the 7 visits and have a firm end date. He will likely periodically bother you in the future but don‚Äôt give in! Also if he bad mouths you, ignore it. These types of people are smear campaign experts. He will flip flop between badmouthing and praising you.

post_text:
Hello! I‚Äôm a PTA specializing in pelvic health, clinical pilates and Myofascial release. 
I‚Äôm venturing out in the new year and starting my own cash based practice. 
I have a PT who will do initial evals and consults PRN. 
I‚Äôm looking for advice on if there are legal guidelines for owning a cash based practice as a PTA/PT. 
Any input and advice appreciated üôè

comments.text: What State?!

I have done the same in Florida.  The only authority outside of federal insurance is your practice act and you may find they don‚Äôt even mention it as most of the per visit type rules are insurance driven. 
There are rules about taking various patients from Medicare, Medicaid and federal insurances though. 
Best wishes!

post_text: HELP! Hello all, as i get closer to starting up and becoming Uncaged I still have one major road block that I need to figure out. Health insurance‚Ä¶ I want my wife to work part time and be home more often with our daughter. I would have to provide our benefits. Many have mentioned Christian Healthcare Ministries, however unless you have $1000+ claim, it seems it won‚Äôt be covered. How do those with CHM afford basic MD visits for colds, viruses, physicals, etc? For those who don‚Äôt and got their own insurance, can you recommend other options?

comments.text: There‚Äôs MediShare and Christian Health Ministries also

You basically have threechoices.  Go with Indemnity plans like CHM which provide mostly just catastrophic coverage or go with an HMO with better coverage but fewer network options or a PPO with the best coverage, lower copays etc. But highest premiums.

post_text:
Hi,

Can a patient submit a superbill to their secondary insurance for reimbursement if their primary is Medicare? Or is that something that would flag Medicare to look into us taking cash payment for physical therapy services. We do have our patients sign ABNs and ensure that they understand they are waiving their ability to submit to Medicare, but some are asking if they can submit to their secondary. Thank you in advance.

comments.text: If they are submitting to their secondary, they are submitting for reimbursement of skilled services...which u cant charge cash for,  for a Medicare Benificiary...as Jason Bloom said above.  ILLEGAL  be careful!  Also, secondary only pays after primary pays first...in this case, primary is never even billed
Yea that's super illegal...that's also not really what an ABN is for,so just be careful...

post_text: For those who are billing through insurance, what icd 10 code are you used for cva in an outpatient setting? I‚Äôve been fighting with insurance reps on a patient since 2022.

comments.text:
You aren't treating a CVA, you are treating the effects of a CVA. 163.9 is a CVA code, that would be treated in the ER or hospital acutely by MDs. 
You can use the hemiplegia due to a CVA; those I codes
Abnormality of gait goes on every stroke I see.

post_text:
Hello colleagues, 
I recently applied with Blue Shield as an individual out-of-network provider so that my clients can be reimbursed through the super bill I provide them with. Since I operate as a mobile PT, I provided them with my virtual office address . However, my application was not processed because it is not a physical address. As a mobile PT, I do not have a physical address. If any of you have faced a similar situation, how did you resolve it? Did you provide a different address or find another solution? I was hoping not to provide my home address.

comments.text: There are businesses set up where their actual business is to act as a physical address for this purpose. I‚Äôm trying to recall what they are called. I‚Äôm also wondering though why apply to be OON. As a cash based therapist I‚Äôm just automatically out of network. I give super bills and then families submit them if they‚Äôd like to but their reimbursement as to do with if their plan offers OON benefits or not. Not me applying to be an OON provider.

I am in-network with BCBS so I could be wrong here, however it is strange that you would need to apply as an OON provider.

I work with many insurances OON and there way no application. Submit claims (or have the patient do it) and they will respond to the claims with era/payment if applicable. They may ask for a W9.

With the topic of Medicare and cash prices, so if I‚Äôm an owner of a private practice in Texas who only provides cash services, am I simply not allowed to take a Medicare patient who is willing to pay my cash prices? post_text: I have a home health patient who is receiving HH PT and has opted to private pay for an outside PT so they can have more therapy visits per week. I know they cannot be charged out of pocket for services that would be covered by Medicare and that a PT cannot opt out of Medicare. Is this PT correct in accepting private pay for additional PT services since the patient is already receiving their Medicare entitled services from the HH agency?

comments.text:
Yes because additional services are not covered while under the Med A HH POC. 

If additional services were medically necessary then the other PT would have increased frequency.

Homehealth bills as Medicare A-
And the succeeding visits by the PT is probably part B ( in home outpatient)?
Anyone doing this? See a patient through Home health agency
Then when discharged, see the same pt as outpatient- home under Medicare Part B?

post_text: Hi all, I recently opened my mobile PT practice. I will be taking medicare and cash patients. What is medicare looking for in a policies and procedures manual? I would like to build my own for now to pass an audit while I shop around for options more in depth. If anyone is willing to share what they came up with I would greatly appreciate it! Or even a spot to find a template. Thanks in advance!

comments.text: We have some resources on this I can send you to review. You can build yourself or we have a manual as well for PT and OT and SLP that is completed by therapists doing exactly what you described. Some manuals are not specific for mobile, Medicare, etc. do be sure to check around. Also check out the OIGs website!

Nancy Beckley's Compliance Rules has great templates. An investment well worth the time saved. Lol

Edit: for reference, we purchased her resources and they‚Äôre awesome. Also we are mobile Medicare/cash also.

post_text:
I need advice on OON billing. I am new to this and I have a potential patient wanting to start physical therapy with me. I called his insurance and verified his benefits. 30 visits/year, no co-insurance, and no auth required. However, he has contributed $0 to his OON deductible. I gave him my cash pay rates and he‚Äôs willing to pay cash. 

My question now is do I still bill his insurance so it applies to his deductible? If so, do I have to bill their OON reimbursement flat rate or my own rate? TIA

comments.text:
If you have an EMR this is/should be quite easy.  
Put in the codes for DXand treatment codes like you would for anyone else.  
Select ‚Äúno‚Äù on accept assignment. and also put the price the patient has paid to you. And just submit to insurance as your normally would.  Aka courtesy billing.

That really sounds like In Network benefits.  You can still submit to insurance but only for the amount u charged him.  The ins. Co. Will need the cost broken down into different CPT codes.  At my clinic, we bill OON as mentioned above or a flat cash rate with no CPT codes and no OON billing.

full_thread_text:

I gave him my cash pay rates and he‚Äôs willing to pay cash.

COMMENT 1: If you have an EMR this is/should be quite easy.  
Put in the codes for DXand treatment codes like you would for anyone else.  
Select ‚Äúno‚Äù on accept assignment. and also put the price the patient has paid to you. And just submit to insurance as your normally would.  Aka courtesy billing.

COMMENT 2: That really sounds like In Network benefits.  You can still submit to insurance but only for the amount u charged him.  The ins. Co. Will need the cost broken down into different CPT codes.  At my clinic, we bill OON as mentioned above or a flat cash rate with no CPT codes and no OON billing.

post_text: I (individually) am already an approved provider for Medicare (was credentialed though a company I previously worked for) my mobile PT business is not (yet). Can I still see a Medicare patient, now? Can I bill as just a individual provider and not a business provider? (Hope that question makes sense..)

comments.text:
You can but you probably want to bill as a business vs an individual. 

You can complete the business application and then hold claims until approval. The start date should go back to the date you completed the application.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: You can but you probably want to bill as a business vs an individual. 

You can complete the business application and then hold claims until approval. The start date should go back to the date you completed the application.

*Please delete if post not allowed 

Sorry for the long post. I have a personal question but figured people here would be most knowledgeable. Can we bill for indirect care? I was under the impression we cannot as it‚Äôs not direct contact. I‚Äòm in California.

Background:
Im taking my kid to a multidisciplinary peds center (offering PT, OT, SLP) and they gave me the following information. They‚Äôre charging me for notes? We‚Äôre also only getting one therapy service and won‚Äôt have a team. 

Edit: They are in-network with my PPO and accept other insurance. No Medicaid, I don‚Äôt know about Medicare 

‚ÄúExamples of indirect care include meetings where members of the child‚Äôs treatment team discussed the child‚Äôs progress in their treatment plan, as well as the creation of progress reports. If the child‚Äôs treatment program is funded by a program that allows us to bill for indirect care, then the client is not responsible for the cost-share associated with indirect care. However, if they do not cover indirect care ** Therapy will bill you directly.
The explanation of benefits (EOB) that you receive from your insurance provider may shows that they had paid for dates of service where the client did not have any direct interaction with the treatment team. If a client‚Äôs insurance benefit is canceled and the client does not inform ** Therapy of the benefit cancellation, then the client or legal guardian will be responsible for payment of the direct and indirect care that is not covered by the insurance provider. Therefore, it is very important that you inform ** Therapy immediately if the client‚Äôs benefit is canceled. If ** Therapy services are self-funded, then the child or legal guardian is responsible for payment of all direct and indirect care.‚Äù

comments.text: While not quite the same thing, my daughter‚Äôs endocrinologist charges $200/year to cover dealing with the prior authorizations and letters of medical necessity. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs ethical but don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs technically illegal

I know some offices charge the client/patient for reports. But cms/regulators has a max amount cap, like no more than $1/page, idk how much it is nowadays. 

The consult package, poc, progress note, discharge report all sounds like the CPT codes on super bills. They are trying to guarantee payments received, if not billed otherwise. 

But! If they are in network with your insurance and they confirmed that you have insurance, legally, according to cms, they cannot charge you these, they have to bill to your insurance & you can appeal their decisions too.

post_text: I am a LMT and CLT. I provide lipedema care. I do not accept insurance; I'm cash based. A client is trying to get her insurance to reimburse her for my services. I received a letter from BCBS saying that I am not on file with them and they provided a link to their credentialing page. As a LMT, I'm not familiar with what this means. Do I need to go through the process so the cleint can be reimbursed? I have zero intention of billing insurance directly.

comments.text:
Many insurances require you to be "credentialed" in order for the be willing to accept any documentation from you, whether it be a super bill or CMS 1500.

Credentialing is not usually the same thing as "contracted" or in-network.  With credentialing, the usually want a W-9 and your information to simply list you in their system.  No contract needed.

They might not accept the superbill if they require you to be credentialed.

It is possible to be Credentialed as an OON provider. If you complete any credentialing, then you want to ensure that you are not being asked to enter into a contract with them and their contracted rate. More often than not, an insurance can process the superbill provided to the patient with a copy if your W-9 to verify your business information.

full_thread_text:
POST: I am a LMT and CLT. I provide lipedema care. I do not accept insurance; I'm cash based. A client is trying to get her insurance to reimburse her for my services. I received a letter from BCBS saying that I am not on file with them and they provided a link to their credentialing page. As a LMT, I'm not familiar with what this means. Do I need to go through the process so the cleint can be reimbursed? I have zero intention of billing insurance directly.

COMMENT 1: Many insurances require you to be "credentialed" in order for the be willing to accept any documentation from you, whether it be a super bill or CMS 1500.

Credentialing is not usually the same thing as "contracted" or in-network.  With credentialing, the usually want a W-9 and your information to simply list you in their system.  No contract needed.

They might not accept the superbill if they require you to be credentialed.

COMMENT 2: It is possible to be Credentialed as an OON provider. If you complete any credentialing, then you want to ensure that you are not being asked to enter into a contract with them and their contracted rate. More often than not, an insurance can process the superbill provided to the patient with a copy if your W-9 to verify your business information.

post_text: Medicare question.  If pt who utilized 100 Medicare A days in an SNF and actually started  under Medicare B in same SNF is going home,  does she start Medicare A again at home?  Or does she go straight to Medicare B?  I don't want to rob the pt from her MedA benefits.  I can always work with her if needed once discharged from MedA.  Thank you.

comments.text: If the patient is homebound by Medicare definition then they would qualify for part A services for home health. Not homebound, or their advantage plan denying part A authorization, would be part B services.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: If the patient is homebound by Medicare definition then they would qualify for part A services for home health. Not homebound, or their advantage plan denying part A authorization, would be part B services.

post_text: So we do our due diligence by calling and verifying benefits for every single insurance patient we have. We write everything down and keep a name a reference number as well. For every insurance patient we always ask ‚Äúdo you require prior authorization‚Äù and for specific CPT codes. BCBS anthem is denying payment saying we did not verify prior auth but I have all documentation that we did. They ‚Äúinvestigated‚Äù the call and gave me 3 different stories about how we didn‚Äôt have the correct reference number, the call got disconnected, and the last story was that the call ‚Äúcut out‚Äù during the time when we were apparently asking about auth. I‚Äôve asked to hear the same recording and they won‚Äôt allow me and say that it‚Äôs not possible. I am planning to ‚Äúescalate‚Äù the situation but is there anything else I can do? This is just getting out of hand and it‚Äôs sickening what insurance companies continue to get away with.

comments.text: This has been a growing problem for years, and the insurance companies have no accountability. We really need to start sharing these stories with our patients. I think it would also be a great local tv story. No other industry would work the way we have to regarding insurance and reimbursement. Seriously, who do you know who worked today, not knowing when or how much money they‚Äôll get paid. Insurance is controlling the healthcare narrative- hoping you do the ‚Äúwrong thing‚Äù from ‚Äúprovided‚Äù information so you don‚Äôt get reimbursed. This is probably why so many of us are part of this group- to change the narrative one patient, one uncaged clinic at a time, all while giving our clients the phenomenal care they deserve. Ok, that‚Äôs it. I‚Äôm tired now
Report to state insurance commissioner.

Hello!  I've got a billing question I need some help with if anyone has some advice for me!  I have a brick and mortar Pediatric Occupational Therapy clinic, but one of my families who I have known for years asked me to do a second session at their home to work on ADLs with my client. I changed the location to "home" on my insurance claim for the home sessions, and keep his clinic session as "office" on the claim.  The home claim went through and was reimbursed without any trouble, but I wanted to be sure this is correct?

I am curious and second guessing this because my friend owns an in-home SLP business, and she says she keeps the billing as "office", even when she is working in clients homes.  Is this different for SLP vs OT? I figured since my location of service was different, I should be sure to change it on the claim?

I really appreciate any advice, I want to make sure I'm billing appropriately and ethically! Thank you!

post_text: Hi everyone! Many of my clients ask me for receipts that they can submit to their insurance. For evaluations and single visits, this is simple and straightforward. My initial response is that yes I could give her receipts but it would be after each session took place with session date. How do others give receipts for packages? Thank you in advance.

comments.text: You can give them a receipt but nothing with CPT codes until they've used the session, otherwise it is insurance fraud.

post_text: Made a mistake of picking up someone who said they had Medicare coverage (I checked Eligibility on Ability and it went through). Turned out they have United Dual Complete & Simply Healthcare for secondary. I looked it up and United Dual Complete is for those with Medicare & Medicaid. I am assuming this is OON for me. Has anyone have experience with this? Am I able to bill OON? Good thing I have only done the eval and would probably have to pause treatment until more verification.

comments.text: I actually just had this same thing happen. I called to check eligibility and it was your typical Medicare picks up 80% and Medicaid would pick up the rest if you have a contract with them. We don‚Äôt contract with Medicaid so patient was responsible for the 20%.
When I bill these, the primary will pay Medicare rates but you will have to let the other 20% go if it‚Äôs Medicaid and you‚Äôre not credentialed with Medicaid. Cannot bill the patient the 20%

full_thread_text:
POST: Made a mistake of picking up someone who said they had Medicare coverage (I checked Eligibility on Ability and it went through). Turned out they have United Dual Complete & Simply Healthcare for secondary. I looked it up and United Dual Complete is for those with Medicare & Medicaid. I am assuming this is OON for me. Has anyone have experience with this? Am I able to bill OON? Good thing I have only done the eval and would probably have to pause treatment until more verification.

COMMENT 1: I actually just had this same thing happen. I called to check eligibility and it was your typical Medicare picks up 80% and Medicaid would pick up the rest if you have a contract with them. We don‚Äôt contract with Medicaid so patient was responsible for the 20%.

COMMENT 2: When I bill these, the primary will pay Medicare rates but you will have to let the other 20% go if it‚Äôs Medicaid and you‚Äôre not credentialed with Medicaid. Cannot bill the patient the 20%

Hi! I‚Äôm new here! So many questions as I‚Äôm getting started! Please bare with me ü§£

For those of you who bill insurance and are mobile.. 

How do you validate billing outpatient therapy services at home and billing with the modifier (12- home) rather than billing for home health services?

comments.text: You can also bill code 11. It‚Äôs arguably your ‚Äúoffice‚Äù because you bring the clinic to them. Code 12 works but sometimes insurances don‚Äôt understand that it‚Äôs distinct from HH

Hello. FYI 12 is the place of service and not a modifier. Per CMS guidelines in home therapy in eligible for billing under Med B services. BCBS usually follows Medicare standards as I understand it. I can‚Äôt speak for other insurers because those are the only two I deal with.

Greetings to all my fellow "UNCAGED CLINICIANS"

I am an Occupational Therapist who started Prism Health Services, LLC ~12 years ago, in an attempt to break away from Insurance driven(dictated) and poor quality medical equipment/products being forced onto the clients at home. post_text:
Hey Everyone. 
I am looking to get credentialed and contracted with some Medicare Advantage plans. Has anyone gone through this process yourself, and was it a difficult process? Or did you use a credentialing service?

If you did use a credentialing service, which would you recommend? I've gotten text messages and emails from people soliciting their credentialing services, but I'm not about to respond to any of those, I'd rather reach out to a company I know is reputable. 

Thanks for the help!

comments.text: Courtesy bill out of network!!! Check their benefits and see if there are any stipulations to seeing them if you are out of network. I currently do this for plans with OON benefits, and they usually pay me Medicare rates.

I bill all Advantage plans OON. In my experience over a couple years the patient is responsible for either the same or slightly more than they would be with INN provider (maybe a $10
Difference in copay). No one has turned me down for it.

post_text:
Trying to understand simple logistics.

 If you're an OON provider- do you come up with your price (ie for eval). If the patient agrees, they pay you the eval price up front (ie: $100). 
After treatment, you provide a superbill which the patient provides to his/her insurance. Depending on their plan coverage the insurance company then reimburses them. This could be nothing or what ever we charged via super bill?

Also, the superbill amount can be more or less than what you charged the patient (ie: $100)? 

Next as an OON provider- credentialing you or your business isn't needed?

 Also checks of benefits? Do any of you guys do that or leave it up to your patients?

Lastly, what kind of notes do you keep on hand as an OON? Similar to those as in network?

Thanks for reading and answering my questions. Trying to understand the game a lil better ü§£

comments.text: the superbill can not be more than you charged the patient.  if they had reached their out of pocket max, the insurance company would refund all of it. (as long as charges are reasonable and customary)  charging more on your superbill than what u charged thebpatient, esp. in this scenario,  would constitute insurance fraud.  second point, documentarion is a state board requirement.  whether u are in or OON.(assuming care is skilled)..board requirementsdo not change for skilled care

I have my rates for all CPTs codes. So for an eval I charge $250 and the patient pays that at the time of service. I provide a superbill with the code, rate, what the patient paid. Then patient submits that to their insurance. If they have an OON Deductible it will get applied to that. Once that is met the insurance will reimburse them based on their fee schedule. 

Let‚Äôs say the insurance fee schedule for 97163 is $150. Each visit only $150 is applied to the deductible (even though the patient is paying me $250). Once met the patient has a 30% coinsurance. Insurance will reimburse the patient 70% of $150, so the total cost for the patient is 30% of $150 PLUS the $100 difference between the fee schedules. As the ONN provider is doesn‚Äôt matter because they already paid you $250. They should expect to only be reimbursed $105 (70% of $150) once deductible is met.

I have the patient contact their insurance to ask about their ONN benefits. I tried to do it and they would always give me the wrong info so I stopped.

If you tell patients you will give them a superbill for possible reimbursement you should make sure your documentation is detailed enough for insurances. Because they may require the patient to submit documentation. Also some plans require you to get prior auth even as OON. You don‚Äôt have to but then the patient won‚Äôt be reimbursed. Again I have the patient find all of that out first. 

I will also give the patient a W9 form to submit with the superbill if I‚Äôve never had a patient with their insurance in the past.

full_thread_text:

post_text: Hey guys! I'm in the process of getting my cash-based mobile PT business started and am trying to figure out the legality of treating clients as cash pay who have Medicare as their primary insurance. I've read from numerous sources that it is illegal to treat as cash pay when they could potentially get Medicare to cover their services, even if the services we provide are medically necessary. I've also seen or heard of others who do accept clients with Medicare insurance, but inform them that they will not get reimbursed and/or put in writing something along the lines of the clients declining to receive PT services under their Medicare insurance. Is there some way to word on intake forms that would allow cash pay businesses to see Medicare clients or is it illegal in every way?

comments.text: Unfortunately PT cannot opt out of Medicare, so if it is a medically necessary covered service by Medicare, you cannot charge cash for it. If it is something not covered by Medicare, you can charge cash for it. That is why a lot of us have a ‚Äúwellness‚Äù component to our businesses, to offer more than is covered by Medicare. This can include, any service provided outside of the home (gym, park, grocery store), needing help cleaning up their home, HEP compliance when PT is no longer necessary, coaching/training, etc. Chapter 15 of CMS is a great resource to start diving into.

PTs cannot legally opt out of Medicare. 
Any medically necessary service requires a Medicare claim to be filed.

full_thread_text:

I've also seen or heard of others who do accept clients with Medicare insurance, but inform them that they will not get reimbursed and/or put in writing something along the lines of the clients declining to receive PT services under their Medicare insurance. COMMENT 1: Unfortunately PT cannot opt out of Medicare, so if it is a medically necessary covered service by Medicare, you cannot charge cash for it. If it is something not covered by Medicare, you can charge cash for it. That is why a lot of us have a ‚Äúwellness‚Äù component to our businesses, to offer more than is covered by Medicare. This can include, any service provided outside of the home (gym, park, grocery store), needing help cleaning up their home, HEP compliance when PT is no longer necessary, coaching/training, etc. Chapter 15 of CMS is a great resource to start diving into.

COMMENT 2: PTs cannot legally opt out of Medicare. 
Any medically necessary service requires a Medicare claim to be filed.
