post_text: A solo PT practice is interested in bringing on my LLC to work with them. We‚Äôre in Pennsylvania. She is OON for everyone but Medicare. I am an OT. For Medicare purposes, she would only be able to bill my OT services if she initially credentialed as a multi discipline clinic, is this correct? She wants me to apply for type 2 NPI but keep everything under her tax ID. I don't think this is possible, is it? I'd actually prefer to bill under her if there is a way (maybe my type 1 NPI?) as I'd like to keep my pelvic floor LLC solely cash based and don't want to deal with any insurances. Any insight appreciated!

comments.text: Depends on the state. In NY to bill under a discipline there must be a member of the LLC that is licensed in that discipline. This is just now starting to be enforced and some PT owned practices billing for OT service without an OT corporate member are in for a big surprise

post_text:
Hi everyone! I have a quick question regarding super bills. My patients insurance denied her superbill claim bc I didn‚Äôt include a modifier code with every procedure code. Can anyone help guide me here? This is my first superbill submission so I‚Äôm newer to this. 

Thank you!!

comments.text: I am just here to say, I sincerely hope you have a different experience than I (my patients) have had with this process. I would say it‚Äôs more common to have denials / requests for additional info (all of which is already on the superbill), requests to resubmit etc., than it is to have a patient submit a self-Claim with a superbill and get their out of network benefit paid out. I wish it was different. That said, I am solo provider / owner and I have very little time to work through how to streamline this process. Good luck!  And I agree with the GP. I actually add that to all my claims and superbills no matter what since I only have PTs.

If you get in the habit of helping patients resubmit with all kinds of modifiers and you keep issuing them you are back in the habit from which you were running from. We do not issue a second one in my business. I tell them yep, that's why we don't work with them. Bc we will submit a 2nd time and it will be another issue...

post_text:
Hi there, long member first time poster here. Just curious - has anyone here dealt with any clients that have ‚Äúlong term care insurance‚Äù such as through Transamerica or one of these companies.

I have patient that I was seeing through Medicare part b (outpatient at home), and recently discharged them as they were approaching their ‚Äúcap.‚Äù I offered private services thereafter, which they are interested in but are adamant about using this long term care insurance (I am growing a cash based business at the moment and do not take insurance). They are willing to pay out of pocket but would like to seek reimbursement independently through transamerica. Can anyone offer any insight into this? Thank you in advance.

comments.text: So a couple of things. There is no thing as a cap for Medicare patients. Consistently discharging patients at or near the threshold is one key thing that is likely to trigger an audit from Medicare. If they are needing skilled medically necessary services this continues to be covered by Medicare. I have had clients who have used their LTC insurance. I have printed the CMS1500 form noting they had paid with an invoice through my EMR.

post_text:
Hi everyone, Medicare question üëé
A patient that we are seeing only wants to come once/month‚Ä¶. Many reasons why. Anyways I guess the question is if we go to a maintenance program, out of pocket, what are the stipulations? Is it not providing care that can be billed to Medicare? If so, what does that entail then?
I want to help the patient, but at the same time I can‚Äôt bill Medicare for her only coming once/month, and for what I believe is maintenance at this point. I know I am not able to justify that at all.
Advise?

comments.text:
Why can‚Äôt you? Why are we stuck in the paradox of multiple visits per week. 
If they need it and it‚Äôs skilled. Do it. Also get them on a RTM program 

If it‚Äôs not skilled charge them your rate.

Maintenance requires skill to maintain and prevent decline. Therapy is provided because the clients can‚Äôt do it on their own, nor do they have someone who can do it for them. I would strongly argue that someone who can maintain and prevent decline with only monthly visits is not maintenance. Sounds like wellness to me.

post_text:
Great idea for anyone afraid to start. I found out this morning my state, Illinois on average for a facility that accepts Medicaid has a wait list of 1300 patients, approximately 8 to 9 months 
To be seen for Ôøºfor physical therapy. Start here.

comments.text: Not worth the money for medicaid unfortunately

My experience from working in an insurance based hospital network outpatient facility: Medicaid patients were the most likely to no-show (and you cannot charge them a no show fee). So I think that unless the patient is especially motivated, you may still end up ‚Äútwiddling your fingers‚Äù. 
In my state, there is a protracted process to get Medicaid auth after eval (front desk always had to spend hours on the phone tracking these down each week), and they took about 2 weeks to come through. And on top of it, we had to send physical (hard copy) paper work into the state to get these approvals. 
Yes, it‚Äôs important for them to get affordable healthcare but I think that our services being essentially free for the patient meant there was less ‚Äúskin in the game‚Äù for them. 
They are a population that deserves to be served but unfortunately it is just not feasible for some of us to serve them and still make a living. For a small, single practitioner office, it just doesn‚Äôt work.

post_text:
Hello My Fellow Colleagues,

Is anyone out there seeing Medicare beneficiaries for wellness, fitness, prevention (WFP) for CASH? Anthony Maritato has some great YT vids on this, but I'm still looking for clarity.

1. I understand Medicare will cover maintenance if skilled care. Otherwise, are all WFP needs automatically defaulted as non-skilled and would never be covered by Medicare?
If non-covered, what's the point of an ABN? Other than purely a voluntary ABN to cover you maybe ?

2. Client wants help establishing a year long plan but wants/needs assessment. What's unclear to me is...let's say they have mobility issues, no pain. How do I assess shoulder dysfunction outside of a skilled care lens? Aren't I, as a DPT, examining shoulder mobility...as a DPT?? How do I know what will suit them best for a year long program and more if I don't eval and examine them (which, arguably, feels like a skilled function)?

3. Lastly, are there any restrictions/limitations on what I can charge for non-covered Medicare services since they still technically have power and authority over us and I'm not allowed to opt-out of their program like every other practitioner can?

Thank you for ANY info. 

Signed,
-Tried to get out of the cage, cage keeps dragging me back in.

comments.text:
I have several cash-pay clients that have been to and don't want any further "therapy."  They want a highly skilled personal trainer who can program and progress exercises for general strength, balance, etc in the presence of their chronic conditions.  They have confidence in me because of my medical background.
I also started a group fitness class for 55+, so am reaching more people and helping them reach their fitness/function goals with an evidence-based program.

1:  ABN not required for wellness services/non-covered services.
2:  You can bill eval to determine if there are further skilled needs or not.
3:  No restrictions on what you charge for non-covered services.  If you are not providing a skilled service, then Medicare does not have "power and authority" over you.

post_text:
Hey guys!

Have been in the group just kind of observing for a while. Appreciate all the information, hoping to someday get to where a lot of you all are! New to private practice and just in the beginning of my journey starting my biz. Was looking for clarification on laws/insurance guidelines, payment etc.

Do direct access laws, signed POC, progress notes, etc. only matter if billing insurance?

If you are billing insurance, is it a requirement to have referral, signed POC, 42 days direct access, CPT codes, etc? 

If you go beyond 90 days without signed POC, Or 42 days with direct access‚Ä¶.Can you get in trouble? I guess my question is are these ‚Äúlaws‚Äù when practicing PT that you could be held accountable for braking or insurance payer guidelines. Any and all feedback is appreciated! TIA.

comments.text:
You should follow your state guidelines even if you are cash-based.
So, if your state requires a signed POC, etc, then yes.
If billing insurance, yes.
If you go beyond 90 days, will you get in trouble? Uncertain.  If it‚Äôs 100 days (10 days late)I‚Äôm going to guess probably not.  If it‚Äôs 200 days, who knows.  Chances are that you just might not get reimbursed. 
Will you lose your license for not meeting deadlines? That depends on if it‚Äôs WAY past deadlines AND consistently so.  But you would possibly just be put on a probation of sorts. 
If you miss one deadline, you won‚Äôt be thrown in jail and have your dog shot

I think it‚Äôs unlikely many people will answer this question with ‚Äúfacts‚Äù that if you get in trouble from doing the things they said, you could point to this person who said you can do it. You should probably ask a lawyer or find a law in your state that says you can or can‚Äôt to protect yourself.

If you go beyond 90 days, will you get in trouble? Uncertain.  If it‚Äôs 100 days (10 days late)I‚Äôm going to guess probably not.  If it‚Äôs 200 days, who knows.  Chances are that you just might not get reimbursed. 
Will you lose your license for not meeting deadlines? That depends on if it‚Äôs WAY past deadlines AND consistently so.  But you would possibly just be put on a probation of sorts. 
If you miss one deadline, you won‚Äôt be thrown in jail and have your dog shot

post_text: We recently heard that another popular PT clinic (that is in-network with UHC) in our area is charging UHC patients $30 on top of in-network rates. Has anyone else heard of this practice / is this legal?

comments.text: If they are in network that means there is a contract in place. The contracts typically indicate that you accept the insurances payment as full payment of covered services regardless of what your normal rate is. If a service isn't covered, then that's a different story.

Let's play devils advocate for second. You charge these 30 dollars for dry needling/sports stretching a non covered service for the extra unit they don't want you to bill etc then how is that balance billing? Truth is UHC wants you to bill under 3-3.5 average units to stay preferred provider. They (big insurance) use lobbyist , loop holes to screw providers.if company see patient for 40 min for UHC 2-3 unit then provide a non skilled unit for an additional fee. That is agreed upon, then what's the issue? IMO go OON with ASh (Cigna) , UHC . However if we all do that then big box corporate stores win and further degrade the life of our #caged colleagues.

full_thread_text:
POST: We recently heard that another popular PT clinic (that is in-network with UHC) in our area is charging UHC patients $30 on top of in-network rates. Has anyone else heard of this practice / is this legal?

COMMENT 1: If they are in network that means there is a contract in place. The contracts typically indicate that you accept the insurances payment as full payment of covered services regardless of what your normal rate is. If a service isn't covered, then that's a different story.

COMMENT 2: Let's play devils advocate for second. You charge these 30 dollars for dry needling/sports stretching a non covered service for the extra unit they don't want you to bill etc then how is that balance billing? Truth is UHC wants you to bill under 3-3.5 average units to stay preferred provider. They (big insurance) use lobbyist , loop holes to screw providers.if company see patient for 40 min for UHC 2-3 unit then provide a non skilled unit for an additional fee. That is agreed upon, then what's the issue? IMO go OON with ASh (Cigna) , UHC . However if we all do that then big box corporate stores win and further degrade the life of our #caged colleagues.

post_text: Just starting my own practice. Currently waiting for the PLLC to be approved (in NY). Trying to get as much done in the meantime as possible. I'm sure I can't move forward with credentialing until I have the PLLC but as a startup does anyone have recommendations on a credentialing service vs doing it myself? Also wondering about a billing company and EMR. Thanks!

comments.text: It takes time to form PLLC (I did it too) compare to a PC. At this point I  would make sure you have your NPI and business NPI, try to register in PECOS system under your own NPI even if you don't have EIN number  for your business yet and proceed with PECOS Medicare  855B form to get the ball rolling if you plan to accept Medicare. I tried to pay someone to do credentialing for me and ended up doing a lot of it by myself.  It's expensive to pay someone and it can be very frustrating.  Most of the insurances have provider enrollment forms online and provider relations representative within a phone call reach. You can shoot me a PM with any questions, happy to help. In regards to an EMR, I personally use WebPT because it's very familiar to me and super easy, but Jane and HeNo have very pretty good reviews.
I hope you did an expedited process! The state is backlogged (estimate of 8-10 months) üòî

post_text:
So PT can‚Äôt accept cash from a Medicaid patient if they want more services but they can pay a diatician??    ü§°ü§°ü§°ü§°ü§°
Logic??

comments.text: Stupid law, but the whole point of Medicaid is financial assistance. If they can afford to private pay for any clinician, they probably need to get off Medicaid. At least, that's how the government sees it. I know it's more complicated than that.

If  Medicare is primary insurance and Medicaid secondary, you can not balance bill the patient if you are not a Medicaid provider. You have to follow Medicare billing rules for non covered services (ABN, still bill MC, etc) if what you provide is not covered by MC.
However, if your patient is not Medicare recipient and has only Medicaid, then ability to charge cash for PT is state specific. I am in Florida.I called and emailed to the Florida Medicaid and was told that I can collect cash for PT services if I am not a Medicaid provider.

full_thread_text:
POST: So PT can‚Äôt accept cash from a Medicaid patient if they want more services but they can pay a diatician??    ü§°ü§°ü§°ü§°ü§°
Logic??

COMMENT 1: Stupid law, but the whole point of Medicaid is financial assistance. If they can afford to private pay for any clinician, they probably need to get off Medicaid. At least, that's how the government sees it. I know it's more complicated than that.

COMMENT 2: If  Medicare is primary insurance and Medicaid secondary, you can not balance bill the patient if you are not a Medicaid provider. You have to follow Medicare billing rules for non covered services (ABN, still bill MC, etc) if what you provide is not covered by MC.
However, if your patient is not Medicare recipient and has only Medicaid, then ability to charge cash for PT is state specific. I am in Florida.I called and emailed to the Florida Medicaid and was told that I can collect cash for PT services if I am not a Medicaid provider.

post_text:
What are the rules if a potential patient has insurance/Medicare but other family
Members want to privately pay for the services?

comments.text: I know there are sticky issues with Medicare patients paying cash rates but if they have insurance and want to pay (or have someone else pay) cash rates, that shouldn‚Äôt be an issue

With a Medicare patient you are obligated to bill Medicare if you are providing physical therapy. The threshold of physical is low meaning it must be skilled, necessary and reasonable. Other things to consider is if the patient/client perceives that you're performing physical therapy and you think you're providing an uncovered service, then it's still physical therapy because they think it is physical therapy and you are held to a higher duty.

full_thread_text:
POST: What are the rules if a potential patient has insurance/Medicare but other family
Members want to privately pay for the services?

COMMENT 1: I know there are sticky issues with Medicare patients paying cash rates but if they have insurance and want to pay (or have someone else pay) cash rates, that shouldn‚Äôt be an issue

COMMENT 2: With a Medicare patient you are obligated to bill Medicare if you are providing physical therapy. The threshold of physical is low meaning it must be skilled, necessary and reasonable. Other things to consider is if the patient/client perceives that you're performing physical therapy and you think you're providing an uncovered service, then it's still physical therapy because they think it is physical therapy and you are held to a higher duty.

post_text: Question: I am a contract employee for a Pediatric Outpatient clinic. They are encouraging us to "bill an extra unit," for certain insurance companies after client's deductibles have been met. They are stating there is no additional cost to the consumer. They are advising us to use our clinical judgement as to whether or not the client would benefit from additional therapy. Our sessions are 45 minutes. Does anyone have any experience with this? I'm in Michigan where it's primarily Primary Health and BCBS. Thanks!

comments.text:
‚ÄúBilling an extra unit‚Äù wiithout an appropriate amount of extra billable time spent with the patient is fraud. Period.

Using your clinical judgement to see if they need more therapy is always a good idea. But just billing an extra unit and justifying it because the patient doesn‚Äôt pay is‚Ä¶ fraud.

In order to bill for the extra until you would need to treat the patient longer. If you treated for a longer duration then you should absolutely bill for that added unit. If not then you‚Äôre committing fraud

post_text: How does one go about finding out what the maximum units we can bill per insurance? Like I know Medicare is 4 units max a day/an hour. But what about other commercial insurances.

comments.text: You can bill all you want but they will only pay a certain amount. I'd say be ethical and bill enough to cover all you do . Some emr I have used allow units for 2 min with WC and some commercial so we'd end up with 6-7 units . I usually changed them and included the 2 min with something else bc I felt guilty . I've never billed more than 5 for an hour
Commercial insurances. Check your contract with them. They usually follow Medicare. But not all.

post_text:
Ok, confused ü´§ 
I have a young patient who has commercial insurance through his parents and Medicaid. I see this patient on a cash basis. The last treatment session his parents casually brought up the patient now has Medicare Part A. So my question is, since I‚Äôm strictly cash based and don‚Äôt file Medicare, do I release him as a patient? Or since he is only receiving Medicare part A am I still in the clear to see him as an outpatient? 
Such a slippery slope and I‚Äôm not trying try to play games with Medicare üòë

comments.text: You can‚Äôt charge a Medicare pt if you are a provider. If you are not you have no problems. In addition medicare part A only covers inpatient.

The Medicare A issue isn't a problem bc med A doesn't cover your services. I think it's also important to know that if it were any issues, then it's a matter of the patient's parent giving incorrect info on their intake paperwork and you'd adjust once you were made aware. You can't really be at fault when the info you need to be compliance was withheld from you. Make sure they know they'd be billed if lack of info caused you to be denied for services, but since you charge cash that's not an issue for you.

Medicare/Cash Based Question!  

**I tried searching through previous questions and haven't quite figured out my answer.**

I have a side cash-based only mobile PT clinic (my main business is animal PT).  I'm mainly only doing this side human PT gig so I can keep using my dry needling skills and help people with acute or chronic muscle spasms, hence the cash-based only.  So many people ask me for my services and I want to get paid for my time and needles vs giving treatment away for free (which happens a lot with family/friends).

I had a patient with Medicare contact me and she wants me to bill Medicare.  Since my business model is cash-based only, I do not need to see her, correct?  I know as PTs we can't opt out of Medicare, but if my business model does not incorporate Medicare or any other insurance, I can safely decline to see her provided I offer her other companies that accept Medicare?

Thank you in advance!

Pic for attention!

comments.text: i don't know the answer but would love to learn more about your animal PT biz
Yea not being able to opt out doesn't mean having to see patients if you don't want to

UPDATE: 

Just found out the payer has been sending payment to another PT group because the practitioner‚Äôs NPI is associated with that group as well (she works there prn). Has anyone encountered this?  I am at a loss for how to fix this.  

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

One of our cash-pay clients has been submitting self-claims for reimbursement.  His insurance is BCBS Federal.  He has yet to receive any reimbursement. post_text:
Huge billing success story with a HH agency overlap !!  

ManyÔøº of us have posted how when a home health agency overlaps us we are not paid for services.  After a year of negotiating we just got paid in this situation!!Ôøº. 

Backstory - as we all know under consolidated billing, a home health agency is responsible for all medical services for the patient under their episode.   ÔøºThis means Medicare is only paying one provider.  The agency trumps a therapy practice so per their regulations we don‚Äôt get paid.  There is the possibility to bill the agency for services provided, stating they are responsible for all skilled care, but I have never known them to pay because they honestly don‚Äôt have to.  

Ôøº In our situation we got paid due to our persistence.   ÔøºWe were already in on the patient and the agency admitted with knowledge that we were already seeing. They nor the patient gave notice to us that they had admitted.  Ôøº The patient had dementia, and family was not closely involved, so we really did not have a way to know.  Ôøº Because the agency knowingly admitted the patient creating the overlap, I sent them the regulation about our ability to bill them for the services, and their requirement to cover all skilled care. After a very long and drawn out negotiation, they actually paid it.  Ôøº Kudos to the agency for eventually doing the right thing.  

Ôøº I just wanted you to know there was hope for getting paid in this situation without having to involve attorneys or even Medicare!

comments.text: Unique circumstances on your side! Kudos to you!
Good for you!

post_text:
PROS & CONS?
I have an ALF that really wants me to be the go to MedB provider for them.  I know the residents well, and enjoy going in.  Most I would assume have Medicaid as supplement to Medicare, if not as primary.
I have not wanted to participate with Medicaid at this time, however, I do see it as an opportunity to work with this ALF and serve those residents.
If I saw these patients who have Medicare primary with Medicaid secondary, do I HAVE to see Medicaid patients at my clinic and mobile visits elsewhere?
Since I wouldn't be travelling much, more patients can be seen in a shorter time, is the difference in what Medicaid doesn't pay out worth it?
Any pros?

comments.text:
Used to do exactly this before starting my own business. 

It can be really profitable. Need to be sure to do due diligence in making sure (frequently) that home health is not seeing a patient. Otherwise, it‚Äôs similar to seeing Medicare patients in a bricks and mortar. Back to back scheduling, opportunity to screen and enroll more patients, etc.

Something to keep in mind is that many ALFs are a private pay type of living situation.  Medicaid is based on financial need.
So chances are, if they have enough money to live in an ALF, they probably don't qualify for Medicaid.

If it's not a true ALF, but more of a state funded group home, then yes, those residents probably have both Medicare and Medicaid.

Possible that they have/will sent paper checks and you are yet to receive. I would call and talk to the provider/claims department and get more info first and foremost to find out what‚Äôs going on. They are a big company and typically helpful via customer support. It will get sorted out.

Second, sounds like it may be worth your while to learn how to submit OON claims on behalf of your patients. It is a nice service to offer, very easy, and can probably increase your revenue long term and eliminate a lot of these headaches you describe.

full_thread_text:
POST: UPDATE: 

Just found out the payer has been sending payment to another PT group because the practitioner‚Äôs NPI is associated with that group as well (she works there prn). Has anyone encountered this?  I am at a loss for how to fix this.  

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

One of our cash-pay clients has been submitting self-claims for reimbursement.  His insurance is BCBS Federal.  He has yet to receive any reimbursement.  Today he was told by his insurance company that "because the NPI is on the superbill, payment was sent to the PT practice..." (it wasn't); and, "the PT practice will need to reimburse you for these funds and there's nothing else we can do for you."  Basically, they have told him (falsely) that we, the PT group, have been receiving reimbursement for his already-paid-for cash services.  Except we haven't received a dime!  It's so ridiculous that I don't know who to call in order to straighten it out.  Plus, I don't have time to be on the phone arguing this as a solo practitioner / owner.  Has anyone else dealt with this?  Honestly, every self-claim attempt my patients have made, regardless of payer, has led to some level of headache and frustration for both the patient, and for me.  It's maddening.  Any advice appreciated.

COMMENT 1: Have the patient ask for the check number and payment date.

COMMENT 2: Possible that they have/will sent paper checks and you are yet to receive. I would call and talk to the provider/claims department and get more info first and foremost to find out what‚Äôs going on. They are a big company and typically helpful via customer support. It will get sorted out.

Second, sounds like it may be worth your while to learn how to submit OON claims on behalf of your patients. It is a nice service to offer, very easy, and can probably increase your revenue long term and eliminate a lot of these headaches you describe.

post_text:
I just finished reading CashPT, got to the section on Medicare and it really confused me. If someone is paying cash how can Medicare stick their nose into the situation? If anyone has info for Indiana laws that‚Äôd be helpful. 

Just getting started, at the research and planning phase

comments.text:
Medicare has a mandatory claims submission rule for physical therapists, OT, and SLP. We cannot opt out as can physicians, etc. 

This doesn‚Äôt mean you can‚Äôt bill cash. If services are medically necessary then you should probably bill Medicare. If it‚Äôs wellness, fitness, training or the patient wants accountability for a HEP, etc that‚Äôs fair game
Yet there are people out there charging folks with Medicare cash for medically necessary care. And lawyers willing to charge you $1000+ to assist with this process. I'll never understand it.

post_text:
Hello everyone I asked question week ago about denial and seeing HHA as reason. That was a mistake. I went to NGS connex and the actual denial code is 040 which basically says price can‚Äôt go over allowed amount. But they‚Äôve always just paid Medicare amount anyways. Then I saw someone else‚Äôs post about deductible. Any idea how much this deductible is and I wonder if that‚Äôs why it wasn‚Äôt covered? Maybe it covered their deductible and that‚Äôs why all rest of the codes from that visit were paid but eval code wasn‚Äôt. 
Same with other patient who‚Äôs eval in December was covered by first 2 visits of this year were not.

comments.text: This is why I ALWAYS hold my billing on patients that don‚Äôt have supplements that cover their Part B deductibles. It‚Äôs definitely a growing/learning process. It took me 3 years to put the puzzle pieces together in Januarys. Now I wait until they‚Äôve been to the doctor/hospital/specialist and check to see if the aforementioned have sent their bills in. Once I know they have, then that other health provider is responsible for collecting the patient‚Äôs deductible. It‚Äôs a pain, but financially worth it in the end.

There is an annual deductible for Med B that resets each year. This year is $226 I believe. Many times the supplemental will pick it up. Sometimes not, which the patient would be responsible for. Some people will hold billing for January to allow for other outpatient services to occur in an effort to avoid this. In MA I‚Äôve seen most supplementals pick up the deductible.

post_text:
Taking part of my reply to someone else‚Äôs great question post. 
***
Why do people agree to pay cash to CAM specialists (Massage Therapists, Acupuncturists, Chiros, Personal Trainers) and Nutritionists and psychiatrists in Psychotherapists, yet fully expect insurance-based PT?

I think that the answer is somewhere in the following: 

PT as profession had a long journey to become recognized as a medical/healthcare field. Attaining medical recognition was a win and a loss. 

Today, two dfferent models of operation exist: 

Chiro + Personal Training + Massage = Wellness ~> Luxury: cash

PT = medical = necessity: insurance

Do we as PTs want to be associated with one or the other?

The answer is neither and both.
We need to carve a new model. And carving something new is‚Ä¶ hard.

Maybe the answer is to change the Wellness to Wellbeing in branding? Or Wellbeing and Whole Health?

Like .. ‚ÄúWellbeing in Function and Whole in Health PT?‚Äù

Dunno.

I am in the very beginning of thinking about my own practice, associated with an unexpected but a welcome move. 

I will be planning and carving, drafting and re-writing things. 

One thing that I will be doing from the very start is to brand my practice as the place where clients start to feel better about themselves and about the things they do for the living, for recreation, for fun and - for functional mobility. 

Because the whip of insurance-based PT is the mere functional gain. Our society insurance-based model is to pay for the person not to die, the rest is secondary.

I want people to be more than functional.  Beyond functional. 

Like‚Ä¶ hurt by personal training -> seek Beyond Functional PT to return to sport.
‚Ä¶ not responding to acupuncture 
-> seek Beyond Functional PT to relieve pain.

Not long time ago Massage Therapists started being recognized as professionals and not a subsidy of sex work industry.  Just 15 years ago I was asked by a client in a well-respected upscale spa if we do happy ending (I came to PT from being a LMT first). 

Somehow Massage Therapists are not recognized by Insurance as providers of medically necessary therapy (even though regular therapeutic massage greatly relives stress on par with Psychotherapy covered by insurance). 

We as a whole profession need a break from medical necessity equating negligent pay.  

And just maybe APTA need to step up too. But it‚Äôs a subject for the next rant.

Thanks for your attention.

comments.text:
I appreciate your rant. I do think there are a lot of people that (probably wrongly) associated cash pay with luxury and I think there is also that challenge of meeting undeserved patients that may not be able to access cash based care without insurance. 

Where I live there is a bit of a challenge convincing the masses that good health and wellness is an investment and figuring out where that lives in their priorities.

Excellent post and viewpoint. I am 100% in agreement with your point regarding whole health branding for improved functioning. I would love to continue this conversation among all of us therapists on this platform.

post_text: Hey all, I have a question regarding super bill codes for in-home outpatient therapy. Apparently my patient's insurance has been reimbursing for "home health." I'm not sure if this is because I used Point of Service code 12 for "home." Is there a different type of coding I should use to indicate to the insurance company that this is outpatient therapy that happens to be taking place in the home (or should I just omit the POS code all together)? I really value this client and want to help him get the proper reimbursement from his insurance co. TIA for any help, guidance, or direction you can provide!

comments.text: POS 11 = Office. Some carriers only see 12 as HH. They advise to use 11 as mobile many times. You just need to ask not using "mobile" or "home". POS 12 PT. They need to look it up actually typing in the codes to see if covered. Otherwise they assume.

I use code 12 for my billing for outpatient in the home. I think it depends on the insurance company, I would call the company or have the patient call the claims different and see if you can get an answer. Hope that helps.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey all, I have a question regarding super bill codes for in-home outpatient therapy. Apparently my patient's insurance has been reimbursing for "home health." I'm not sure if this is because I used Point of Service code 12 for "home." Is there a different type of coding I should use to indicate to the insurance company that this is outpatient therapy that happens to be taking place in the home (or should I just omit the POS code all together)? I really value this client and want to help him get the proper reimbursement from his insurance co. TIA for any help, guidance, or direction you can provide!

COMMENT 1: POS 11 = Office. Some carriers only see 12 as HH. They advise to use 11 as mobile many times. You just need to ask not using "mobile" or "home". POS 12 PT. They need to look it up actually typing in the codes to see if covered. Otherwise they assume.

COMMENT 2: I use code 12 for my billing for outpatient in the home. I think it depends on the insurance company, I would call the company or have the patient call the claims different and see if you can get an answer. Hope that helps.

post_text:
Is it crazy to specialize in geriatrics if I want to do cash-based mobile services? 

(City with a population of 110,000). Background: I love working in Parkinson‚Äôs and have a lot of experience/training there. But those folks will nearly always qualify for maintenance, therefore, Medicare billing, right?

comments.text:
I disagree with "nearly always qualify for maintenance." My practice is young, so take this with a grain of salt. I have had some luck graduating patients from formal PT into a cash/wellness program once they no longer meet restorative PT or maintenance PT eligibility.

Maintenance is also typically a very low frequency. Once weekly or less. I haven't had luck with this yet but hope to build up a roster of hybrid peeps where MCR pays for once weekly maintenance visit but then they pay cash for extra visits to up their frequency to 2-3x/week.

It sounds like the challenge would be lead finding. If you accept Medicare you could generate your own leads, but then you have to bite the Medicare bullet. Just my 2 cents.

Be very clear on what is therapy and what isn‚Äôt. That should help clarify everything.
A lot with PD have Medicare and will want to use that most likely. Just all how you market your services

post_text: I feel like I should know this already, but I don‚Äôt and I don‚Äôt know where to look for answers, so im reaching out to this group. I‚Äôve done HH for 10+ years. All insurance based. All my experience with documentation is based on keeping insurance companies and my employer satisfied and checking off all their boxes. Well now I‚Äôm starting my own self-pay mobile outpatient practice, and I just don‚Äôt know how much documentation is actually required. Do I need ICD-10 codes on every note? Do I need CPT codes (I assume I do if I‚Äôm giving the patient a superbill)? How long can I write a plan of care for? 4 weeks? 10 weeks? Are formal reassessments required, and if so, how often? I‚Äôve tried looking up information in my state practice act, but it seems to only cover licensure requirements for the most part. I want to ensure I am fully compliant with my licensure while not over-documenting (which is what I feel I‚Äôve done all these years in HH). Thanks for your input!

comments.text: I‚Äôm in the same situation. Working for HH way too long now. HH charges Medicare A. Regulations are very different than outpatient services which bill Medicare part B. The paperwork in HH is becoming ridiculous. I‚Äôd like to learn what is required to begin an outpatient PT practice as well (because I have not worked in an outpatient setting for 16 years and I‚Äôm sure things have changed‚Ä¶ ) especially to cover Medicare requirements to accept Medicare Part B. Where is a good place to start for someone opening a mobile practice these days?

Well my guess is that all the things you‚Äôve been doing for 10 years were required so that you get re-imbursed. And if you get sued you need to CYA. So as far as documentation goes I would mimic what you have always done. To me the perks of f being self employed are in your freedom to pick and choose who you serve, when and where you work. If you give super bills and your clients can‚Äôt be reimbursed because of shoddy documentation then it could come back to bite you. You have to decide what type of reputation you want. If repeat business or referrals are not a concern then you can do what you want.

post_text:
Jan 2023 I will be uncaged PT Hallelujah!   
Question: pt calls & ask do you take insurance?
I know my first response doesn‚Äôt need to be ‚ÄúNo but I‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Äù 
So give me your 1st couple of sentence response to this question that makes them not hear NO
Thanks in advance just trying to work on my marketing skills

comments.text:
I‚Äôm real blunt, I just say ‚Äúnope, I don‚Äôt contract with any insurance companies, I just exchange services for a flat fee payment,‚Äù and let it sit. I feel like right out of the gate that demonstrates the simplicity and transparency of the business model, which is one of the biggest upsides. It also can remind them that that is how most other business operate, and reinforces that that is entirely reasonable. Then I gauge it from there based on their response.  Sometimes I bring up super bills and HSA/FSA, sometimes I basically say ‚ÄúI am out of network for multiple reasons‚Äù which opens a door for them to ask why, and I can explain the benefits of the business model a bit. Sometimes I say ‚Äúout of network care can be more or less cost effective depending on your coverage and issue‚Äù and I‚Äôll follow with asking if they have stellar or poor coverage/copays if they‚Äôre post op or non op etc. which gives them a chance to tell me what‚Äôs going on and build rapport. I truly don‚Äôt try and sell every call, I openly tell folks when i think in network is the move if I feel they‚Äôll benefit from frequent shorter visits and have great coverage, and when low cost is a massive priority for them.

Generally when I drop that first line and leave it, they‚Äôll have some questions that will demonstrate sticking points if they have any. Ultimately most are just asking that because they think that‚Äôs how you‚Äôre supposed to shop for healthcare, not because they‚Äôre sold on going in network. Usually they‚Äôre calling because they want to tell someone their problem, so I try and get us to that point without shoehorning the convo in any particular direction. 

But, I also am not one that likes to haggle or do a lot of convincing. I don‚Äôt want a patient on my books that I have to fight to get scheduled because they don‚Äôt want to prioritize paying for care or can‚Äôt pay for care. If they truly can only afford me once every three weeks, have a ten dollar copay with deductibles met, they honestly may be better served in network anyhow, so I take the L, offer to help them find someone else, and don‚Äôt sweat it. 

That‚Äôs my approach. May not be the best from a brute sales perspective, but it fits my personality well and is authentic to me, so it works!

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs great to talk to you! I‚Äôm not in network with any insurance companies, but I‚Äôm happy to provide a super bill, which is basically just an invoice for each visit that you can submit to your insurance for potential partial reimbursement.‚Äù

post_text:
Hi! Appreciate any insight...

My business uses a combo of mobile PT and treating in my clinic, which is attached to our home. I've been strictly cash based but am considering credentialing with Medicare. I've tried to research but haven't seen a clear answer
1. My understanding is that when applying to get credentialed, I could use my home address IF I were solely a mobile PT... but because my business also includes a clinic attached to my home, I can't**.** Is this correct?

 2. If that is correct, is there a way of applying for credentialing for only **MC mobile visits** but still be able to treat NON-MC clients at my home clinic? Or do I have to switch my business to 100% mobile and/or a separate physical location in order to get apply for credentialing? 

Thanks in advance for any input!

comments.text:
You can do either or both. 

You can use your home address for mobile as well as treating Medicare patients in your homes They would prob just want to do a site visit to confirm is a real place. 

If you wanted to just do mobile for Medicare but not in your home, I believe you should be able to select mobile only.
Check out Anthony Maritato's Medicare Billing group

full_thread_text:

Thanks in advance for any input!

COMMENT 1: You can do either or both.

post_text: If you are in network with Medicare and bill Medicare B for reimbursement it's my understanding they will pay 80%. The other 20% of the cost can be covered by the patients secondary insurance. Do you have to be in network with the secondary insurance also? How does that work? Any help would be appreciated!

comments.text:
No.

If you bill Medicare and the claim is approved they will automatically forward the claim to the patients secondary insurance (as applicable) and you will be paid at Medicare rate for the other 20%.

Some secondary insurances still have a co-pay. Rare but I‚Äôve seen up to $15.

If they have a supplement it will pay pretty much regardless I think but secondary insurance will sometimes require you to be in network so the patient may be responsible for the extra. You can call them to find out

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: No.

COMMENT 2: If they have a supplement it will pay pretty much regardless I think but secondary insurance will sometimes require you to be in network so the patient may be responsible for the extra. You can call them to find out

If a therapist works as independent contractor for a home health agency and patient needs services after discharge from all med A services. Are you allowed to offer cash based tx or outpatient services if patient wants to continue services with same therapist? 

Does the therapist need LLC and separate NPI to provide any such service? 

What would be good reference to justify service with no conflict of interest? 

I am very new to uncaged part of the world and I am still in learning process. I would appreciate some guidance or pointers to right reference.

TIA

comments.text: I don‚Äôt see why there would be a conflict. With that being said many CHHAs also have a sister company providing part b . Aside from that you need to be credentialed with Medicare in order to bill or if you are not cash is better.ü§£üò¨
Discharge from Med A would/should move to Med B (outpatient), cash services would only be appropriate for after Med B services are provided.

post_text: Hi! We are Medicare Part B provider. There is a home care agency who is referring a pt, but has commercial insurance. comments.text: I believe what they are suggesting is that you contract for them. You would be seeing the patient, they would be billing insurance and pay you whatever is agreed upon. They likely don't have anyone available to see the patient.

I‚Äôm getting discouraged because the local marketing I‚Äôve done and will continue to do will be geared towards seniors, the clientele I like to work with. post_text:
Question: 
I have a client who has met all functional goals & was able to perform their training they were preparing for‚ÄîI progressed them to the point where they were able to perform combatives and carry a holster without reported back pain. His insurance authorized 6 more PT sessions despite me stating in my note that all functional goals have been met. We had the discussion that it may not be medically necessary as he was able to achieve his goals. He then responds with ‚Äúbut I do have pain when I sit‚Ä¶‚Äù ..this was after he ran to my clinic and stated feeling ‚Äúmore stable‚Äù. 

I‚Äôm conflicted. I don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs medically necessary and feel that it‚Äôs unethical to see him at this point despite insurance approving him for more and am concerned he is coming in for a ‚Äúworkout ‚Äú which is clearly not covered by insurance. 

Help!

comments.text:
Maybe shift your focus.  Performing activities pain free maybe a new goal. 
Ask the patient why he thinks PT is  still beneficial.  
Small steps toward progress is still progress. 
Look at the whole person.  He sees value is the services provided‚Ä¶ insurance sees value‚Ä¶ why?

Insurance can always go back and audit the notes and if they deemed you provided services that are not skilled they can ask you for the money back. Billing insurance without medical need is also considered abuse . If your patient needs treat him but many patients think about PT as a work out as you mentioned already.

I‚Äôm conflicted. I don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs medically necessary and feel that it‚Äôs unethical to see him at this point despite insurance approving him for more and am concerned he is coming in for a ‚Äúworkout ‚Äú which is clearly not covered by insurance. 

Help!

COMMENT 1: Maybe shift your focus.  Performing activities pain free maybe a new goal. 
Ask the patient why he thinks PT is  still beneficial.  
Small steps toward progress is still progress. 
Look at the whole person.  He sees value is the services provided‚Ä¶ insurance sees value‚Ä¶ why?

COMMENT 2: Insurance can always go back and audit the notes and if they deemed you provided services that are not skilled they can ask you for the money back. Billing insurance without medical need is also considered abuse . If your patient needs treat him but many patients think about PT as a work out as you mentioned already.

If seeing a patient multiple times in a week (or month), can you combine all visits into 1 superbill, or should there be a separate superbill for each visit?

comments.text:

I will often bill multiple patient visits at the same time and my billing software automatically combines these dates of service onto the same form.

post_text: Quick question, if a person is on Medicare A, am I not allowed to provided ‚Äùskilled services,‚Äù or is that just Medicare B?

comments.text:
Medicare Part A hospital insurance covers inpatient hospital care, skilled nursing facility, hospice, lab tests, surgery, home health care.

What Part B covers

Medicare Part B (Medical Insurance) covers, including doctor and other health care providers' services and outpatient care. Part B also covers durable medical equipment, home health care, and some preventive services
If a patient is currently receiving Part A services (or hasn‚Äôt been officially discharged) you cannot perform Part B services.

full_thread_text:
POST: Quick question, if a person is on Medicare A, am I not allowed to provided ‚Äùskilled services,‚Äù or is that just Medicare B?

COMMENT 1: Medicare Part A hospital insurance covers inpatient hospital care, skilled nursing facility, hospice, lab tests, surgery, home health care.

What Part B covers

Medicare Part B (Medical Insurance) covers, including doctor and other health care providers' services and outpatient care. Part B also covers durable medical equipment, home health care, and some preventive services

COMMENT 2: If a patient is currently receiving Part A services (or hasn‚Äôt been officially discharged) you cannot perform Part B services.

post_text:
Another question 

I‚Äôm confused about Medicare. 

I know our individual NPI is ours forever. I‚Äôve been asked for my NPI for the superbills I‚Äôve given out. 

Should I enroll with Medicare? I know I can‚Äôt legally treat them for physical therapy cash based, but we CAN do wellness visits cash for Medicare patients. 

Is it worth it ? Some colleagues say no. Some say yes. Right now I don‚Äôt have any Medicare patients at my doorstep. 

But if I wanted to enroll, as a sole proprietorship do i still need a business NPI?  UPDATE. SOLE PROPRIETORSHIP IS NOT ELIGIBLE FOR AN ORGANIZATIONAL NPI.  FOR ANY WHO IS INTERESTED OR IN SAME POSITION AS ME.  YOU USE YOUR INDIVIDUAL NPI UNTIL YOURE READY FOR PLLC OR PC. 

I don‚Äôt understand the process.  

Idk if it matters but with my NPI under my old employer, I was fully credentialed with all insurances‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.idk if giving my NPI on the superbill is going to affect that????

comments.text: I treat Medicare and it has been great. Really haven‚Äôt had any issues with billing and are a good payer in my opinion. I think it depends on who you are targeting and the people you want to work with. There is a large older adult population where I am in NJ and only got contracted with original Medicare. I use both my individual NPI and business NPI for submitting claims. Let me know if you have any other questions and if I can help in any other way.

You still should have a business NPI. 
I‚Äôm hybrid and find it easier to sell to Medicare clients. The reimbursement is less per visit than my cash based patients but it‚Äôs a nice stream of revenue. Plus I do transition quite a few of my Medicare clients to wellness. It‚Äôs give you an opportunity to get you foot in the door and they see how you operate. It‚Äôs an easier sell for wellness once they see what you are about and what you can do for them.

post_text:
Hello all, 
I‚Äôm wondering if anyone can answer a couple questions for me.  I just started taking Medicare patients. (I feel like I sold my soul to the devil). Got some questions about coding.  I went cross-eyed trying to find the answers yesterday.  With regard to G codes, does Medicare still require those?

I also have questions about the 59 code and the new X codes I‚Äôve been reading about.  I tend to bill 97112, 97110, and 97140 together quite a bit.  Does anybody know if that combination requires any of those codes? 

Lastly, I don‚Äôt understand the proper use of the ‚ÄúGP‚Äù code. Can anybody clarify that for me too? Thank you.

I have downloaded over 100 pages of Medicare billing manual. But I‚Äôm really struggling to find that information.  Thanks again.

comments.text: No G codes anymore thankfully. GP modifier is added to all codes (performed by a PT). 59 is only needed with certain codes to essentially confirm that they were separate procedures and not performed concurrently. You'll want to look at the list for all of those combos. For example, I treat vestibular patients, so I use a 59 when billing a repositioning maneuver and Neuro re-ed in same visit.
G codes are no longer a thing!   I would totally recommend hitting up Anthony Maritato and his courses zero to paid!  Or do a lot of googling!

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello all, 
I‚Äôm wondering if anyone can answer a couple questions for me.  I just started taking Medicare patients. (I feel like I sold my soul to the devil). Got some questions about coding.  I went cross-eyed trying to find the answers yesterday.  With regard to G codes, does Medicare still require those?

I also have questions about the 59 code and the new X codes I‚Äôve been reading about.  I tend to bill 97112, 97110, and 97140 together quite a bit.  Does anybody know if that combination requires any of those codes? 

Lastly, I don‚Äôt understand the proper use of the ‚ÄúGP‚Äù code. Can anybody clarify that for me too? Thank you.

I have downloaded over 100 pages of Medicare billing manual. But I‚Äôm really struggling to find that information.  Thanks again.

COMMENT 1: No G codes anymore thankfully. GP modifier is added to all codes (performed by a PT). 59 is only needed with certain codes to essentially confirm that they were separate procedures and not performed concurrently. You'll want to look at the list for all of those combos. For example, I treat vestibular patients, so I use a 59 when billing a repositioning maneuver and Neuro re-ed in same visit.

COMMENT 2: G codes are no longer a thing!   I would totally recommend hitting up Anthony Maritato and his courses zero to paid!  Or do a lot of googling!

post_text: Hi all, I've tried to search the group, but can't find this answer...I am enrolled with Medicare, and out of network with Priority Health in Michigan.  I have a potential patient who has a Priority Health Medicare plan. If Priority Health has stated that I cannot enroll as a preferred provider, but I'm enrolled with Medicare, do I try to bill this patient through Priority Health?  I know I can't bill a Medicare patient cash for a service that would be covered, so not certain what to do in this situation.

comments.text: I have a patient I'm starting tomorrow with a Priority Health Medicare Advantage PPO plan in MI. I had to get preauthorization for it which took about a week. I filled it out as OON but when I got the Auth back they said they would bill as IN. The OON for them was a 40% coins, no ded. I'm still trying to call and talk to someone to see what the IN benefits are now that they said I can bill IN

You can call and verify benefits directly with priority health. If they have out of network benefits you can send the claims and priority health will let you know what amount the patient is responsible for.

Hey all, quick question. I just spoke to a potential client who asked me a question I didn‚Äôt know the answer to. I‚Äôm cash based but will give clients a superbill for them to seek reimbursement. She was told by her insurance company that she needs to do PT first before an MRI is approved for them to check out a potential cyst on her hip. She asked me how does she prove to them that she did the PT with me(being that I‚Äôm not getting auth or submitting claims to them?) Do I just give her my notes and have her submit them to her insurance company?
She is not concerned really with reimbursement, she just wants to have the imaging done to rule out something more serious. 
Has anyone encountered this as cash based?

comments.text: I've created a superbill and a signed letterhead note written to their physician stating rationale for mri. Like David said, the patient should be able to call their insurance to find out exactly what information is needed that you can then provide them.
Best to just call the insurance company to ask. Probably some kind of note with a letterhead or medical records from you

post_text: I told myself I wouldn't do insurance cause I wanted to be cash only but I see elders. So I am now a Medicare provider. No more insurance though...but now I have a referral source (only took a year but I got it!) but the majority of their patients have advantage plans and with so little business yet, it's hard to turn a patient down. Does anyone here have experience with Aetna Advantra Silver HMO? Curious if reimbursement rates are worth contracting with them for their HMO has no OON benefits and these patient's can't afford private pay. Not don't want to pay, they can't pay.

comments.text: I would ask Aetna directly. Being out of network with Aetna, I have had some clients where I have been reimbursed just about exactly according to the Medicare fee schedule.

Aetna fee schedule is typically 25-30% less than Medicare fee schedule per visit in my experience. Not worth it for me personally although I don‚Äôt know the specific plan.

Many advantage plan HMOs have a co-pay in the area of 25-30/ visit as well. Really quite awful plans overall for rehab purposes.

Also, icing on the cake, Aetna contracts are notoriously hard get due to capping number of providers per geographical region.

post_text: Anyone running a cash based clinic for geriatric clients (Medicare beneficiaries), how do you notify your clients with Medicare that you can‚Äôt provide PT? Do you charge less for wellness sessions or keep the flat rate? Can this even work? I go back and forth in my head thinking it can and then that it can‚Äôt‚Ä¶in need of some help here. I love working with seniors, really anyone over 50, and really want to make this work. Want to be able to provide PT to non Medicare beneficiaries but know most will be üòñ

comments.text:
Heather Reichenau nope! I know it sounds funny but that's what I meant. I truly believe that the results for which many older adults are looking, require a focus on wellness sessions which help to establish a lifestyle change. Those results are not possible in your typical therapy POC...which is why so many just continuously go through the cycle of immobility after discharge from skilled care, never reaching their goals. Educating medical providers, families, and most importantly patients about these legal cash pay services is the future. One by one we can change the lives of so many. 

To add to this, which may sound even crazier, the quality of care with the insurance based model has gone so far down, that patients don't even want it. But anything medically necessary has to go by the rules.

It is very tricky because if you treat a Medicare beneficiary and falls under the realm of skilled PT you cannot accept cash.

I work a lot with the geriatric population as well I was really hesitant about having to deal with insurance. But I did go ahead and enroll with Medicare and  they paid very quickly on my first client.
Their rules are actually quite simple and as long as you follow all of the documentation and CMS requirements you should be fine.
When you add Medicare and the secondary it was about $105 a visit.
You can always add non covered services to the mix that are not covered by Medicare but you'll have to be very upfront with your patients so they understand what constitutes a covered and non-covered service under Medicare

There is a shortage of PTs and PTAs, can I hire an athlete trainer, pilates instructor and Bill it under thera ex? I know with medicare that is unacceptable but can I do that with BCBS, Aetna? Humana? United health care?

I'm 46 yrs old, when did it change? Back in the days a massage therapist would do the exercise or massage since the PT had a patient every 30 minutes?

I'm a lymphedema and pelvic therapist now so I always get 1 hr one on one time so I was not aware of the changes

comments.text:
I realize this is a legitimate question so I hope my answer is well received. 
Please do not hire and bill therapy procedures for an individual who is not a licensed and qualified PT or PTA. In the past I fought long and hard to keep said skilled services under the ‚ÄúPT only‚Äù domaine.  
Thank you.
If you are billing for skilled PT, that means a licensed PT or PTA.

post_text:
Do you worry about medically necessary when seeing a cash patient?
Say I am out of network with patient‚Äôs insurance. I have a doctors order, and I am providing a skilled service. 
Patient is a young man who has a diagnosis that makes him have muscle cramps and pain.  Mom refuses to place him in pain meds. They tried massage, stretches, etc. he has a hep, stretch program and is very compliant. But it is not enough. Md suggested pain medication, muscle relaxers, but mother is set on avoiding drugs. They like that after my treatments he is pain free for up to 1 week (used to be 2 weeks until he relapsed 3-4 mo ago). I give superbill and insurance has been paying them faithfully but it makes me anxious that we‚Äôve been doing this for almost a year. 
If tomorrow insurance decides all this therapy was not medically necessary because maybe pain meds were cheaper or whatever‚Ä¶ am I liable? Even though I did not submit anything to insurance ? (Tricare)

comments.text: My son is similar. What we have to do, unfortunately, is stop about once a year for a few months to show regression. As a mom, I wouldn't allow pain meds either. You just need more in my opinion. Sounds like your patient is showing regression when you aren't treating. That, along with needed skill, I wouldn't worry about it. My son won't make progress (most likely) but we are preventing "scissoring" from muscle contractures/scoliosis.

Tricare is fabulous insurance. As a recipient and also having a ton of Tricare patients I‚Äôve never experienced a denial or needed to submit a note. If you are helping him with his pain and living a better life- it‚Äôs skilled.

post_text: Question.. when you're credentialing with an insurance as the sole proprietor of your business do you have to credential the business/ group and yourself as an individual provider as well? Or just the credential the business since you'll be submitting claims through the business NPI and TAX ID? TIA

comments.text: It seems to vary by insurance. But I would always do group if possible because if you do add someone down the road, it will be easier to credential them with your group as well.

Why sole proprietor? LLC or PC would offer less risk against your personal property. Anyways, back to your question. As a sole proprietor, you are the business, so credentialing the business or vice versa is the same as credentialing you.

full_thread_text:
POST: Question.. when you're credentialing with an insurance as the sole proprietor of your business do you have to credential the business/ group and yourself as an individual provider as well? Or just the credential the business since you'll be submitting claims through the business NPI and TAX ID? TIA

COMMENT 1: It seems to vary by insurance. But I would always do group if possible because if you do add someone down the road, it will be easier to credential them with your group as well.

COMMENT 2: Why sole proprietor? LLC or PC would offer less risk against your personal property. Anyways, back to your question. As a sole proprietor, you are the business, so credentialing the business or vice versa is the same as credentialing you.

post_text: One of the things that may scare me out of trying to start my own business is the cost of health insurance. I will have to have health insurance for myself, my wife and hopefully for children in the near future. Is there anyone who has been there and done it? I‚Äôve heard cost of purchasing insurance in the marketplace is insanely expensive which makes me question if it‚Äôs all worth it?

comments.text: We use CHM (Christian Healthshare Ministries) ‚Ä¶similar to Medishare that was mentioned above. We‚Äôre a family of four and have no complaints so far.

We use Zion Health share plan and have a Health Matching Account for health related expenses. It costs me $500 less per month than my employer sponsored health insurance through Humana last year. And $300 of the total that I pay per month is going into my HMA which I can actually USE instead of paying all that extra money to then have to meet a deductible. We are a healthy family of 4 with no major health problems or concerns. It was a little hard this year because we just started this plan and didn‚Äôt have much saved in the HMA yet. But going forward I feel like the HMA will cover the small expenses and then Zion will cover anything over $1000 per need.

post_text: For the folks in mobile med b and cash only mobile practice, do you plan on adding some insurances to fill your case load‚Ä¶do any other insurance reimburse for mobile services other than med B or have a higher reimbursement rate and are worth getting credentialled for a solo mobile physical therapy practice‚Ä¶sorry for a dumb question.. I will be practicing in northwest Indiana

comments.text:
The headaches of dealing with insurance companies was one of the main reasons I started my own practice.
Medicare is so easy to work with.  The private insurance companies require lots of extra paperwork, all while breathing down your neck‚Ä¶ not to mention the difficulty of getting accurate information when you call and speak with a rep.
As a solo provider, it‚Äôs not worth the extra time/effort (in my opinion).

To help me make this decision, I did research in my area in regards to the payer mix. For an example 98% of the population have insurance, Medicare and BCBS of GA at that. I had to also consider my niche population (Lymphedema and Geriatrics) which requires frequent episodes of therapy care which can add up if cash pay. Another factor was the economic status of patients.  Taking into consideration the people I will serve and my area, insurance contracting was a no brainer. However there is opportunity for me to partake in the 2% cash pay population in the form of offering Wellness Services

I will be practicing in northwest Indiana

post_text:
Question for those who take PI cases where you bill the insurance company directly.

I have a client for PI that we would be billing State Farm directly for. We do have a prompt pay discount rate as well as a fee schedule that we bill to Medicare ($100/code for simplicity). The client has $15k in PIP and is seeing her primary care and received medications already. I don't necessarily need to make my actual fee schedule and eat through her PIP, but I also don't want to bill out my prompt pay rate when we will be waiting on payment for months. She does not have an attorney involved. 

My concern is if we bill out our rate of $4-500 a visit that we bill Medicare/out of network, is State Farm actually going to pay that or will they negotiate it down? Thanks!

comments.text: they will pay what is reasonable and customary until PIP is exhausted.  but get your Bill's in quick, that money is there to share with all medical providers (docs, ambulance, hospital etc)

Depends on state rules, in FL pip is 10k once your over that you will need to go after the PI portion with all the other healthcare providers. Billing your max but reimbursement depends how much they get could 20-50%of your billed charges once the case is settled. Sometime you won‚Äôt see anything

full_thread_text:
POST: Question for those who take PI cases where you bill the insurance company directly.

I have a client for PI that we would be billing State Farm directly for. We do have a prompt pay discount rate as well as a fee schedule that we bill to Medicare ($100/code for simplicity). The client has $15k in PIP and is seeing her primary care and received medications already. I don't necessarily need to make my actual fee schedule and eat through her PIP, but I also don't want to bill out my prompt pay rate when we will be waiting on payment for months. She does not have an attorney involved. 

My concern is if we bill out our rate of $4-500 a visit that we bill Medicare/out of network, is State Farm actually going to pay that or will they negotiate it down? Thanks!

COMMENT 1: they will pay what is reasonable and customary until PIP is exhausted.  but get your Bill's in quick, that money is there to share with all medical providers (docs, ambulance, hospital etc)

COMMENT 2: Depends on state rules, in FL pip is 10k once your over that you will need to go after the PI portion with all the other healthcare providers. Billing your max but reimbursement depends how much they get could 20-50%of your billed charges once the case is settled. Sometime you won‚Äôt see anything

post_text:
I have a question about OON billing...I apologize for the length of the post but I am incredibly frustrated and I would greatly appreciate any advice!

I've been billing OON with EmblemHealth and UnitedHealthcare for 2 different patients. EmblemHealth began denying all claims after patient met their OON deductible (how convenient...). I've called several times, long story short it's been a mess, they say it was all an error on their end(denied stating I already billed for those services that day which just is not correct and they acknowledge that), and they keep just resubmitting them for review, they get the same error, and repeat. It is significantly delaying payment to me.

For UnitedHealthcare, I had to get prior authorization with Optum physical health through this "Voluntary Prior Approval" process. I took the time to do that (a lot of time since they approve 1-4 visits at a time) and I was told I wouldn't have to submit medical records. I submitted claims for all of the appointments that were approved with the approval number. They only approved 2 claims (sent both checks to the patient even though they told me if they assign benefits to me and I accept assignment it would go to me, both are not cashed and the patient says she never received them.). UHC denied one of the claims stating they asked for medical records and I didnt respond so it is denied. The other 5 were sent to Optum Insight for review and they are still processing until they recieve medical records from me. I never recieved any letters asking for documentation. I call and they say oh it looks like a completely different provider info is on the claims and sent to X address (which isnt mine), someone really messed something up here. However, on the patient's portal my name and NPI are associated with all of the claims...They essentially said they can't do anything about it, I have to wait until they are denied within 30 days of not receiving records (some are past that timeframe already!), then resubmit the claims and hope they dont screw it up again...this is completely unacceptable.

Is this something to bring up to the State department? UHC owes me $9100 and Emblem hasn't paid anything since May...Safe to say I am only giving superbills from now on...it doesn't matter how large their fee schedule is if they will not pay you and require as much admin work as in network!

comments.text: yep.  send it all to your state insurance commissioner.  this has got to end.  noone should have to spend thatch time and waste just to get paid an amount they already approved.
Wow that is awful it is my biggest fear of seeing patients in general and dealing with insurance. I'd like to hear input on this as well!

post_text: Today my patient had a genius idea!!! Insurance companies give their patients a set amount (say 10) PT sessions each year. They can be for a problem or preventative like ergonomics!!! In the end they would pay less for meds and surgery!

comments.text:
One of the main reasons our healthcare system is as broke as it is is because of how frequently people change insurance providers. Because of this, insurance companies see preventative healthcare as lining the pockets of their competitors. 

To market this, you would want to pursue a large corporation (the pull with insurance companies) that has an abnormally low degree of employee turnover (benefit from keeping employees healthy).

There is a company named Centene. They actually bought a medium size company that specialized in doctor visits at home and used it to prevent hospitalizations and save money. A managed system like that would be the company to pitch it to.

post_text: Does therapeutic Activity have to be one on one and 15min?

comments.text: No. You can bill a unit at 8 minutes. Medicare only pays for direct one on one care. That does not mean 8 minutes uninterrupted.  You have to consider the entire treatment time and adjust accordingly per Medicare guidelines

#Compliance #CPT97530 #TherapeuticActivities 

CPT¬Æ 97530

....By the book is correct: "Therapeutic activities, direct (one-on-one) patient contact (use of dynamic activities to improve functional performance), each 15 minutes"    

....edited: Per AMA time is achieved when the mid-point is passed. 

.....How time is calculated for the purpose of billing is a matter of payer policy. 

[CPT is a registered trademark of the AMA]

post_text: What factors do you consider whether to do OON billing for patients vs giving them superbill/reimbursify? Obviously doing it for them is more work. Anyone have any insight (especially if you have done both)?

comments.text:
I do OON billing when:
They have OON benefits with low deductible (<$2500 - arbitrary based on typical POC for my patients) or have already met their deductible AND high reimbursement rates (UCR based fee schedule)
I give a Superbill to people who have OON benefits with high deductible (>$2500) or low reimbursement rate (Medicare percentage based or their own that is lower than UCR rates).
Factor the OON billing into your rates. If you are set up with a clearinghouse, OON billing is pretty simple.

full_thread_text:

They have OON benefits with low deductible (<$2500 - arbitrary based on typical POC for my patients) or have already met their deductible AND high reimbursement rates (UCR based fee schedule)
I give a Superbill to people who have OON benefits with high deductible (>$2500) or low reimbursement rate (Medicare percentage based or their own that is lower than UCR rates).

COMMENT 2: Factor the OON billing into your rates. If you are set up with a clearinghouse, OON billing is pretty simple.

post_text: Hi, questions for seasoned private practice PTs! What are the cons when taking insurances? Do solo practice gets paid less than big hospitals/ franchise clinics from insurances? Or gets denied? Why did you stop taking insurances if cash based? I'm trying to decide which model I need to go with. My specialties are pelvic/lymph. Any thoughts on which model would be better for these specialties? TIA!

comments.text: i am currently trying to do both. I work for someone else in a clinic (I‚Äôm also pelvic floor) and there I am just about maxed out on the pay scale because of what insurance reimburses us. I am trying to start a cashed based virtual practice so I have a little more freedom

When you go insurance a lot of people talk about insurance dictating what you can and can't do with clients. But when you go the cash pay route you can do what's best for your patient plus you'll have more Financial Freedom going that route. Pelvic floor and lymphedema are really good niches and people definitely do pay cash for that.

Also, you will see a different type of client most of the time with cash vs insurance. Cash clients are typically more proactive about their health from what I have seen.

post_text: Is it true that you cannot treat Medicare patients on a cash pased basis? Does anyone know how to get around this if so?

comments.text: PTs cannot opt out of medicare so you can't charge a person with medicare cash for a service that medicare would cover. You can, with some stipulations, if they have a managed medicare plan as primary.
The workaround is to provide services that are non-covered services according to Medicare. Only if you are providing a service that are considered non-covered services then you can charge cash.

full_thread_text:
POST: Is it true that you cannot treat Medicare patients on a cash pased basis? Does anyone know how to get around this if so?

COMMENT 1: PTs cannot opt out of medicare so you can't charge a person with medicare cash for a service that medicare would cover. You can, with some stipulations, if they have a managed medicare plan as primary.

COMMENT 2: The workaround is to provide services that are non-covered services according to Medicare. Only if you are providing a service that are considered non-covered services then you can charge cash.
