post_text:
Hello there! I want to be uncaged but currently don‚Äôt have the brain power or time to do so‚Ä¶  (mom of a 3 yo and 9 month twins). Can someone shed some light on the whole ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt provide therapy services under cash pay because they‚Äôre billable to Medicare‚Äù thing? Do I have that concept wrong? I see people offering ‚Äúwellness‚Äù rather than therapy. 

If the above is how it works, aren‚Äôt you by default not providing skilled therapy covered by Medicare if you‚Äôre not documenting your services? There is no skill of a therapist if there is no documented skill of a therapist, and no physician signed POC right? What am I missing here or do I have it all wrong? 

Thanks for helping me out if you can. I have a few clients in home health that told me they‚Äôd hire me if I started my own practice, but there is absolutely so much I don‚Äôt know and I don‚Äôt have the time to figure it all out üòÖ I‚Äôve just been lurking in here trying to slowly glean information and wrap my head around this concept. Thanks üòä

comments.text:
Great question Veronica Erlenbush, and let‚Äôs get some clarity here. The reason why most PT‚Äôs say that you cannot charge cash for Medicare beneficiaries is due to the Meidcare Mandatory Claims Submission Rule. Meaning, if it is skilled PT that Medicare covers, it is mandatory that we submit a claim. Where it gets tricky, is if you have literally no relationship with Medicare, there is no way for you to submit a claim. Here is where it gets confusing: If there is no way to technically submit a claim online, but it‚Äôs still mandatory for you to do it as a non-participating provider‚Ä¶‚Ä¶you can now understand why this is talked about so much lol. Here is where I can give you clarity: Medicare does define wellness as essentially skilled care for the patient. So, if it is unskilled like simple strengthening and endurance, technically that is NOT covered UNLESS a pre-qualifying injury or hospitalization takes place. See where I‚Äôm going here? So, if a Medicare aged client is seeking you out for general strengthening and well-being and they aren‚Äôt being treated for a specific injury or disorder, you can have them sign a Medicare beneficiary form decided under their own free will to pay you out-of-pocket for wellness services.

I know it‚Äôs a mess. Honestly, I‚Äôm with PT‚Äôs who have battled this and called it unconstitutional. They have created a monopoly essentially. 

I believe the only true loophole left, is if they are truly wellness (which the funny thing is that‚Äôs about 90% of HH clients I have seen after they have been discharged from therapy). Then, as long as they are deciding under their own free will because they want to get stronger and pay you, technically they can.

You just have to be okay with some physical therapists saying it‚Äôs ‚Äúrisky‚Äù. I believe Medicare has struck immense levels of fear into our profession to try to make sure they keep their monopoly in place.

But, if a Medicare aged client who doesn‚Äôt need skilled therapy comes to me and wants to get stronger to age better, I‚Äôll see them 10 out of 10 times.

As a parent, I'll give you parent version.  You can't take cash from medicare patient for what would be something medicare pays for.  If you a rehabbing a post op knee, can't do it, but if you are keeping them from having pain while playing golf (not a covered service by Medicare) you can.

post_text:
I'm sorry if this has already been discussed, but I've tried searching for the answer, resulting in pure confusion.  I'm registered as a Med B provider, but I want to submit my claims electronically.  

When filling out the EDI enrollment form it asks me for the network service vendor (NSV) and Billing Software Vendor. Here are my questions:
1. What is NSV?
1. Recommendations for NSV and Billing Software Vendor?
1. On the JL 5010 Approved Vendor List, what does Clearinghouse (CH) mean?

Thank you so much for your responses in advance!

comments.text:
Faith Afriyie A NSV allows you to connect to your MAC. A clearing house is where your billing passes through when going out/coming back (EDI/ERA) to make sure the necessary data is completed. an example of a common clearing house is Office Ally. 

I don‚Äôt recall needing to complete info related to an NSV. I believe that the NSV would be what your clearing house chooses to use. Might be MAC/location dependent.

In Massachusetts we complete the info provided from office ally into our Medicare MAC site (NGS).
Sent you a dm!

post_text:
Happy Friday everyone! 
Question about if anybody has experienced this: 

I am 6 months into running my cash based solo practice. I have an office space in town and am not set up to bill insurance nor have I contracted with insurance under my NPI Type 2/my LLC; however I am contracted for all insurances with my OP staff PT job in the next town over for which I still work 2 days per week (I'm in NM). I must have somehow gotten into the system for my personal LLC and have started receiving referrals (Medicare included) from local doctors. This is awesome; however, I have had to contact those offices to let them know I am currently fee for service cash based and am not billing insurance through my personal office location. 

Has anyone deal with this? It sucks to turn patients away, but it is what it is!

comments.text: I would say get credentialed with Medicare.  Open up your base. On the other check to see if they have OON benefits and then if not offer cash pay options

Agree with Sue Doyle here. No reason not to credential with Medicare. The 100ish/visit you could get is likely far more than you make at your OP job and this population may help you escape employment faster (assuming that is something you want)

Lots of potential to build relationships and transition to wellness/cash based care. Also you never know who might be that one patient you see that refers you 10+ of your ideal clients.

full_thread_text:
POST: Happy Friday everyone! 
Question about if anybody has experienced this: 

I am 6 months into running my cash based solo practice. I have an office space in town and am not set up to bill insurance nor have I contracted with insurance under my NPI Type 2/my LLC; however I am contracted for all insurances with my OP staff PT job in the next town over for which I still work 2 days per week (I'm in NM). I must have somehow gotten into the system for my personal LLC and have started receiving referrals (Medicare included) from local doctors. This is awesome; however, I have had to contact those offices to let them know I am currently fee for service cash based and am not billing insurance through my personal office location. 

Has anyone deal with this? It sucks to turn patients away, but it is what it is!

COMMENT 1: I would say get credentialed with Medicare.  Open up your base. On the other check to see if they have OON benefits and then if not offer cash pay options

COMMENT 2: Agree with Sue Doyle here. No reason not to credential with Medicare. The 100ish/visit you could get is likely far more than you make at your OP job and this population may help you escape employment faster (assuming that is something you want)

Lots of potential to build relationships and transition to wellness/cash based care. Also you never know who might be that one patient you see that refers you 10+ of your ideal clients.

post_text:
I‚Äôve been told that no commercial insurance shares their fee schedule until one credentials. However, it would really help to make this decision of credentialing with some private insurance s such as BCBC, Aetna, Anthem etc if someone is willing to share an estimate of what the reimbursement looks like for such insurances, if your outpatient practice already credentials with them? I have a mobile PT practice and based in CA, if it helps.
Thank you üòä

comments.text: You might try staying out of network for higher reimbursement rates, it also gives you a chance to see what those OON rates are, if you are able to get OON coverage for most of your clients, and see which insurance companies are the most popular in your area (probably the best reason to go in network is if you have a lot of patients coming in with BCBS, for example).  Then you can apply for in network status, as someone already mentioned, and choose whether to accept or decline- because they will not give you a fee schedule if you are not in network and most will have you sign a contract saying you cannot share their in network rates- but they might give them to you if you are about to sign an in network contract.
This is all very very helpful to know and make this credentialing decision accordingly. Thank you so much üôèüòç love this group and everyone‚Äôs willingness to share and help!!

post_text: Officially hired on my first contractor for my mobile practice ü•≥I bill OON. I am already credentialed with all the insurance companies; do I need to add the new therapist on and credential her or does it all fall under the company? Any help would be great. TY!

comments.text: For OON, it should be based off your tax id#

#Compliance perspective - verify w/each plan. Most states have Insurance Fraud Laws, including Florida. I am aware of this being implemented involving a non-credentialed therapist billing under credentialed therapist - so verify how your company would bill, based on your credentialed status, for a "contracted" employee.  A lot of pieces to consider. 

GoToTheSource: Each insurance plan;  FL Statutes 817.234

post_text: Has anyone treated anyone with a long term care insurance policy? I have a potential patient who has both a LTC policy and Medicare. I called the LTC plan and asked if outpatient PT provided in the home was covered and they said ‚Äúany service provided in the home is considered home care and is covered‚Äù. I clarified that this was technically OUTPATIENT PT, and she still said because it‚Äôs in the home it‚Äôs covered and she‚Äôll just have to submit an invoice. She also has Medicare‚Ä¶ can I go through the LTC instead of Medicare? Something is telling me I can‚Äôt but I‚Äôm not sure.

comments.text: Bill Medicare for services that are medically necessary.  Once beneficiary reaches a point that they benefit from visits but do not require the skills of PT then bill LTC.  Orders may state that patient continues to benefit from balance, endurance, and/or strength training to maintain quality of life and the ability to age in place.
I feel like you should go through Medicare and bill LTC policy the difference? Just my thought process

post_text:
Anyone has any experience seeing a teenager (17yo) longish term?
I‚Äôve had kids with developmental delay in the caseload for years, but that is different.
He is 17, diagnosed with scoliosis and lyme. The scoliosis is currently an uphill battle because he is still growing, so not making much improvement but not worsening. But the main thing is that due to the postural issues abs lyme issues he gets muscle spasms, cramps and pain. He has allergy to tons of stuff so no pain medication (though not sure mom would want a 17yo to depend on pain medication). 
I‚Äôve been seeing him since September last year now. We‚Äôve got to a point where things were good enough we were down to every other week, but back to once a week. Any more than that he locks into spasms, pain holds back from doing activities, etc.
I am out of network with his insurance (tricare select), who has been paying all along without a single concern)‚Ä¶ but I‚Äôve been getting nervous lately that while I know we are holding curve from worsening, and releasing spasms so that he can do activities etc, if tricare was to ever request my notes, there would be no ‚Äúnet gain‚Äù‚Ä¶.  More like maintaining‚Ä¶ I keep getting worried I will suddenly get a letter asking me to return all payments or who knows‚Ä¶. 
Suggestions? Thoughts?

comments.text: My son sounds similar. Severe scoliosis. He is 26 yrs old. Severely disabled. He has PT once a week all year long. If we don't, he wakes up "stuck". I'm a biller, not a PT so I don't have the right terminology but his legs are "scissored" and stuck. Lots of pain. I haven't had problems with insurance paying, but as a Mom, I'm not worried. I'm kinda a Momma Bear when it comes to my son. They wouldn't win. Most of my "Mama Bear" friends are in the same boat. He's not regressing, preventing pain, requires skill, I can't see them denying. For the sake of the kiddo, please don't stop. üôèüòâ

At 17 he isn‚Äôt skeletally mature. Can you document height and weight and then the changes in height and weight? Or get measurements from mom from early treatment to now? Then you can justify by saying that growth affects his scoliosis and progress. Often times insurance does not take into account a child‚Äôs growth and they should!  I went through something similar with my son and bracing and fought it like this and it worked.

post_text: Insurance Question: I have a patient with Aetna Medicare and Medicaid dual plan. On availity it says she needs a prior Authorization. So I evaluate the patient and send the prior authorization request on availity and it says Further Medical Review Required. What are my chance to get the Authorization prior to my second visit? Also, if it requires Authorization will I get paid for the evaluation or not? Please guide.

comments.text: My experience- eval doesn‚Äôt need prior authorization and they will pay. We don‚Äôt go out on the second visit or any further visits until we receive authorization. You can follow up with them via phone.

From my experience obtaining authorizations, they may not retro authorize. Unless your Eval date is stated as the effective date (first day of the auth period) they may reject it
But you need to have evaluated them before you can request the auth so that you can accurately provide the diagnosis and CPT codes and projected number of visits/sessions 
I have started charging the self pay rate for the Initial assessment then I call to request the auth and include the date from when I call so that the followup sessions are covered, then I balance bill the patient after the sessions process through the insurance

full_thread_text:

So I evaluate the patient and send the prior authorization request on availity and it says Further Medical Review Required. What are my chance to get the Authorization prior to my second visit? Also, if it requires Authorization will I get paid for the evaluation or not? Please guide.

COMMENT 1: My experience- eval doesn‚Äôt need prior authorization and they will pay. We don‚Äôt go out on the second visit or any further visits until we receive authorization. You can follow up with them via phone.

COMMENT 2: From my experience obtaining authorizations, they may not retro authorize. Unless your Eval date is stated as the effective date (first day of the auth period) they may reject it
But you need to have evaluated them before you can request the auth so that you can accurately provide the diagnosis and CPT codes and projected number of visits/sessions 
I have started charging the self pay rate for the Initial assessment then I call to request the auth and include the date from when I call so that the followup sessions are covered, then I balance bill the patient after the sessions process through the insurance

post_text: I am sure this has been asked before. So when I sent a claim to Medicare they paid X for the services and 20% of it would be patient‚Äôs responsibility. The patient‚Äôs responsibility portion goes to seconds insurance (Medicaid). So if Medicaid doesn‚Äôt pay any of the patient‚Äôs responsibility, can I ask patient to pay the remainder? Please guide‚Ä¶.

comments.text: If the secondary was not Medicaid then yes. But in this case, no.

Sadly, you cannot collect when Medicaid is the secondary, and Medicaid will likely not pay you the 20% because the Medicaid fee schedule is less than Medicare‚Äôs, and Medicaid will consider the therapy already paid in full.

post_text: Hello! I run a cash pay PT clinic, and I recently got a check from an insurance company. It looks like reimbursement for the patient. comments.text: It's a pain in the butt but you have to send it back. Tell the patient it was sent to you and they need to call their insurance to get a new check issued to them. I have tried signing it over to patients (didn't work) and also cashing it then writing a check to the patient. This just leads to MORE checks coming to you! Keep it off your books. Send it back. Fix this problem now before it snowballs (trust me on this!)
Did you bill the insurance?  I guess no since you are cash pay. I would call the insurance and tell them. Keep it off of your books

post_text:
Will anyone share with me the form they give patients to sign if they have Medicare but are using you for cash pay? 
Thanks so much!
Edited to add: they already use medicare services but want extra hours of cash PT each week outside of their medicare services

comments.text: You must bill Medicare for medically necessary skilled therapy services. Clients are not allowed to pay cash for these services. If they are received wellness services (be clear on how you define this) that are not covered by Medicare then there is no form that they need to sign.  If the services might normally be covered but do not meet the skilled therapy medically necessary code outlined in Section 220.2 of CMS Chapter 15 then  you will need to have the client sign an ABN. Here is the link to Chapter 15 https://www.cms.gov/Regulations-and-Guidance/Guidance/Manuals/downloads/bp102c15.pdf   Here is a link on how to correctly complete an ABN. https://www.cms.gov/Medicare/Medicare-General-Information/BNI/Downloads/ABN-Form-Instructions.pdf
Its a complete scam that medicare specificly names professions that can't opt out while saying others can for no reason at all. It's completely discriminatory and unconstitutional.

post_text: Where does medicare draw the line of 'medically necessary' (I know I'm not the first one to ask this....just frustrated again)?  Say we have someone who can perform their daily functions with no restrictions (but maybe some mild discomfort/pain), however their main complaint is that  they are limited & painful in their ability to go hiking and play pickleball.  Would a wellness plan, with a treatment focus around making hiking & pickleball easier for them to participate in,  even if it entailed some manual therapy skills, be allowed under a cash-pay arrangement?

comments.text:
Don‚Äôt confuse services covered under the Medicare benefit with medical necessity. 

Medical necessity is just one part of the requirements for covered services. 

Reasonable is another part. 

Standard of care is another part. 

This is a balancing act for sure. As Nancy mentioned, you are the therapist and make your determination based on the initial evaluation and findings. 

After that you develop your treatment plan and based on published guidelines you make a determination of what YOU believe falls within the coverage guidelines. 

You may charge cash for non-covered services and seek reimbursement for covered services. 

But reimbursement is always conditional. 

Ultimately you are not the one paying the bill nor is your patient. So Medicare would make the final determination if it ever came to that under review. 

And when Medicare makes that determination the Medicare rep will look at published guidelines and your documentation. 

I would say by far most of what I see in small, private practice outpatient therapy is largely non-covered services. But therapists are so desperate to help their patients they are willing to assume the financial liability associated with over utilization of services. Or they just don‚Äôt understand the intent of Medicare coverage.
Sounds a lot more like a cash pay service. Unfortunately Medicare isn‚Äôt concerned about someone‚Äôs ability to play pickle ball‚Ä¶ regardless of how important it is to the client

Would a wellness plan, with a treatment focus around making hiking & pickleball easier for them to participate in,  even if it entailed some manual therapy skills, be allowed under a cash-pay arrangement?

COMMENT 1: Don‚Äôt confuse services covered under the Medicare benefit with medical necessity.

post_text: Does anyone know how long it is supposed to take for credentialing? Sent in my applications via a local credentialing agent in March, received a declined letter in late April/Early May due to a ‚Äúbank letter‚Äù issue. Just curious if it‚Äôs supposed to take 90+ days? Thanks!

comments.text: I applied in middle of March, I received a bank letter issue too but received a letter to fix it before any denial. Fixed the bank issue, and was credentialed by May. My credentialing company alerted me to the issue immediately and I was able to resolve that (and one other issue) and got approved! Also, my bank letter was created online and instead I did a voided check the second time and they accepted that immediately
Not sure who you have to use but mine is Palmetto GBA and it has NOT been good.   Hopeful your path is better and those you work with are more helpful

full_thread_text:
POST: Does anyone know how long it is supposed to take for credentialing? Sent in my applications via a local credentialing agent in March, received a declined letter in late April/Early May due to a ‚Äúbank letter‚Äù issue. Just curious if it‚Äôs supposed to take 90+ days? Thanks!

COMMENT 1: I applied in middle of March, I received a bank letter issue too but received a letter to fix it before any denial. Fixed the bank issue, and was credentialed by May. Also, my bank letter was created online and instead I did a voided check the second time and they accepted that immediately

post_text:
Hi guys, 

  Is it okay to use your personal laptop for work? Or do I need to get a new laptop that is separate for work?

comments.text: Depends on how you're able to accommodate HIPAA guidelines and the standards of whatever insurances you work with.  A separate laptop isn't strictly necessary, but it may be easier to make a separate, protected account on your existing device for work.  This has two benefits: added protection against patient data loss/theft, and helping literally keeping your work and home life separate
My personal was a mac. My emr could not go on a mac‚Ä¶ soooo I had to get a windows

post_text: Any other Floridians doing mobile/cash based? I know the practice act requires rx after 30 days but how do you tend to go about that? I do pelvic, so especially if they were referred by Licensed nurse midwife or doula? Just looking for clarity on how hard and fast that 30 days is, is it only relevant with insurance based, or if there are lüëÄpholes‚Ä¶

comments.text:
There's some verbiage in the FL practice act regarding being able to treat if the condition was previously assessed by the physician, but honestly after reading it myself I decided that it's a safer option to just get something in writing.  It may be a good idea to take a look at the practice act and get your own impression of that portion of it.  

The 30 day rule wouldn't be impacted by cash vs. insurance.

post_text:
Question:
There‚Äôs a Medicare pt who just started home health part A with a company.
She has lymphedema and she wants me to wrap/manage her legs at the same time (I have cert in Lymph Mgt). The HH therapist is not lymp certified so he can‚Äôt do that part.
Can I do session with that pt for lymph out of pocket with an ABN? If yes, what would be my reason for out of pocket pay & not utiize medicare? 
I would think lympedema is medically necessary.
I would appreciate the input!

comments.text: following because this is where the patients needs are medically necessary and the insurance/HH is hindering healing and progress.

If you are totally out of network with Medicare, I am very comfortable with patient signing stating they understand the services you are providing are not and cannot be covered by Medicare. I know that makes some people queasy, but that's my approach. Now, if you are seeing some other Medicare beneficiaries and billing Medicare, that gets iffy really quick, in my opinion.

full_thread_text:

Can I do session with that pt for lymph out of pocket with an ABN? If yes, what would be my reason for out of pocket pay & not utiize medicare? 
I would think lympedema is medically necessary.

COMMENT 1: following because this is where the patients needs are medically necessary and the insurance/HH is hindering healing and progress.

COMMENT 2: If you are totally out of network with Medicare, I am very comfortable with patient signing stating they understand the services you are providing are not and cannot be covered by Medicare.
